Finish is a nice rich roasted nutty caramel malt with some mild bitter notes, yeasty, bready nutty lingering flavor. Overall a very good, flavorful and enjoyable ale.

pour is dark chestnut brown with a tan fluffy head. Nose is heavy sweet malt, candies sugar, dark fruits, lightly green. Taste offers well balanced sweetness, notes of nuttiness, and dark fruits aplenty. Body is a touch thin with heavy carbonation and a soft feel.

aroma: caramel, bread, floral, toast, 
apparenza: brown, cloudy, rocky head, 
gusto: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
palato: medium body, average carbonation, long bitter finish, sticky, 
birra inferiore rispetto alla sorella "prior 8" ma comunque da alta scuola...rispetto alla prior 8 posso sentire sicuramente un aroma più floreale,luppolato che si avverte anche nel mezzo del gusto e nel finale lungo e amarognolo..aroma molto differente,poco pronunciato e anchesso con sentori floreali ma anche maltati (è sempre una dubbel),promossa!

une bonne bière dabbaye, arômes complexes mais pas totalement fondus, bière assez forte, longueur en bouche.
pour moi, il manque un peu d équilibre et de subtilité

Solid dubbel, but not nearly as good as the 8. Very fruity, and light on the palate. A bit pricey for what it is. Good beer though.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice amber pour with an off-white head. Sweet dark fruits with a bit of spice, some banana, and some toasted malt and toffee. A bit of yeast on the finish. The malt sweetness translates quite well to the flavor. A lot of toffee, toasted malt, and caramel. Moderate fruit notes of raisin and banana. Just a bit of clove spiciness.
Dark brown coloured beer with a small slightly brown head. It has a sweet aroma of nuts. Flavour is smooth, sweet and some alcohol is noticeable. (Bottle 33cl)
330ml bottle. Cloudy brown color. Medium off-white head, stays forever. Yeast, fruits, sweet, malty notes in aroma. Sweet, malty, fruity flavor. Dry, mild bitter ending.

Bottle 330ml
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and floral hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long malty and caramel finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Highly drinkable dubbel.  Low abv allows more nuanced aftertaste.  Figgy taste.  Once again St. B makes a beer that is at one end unique and at another typical and traditional.  Well done.

Brown colour, with a massive nice beige foam head.
Nose is powerfull, a lot of esters, candied fruits, yeast.
Mouth is full and complex, rich with sweet flavours.
Full bodied belgian beer.
Great
Great. The nose is malt forward with notes of brown sugar, caramel, and spice. The beer is deep brown with a beige cap. Sweet with just a touch of bitter balance. Smooth and a touch thin, but great.

Its sort of pecan brown colored with pale, tan head, dissipating slowly into an off white sheet. It smells of caramel and light syrupy fruits, maybe pear, and some toasted bread. Its well balanced and full flavored, tasting of sweet danish and a bit of orange. Its got a medium finish, with just a little bitter and sour. FANTASTIC.
On tap at Kloster, Madrid. Dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, toffee and malt. Surprisingly flavourful. Well balanced and very nice. (2012-08-16)

Very well-rounded and rich Dubbel, with hints of dark chocolate, usually only found in Tripels or Imp Stours with 9% or more. Easily drinkable because of that, without any of the typical Belgian sirupy sweetness (as in Chimay or Floreffe). Very composed and classy abbey ale!

Bottle. Pours dark amber brown and its hazy with a foamy off white head that sticks around. Aroma has sweet scents of raisins clove and pitted fruit along with candied sugar and yeast/malt. Taste starts bitter and malty with the fruitiness and sweet caramel candied sugars coming through along with yeast in the finish. Palate is medium and fizzy with a chalky finish.

This dubbel stands out. It had a nutty bread aroma. The appearance was brown with a reddish tint. There was a creamy palate that was comforting. The taste was bread-like as well with malts following close behind. No alcohol taste at all. There was a slight cheesy aftertaste , which is the only thing I would change. Otherwise, heads above the rest in this style.
Sarà che sono strano io, ma nelle birre di Watou, non ci trovo niente di incredibile, certo molto potabili ma non certo indimenticabili...
Pours deep amber with a high head. Aroma is malts, yeast and alcohol. Flavor is sweet malts, yeast, caramel, nuts and alcohol. Excellent "low ABV" abbey ale.
A top-notch dubbel. Rich and sweet with great spicy flavors.excellent. This is a great example of Belgian Dubbel.

Bottle pour. Chesnut color as said in description. Big beige head that fizzles away. Baked bread, brown sugar, alcohol in the nose. Taste is the same with some banana and other light fruits, hops and fresh well water in the finish.

Bottle brought from Lille. Pours dirty brown with a full beige head, that sinks but remains as a layer throughout the session. In looks, it is very similar to Westvleterens 12. The aroma, on the other hand, is more distinct, full of chocolate and dried fruit. Its a lovely aroma. The taste is more dried fruit, caramel, and licorice, backed up by a lot of bitterness. Id say the bitterness in this beer is a lot higher than is normal for this type of belgian beer, but then St. Bernardus lies smack in the middle of the Poperinge hop growing region, so why not?  The beer is lively in the mouth from typical belgian carbonation level, medium in body and with a long bitter aftertaste which gives taste of anise. I wouldnt necessarily call it a typical dubbel, its a trappist type of abbey ale of lower alcohol level. And its lovely, showing the clear relationship with the Westvleteren abbey ales.

On 33 cl bottle.
Dark color, good foam.
Some malty aromas & some dried fruit ( medium). Notes of chocolate .
Fill body and high complexity.
Good velvety carbonation  & very well balanced.
Some sweetness, also some balancing bitterness.
Very enjoyable , I should have been a monk
Bottled from old house Sheffield. Dark Belgium beer, chestnut flavours along with a nice vanilla sweetness.

bottled, served at cafe francis on pilsens main square. dark brown with a thin off-beige head; aroma of fried hazelnuts and vanilla custard; balanced and mellow, if not exactly whacking you over the head with flavour, some caramelised banana giving it a light fruitiness
Thanks SJ. I really enjoyed this. A good amount of Dark fruit, caramel, yeast. A nice full body and good banana, spice aroma.

Kleur van rozijnen met een vrij witte schuimkop. Smaak start wat prikkerig van het koolzuur en gaat over in licht bitter zoet met hinten van rozijn, banaan, bruine suiker en een vleugje gist. Geen alcohol merkbaar. Erg lekker.

Aldus Huubs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a nice raisin colour. Smells and tastes like raisin bread...yeasty, a bit of bubblegum. Brown sugar. Boozy/hoppy flavours throughout. Very nice.

Hazy reddish brown colour, reddish strong foam. Mild pleasant sweet smell.  Little fizzy on tongue, leaves mild sweet bitterness. Taste is sweet caramel but with sour tinge. Good beer, less strong than other St. Bernardus beers.
Nose does not promise much. Strong carbonation, nice touches of caramel and licorice. Pretty decent.

Aroma of raisins, brown sugar and yeast. Plum brown , retained one finger settled head. Sweet and tart dark berry flavor. Dont get me wrong its bitter as well, not a Snapple flavor here. Light foamy body with an appropriate amount of carbonated zest. A nice Belgian ale that would benefit from a heavier profile all around.

330 ml bottle into signature chalice, best by 7/22/2013.  Pours lightly hazy reddish brown color with a nice 1-2 finger dense cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some nice spotty lacing clings to the glass, with some carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, fig, apple, caramel, banana, molasses, clove, herbal, earth, bread, and yeast spices.  Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity.  Taste of big raisin, caramel, prune, molasses, pepper, bread, toast, banana, earth, herbal, and yeast spiciness.  Light fruity tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark fruit, caramel, molasses, bread, toast, earth, banana, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit.  Nice flavor balance and complexity; with no cloying sweetness.  Medium carbonation and body; with a fairly creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a damn nice dubbel.  Nice flavor complexity and balance; and very smooth to drink.  Really enjoyable.

Unfair really - my bottle a bbe 12/2003 and Im drinking it in July 2012. Good bottle conditioned beer ALWAYS benefits from keeping several years beyond bbe date, even a relatively low alcohol one such as this.
Spicy/malty nose, beautiful deep red glowing colour, pristinely clear (after very careful pouring to avoid copious sediment).  Satisfying rounded mouthfeel. Smooth malt taste, the typical candy sugar Belgian flavour still there but reduced to a minimum in such a well-aged beer. Glorious. Thank you to Wineways of Harrogate for firstly finding this beer, and then selling it to me!

Bottle. The pour was a dark murky chestnut brown with a slight reddish hue and an average sized (1-2 finger) light tan creamy head that lasted throughout with excellent sheeting of lacing which basically coated the glass.

The aroma was of a toasted biscuit malt and a sweaty Belgian yeast with notes of caramel, toffee, banana and some dark fruit (plums and overripe grapes).

The taste had a strong malty presence and a mild sweetness with a hint of banana and caramel early on, and then slowly transformed into a much yeastier taste with a large dose of dark fruit and a mild toffee presence towards the end. The flavor lasted a good amount of time after the swallow with a sweet yeasty flavor and a mild fruity ester that was left to linger on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was somewhere between light and medium in body with a creamy and a tad oily texture and a medium carbonation.

Overall an extremely tasty and very easy to drink Dubbel, and is a brew that hides all notion of somewhat moderate ABV...

Sampled 2 * 33 cl. bottles @ Black Frés Forest BBQ // it has been a while since I picked up a new Bernardus beer, some of their beers were one of the first ones I tried, usually representative & solid but not top tier & touch outside of my preferences which applies to this one as well // murky brown fruit colour with a slightly tanned, off-white head // smells murky & earthly foremost, strong Belgian yeast presence, touch overkill, murky dark fruits, malts, touch berries // taste follows suit, excess yeast or intentional strong dominance, earthly, murky, murky dark fruits, berries, malt heavy, hint of EU hops in finish // body is murky as well & defined by heavy yeast presence // within style, solid but not really my suiting my preference
Full-bodied and good with a pleasant sweet taste. Fruity and some raisins in the taste.

Brown colour with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Notes of citrous, earthy and caramel.  Flavour is mildy  sweet but well balanced. Notes of belgian yeast, bananas, sweet malt and faint hints of alcohol.  Medium long aftertaste.

33cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. Best before 2014-12-24. Brown colour with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Notes of belgian yeast and caramel. Also notes of bread and malts. Flavour is also sweet. Notes of belgian yeast, bananas, sweet malt and faint hints of alcohol. Perhaps a better version of Prior 8. Medium long aftertaste.
Exactly what you would expect.  The taste is nuts, dark fruits, spices, earth, and light sweetness up front that finishes pretty dry with loads of dark fruit and cola.  Pretty nice just a bit thin.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2012 Pours opaque brown with one finger if creamy head. Smells of yeast ad malts. Tastes of sweet caramel, fruity yeast, and slightly bitter on the finish. Mouthfeel is very creamy with medium carbonation.

330ml bottle from Bierzwerg. Dark ruby brown colour with nice head that last long time. Aroma is malt, dark fruits. Flavour is caramel, dark fruits, hops, belgian yeast. Sweet aftertaste, but in a good way.

12 oz bottle pours hazy amber with a off white head.  Aroma of yeast and slight malts.  Taste is much the same.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2016 Deep dark brown colour. A lot of foam that stays long. Sweet aroma. Taste is medium, sweet, soft, a bit spicy afterwards. 
Syvän tummanruskea olut runsashiilihappoisella vaahdolla. Vaahto ei todellakaan katoa, vaan säilyy pitkään noin puolen sentin kerroksena oluen pinnalla (Rochefortin lasista nautittuna). Tuoksu on pehmeä. Maku keskitäyteläinen, makea, pehmeä, jälkimaku hieman mausteinen. Erittäin nautittava olut ja pieniin prosentteihinsa nähden suorastaan mainio.
Now I love me a double. One of the originals. These are great cause you get everything that kicks ass with quad with high drinkability. Nutty and fizzy. Belgian yeasty finish.

Grapey, pear like aroma.  Medium brown body.  Taste is sugary pear with a touch of yeast funk.  More flavor than you would expect.  Towards the end of the sip the flavor bursts with carbonation and dissapates pretty quickly.

The first beer of my St Bernardus evening. I have a mixed four pack of 330ml bottles that I am drinking, reviewing three as I go (I have already reviewed the 12 some time ago).

This bottle is best before 15th Feb 2010, today is 1st March 2008. It was poured into my Westmalle bowl glass.

Looks wonderful at first, a deep clear redish brown with a full light biege foaming head. The head fell away just a bit to quickly for me, I like it to stay untila at least Ive had a sip or two.

Rich malty molasses fill your nose and a toffee, coffee sweetness comes through too.

The taste was a big let down for me, none of the flavours of the smell comes through into the actual beer. It is almost the blandest and tasteless dubbel I can remember having and I have had more than a few over the years.

It cant be discribed as watery, but it isnt a thick or viscous in any way either. A sourness comes into the mouthfeel as the beer warms in the mouth and I didnt like that either!

All in all a mixed start to my evening of tastings. I was expecting a lot more from this beer.

2012.05.09 - 750ml bottle in pint glass. Pours a mid brownish orange.  Very active foamy head recedes slowly, leaves foam around the glass. Taste is pretty much what you'd expect if you've had other St. Bernardus brews.  Clear Belgian taste, flavorful but not as strong as the higher abv SB offerings. Much closer to a session beer than other SB offerings.
Nice dark brown color with 2 fingers of foam, very fruit aroma. Hints of lemon and other sour fruit, kind of unexpected. Looks like a heavy beer which it isnt.

Poured into my St. Bernardus chalice from an 11.2 ounce bottle best before 19-04-14.

A: Beautiful opaque chestnut body with light visible through the edges, dense billowing tan head looks wonderful in the chalice.

S: This is pretty straight forward, a bit earthy and floral with fruity esters, slight biscuit aroma.

T: Wow, the flavor is full here, in a good way. Mildly fruity from start to finish hinting at grapes and apples, while a biscuit flavor lays the ground work. This is an excellent beer.

M: This is a pretty thick beer with mild carbonation.

O: The flavor of this really shocked me coming from the rather weak aroma, I say weak only in comparison to strength. This is one of my favorite dubbels now with a lot of complexity to it.

LIVE RATING: Bottle from Craft Beer Co, London on 7th May 2012. Pours reddish brown with a yellowish-white collapsing head and a little lacing. Rich yeasty, cheesy and hoppy aroma. Rich, earthy malts and citrus fruit in-mouth, fresh-baked bread, fruitcake also present. Tangy sweetness in the aftertaste. One to sup and savour. Zingy mouthfeel and fair body albeit a little light for its alcoholic strength.

Tap @ Milltown.   Dark red amber with a small off-white head.  Nose is spicy, dark fruits, phenols.  Flavor is dark fruits--raisin, prune, plum,--bready malt, leather.  Pretty solid dubbel.  Not a style I care for too much anymore but this is well done.

The aroma is serious Belgian funk. Sour raisins. Sweet grapes. Complex and great.

Blush-red appearance, decent half-finger of head. Hazy, lots of carbonation.

The flavor is notes of white wine and sweet grape juice. Spicy Belgian funk. Slightly tawny. Sweet, grapey finish. Like Welchs Concorde grapes.

The feel is fizzy, creamy, and chalky, with an ashy finish. Sweeter than expected. Very grapey after a funky start.

Pours a clean mahogany brown with deep ruby highlights. Two fingers of creamy off white head.  Slow to dissipate.  Rich and malt forward nose. Lightly leathery and earthy.  Raisin and prune, lots of dried dark fruits.  Lightly estery sweetness with a spicy quality. Notes of caramel.

Pours a dark ruby with a nice constant head. Aromas of malt, candied sugar, light cocoa, raisin/fig and Belgian yeast. Initial taste is sweet and malty with a slight dusty finish. Flavors of cocoa, dusty, funk, dried fruits, candied sugar and a touch of alcohol. Mouthfeel is bland, slightly sticky. Overall...its ok. Kinda disappointing.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle is hazy reddish brown with thin off white head, aroma brought ntoes of biscuit, caramel, earth, nice yeasty notes with some slight esters, touch of cocoa and nutty notes as well.  Taste is a fairly decent but a bit weak, nice cocoa, nuts, toffee and caramel, touch of biscuit and yeast, hints of earth and slight grass, finishes fairly sweet.

A- fruit with light caramel and coriander
A - dark, hazy brown with lasting cream coloured head
T - sweet with roasted bitter
P - mid to full and soft
O - goooood!!!!

330ml Bottle:  Got in trade from smith4498; THANKS Jason!  Aroma of malt and Belgian yeast.  Poured chestnut-brown in color with a large, creamy, dense, rocky, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny and small-sized particles throughout.  Good lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, Belgian yeast, yeast, dust, raisins, and and slight dark ripe fruit.  Medium body.  Slick, creamy, then lightly sticky and dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Medium sweet, malt, Belgian yeast, dust, finish is sticky and dry.

Une double, encore, comme la Prior en 8 %abv, toujours sans mention
sur létiquette, mais avec une intention claire (pardon foncée) de faire ce
genre de bière.
Couleur châtaigne, avec une levure très foncée et importante, quil convenait de verser dans mon exemplaire parce quelle arrivait très tôt.
Ma bouteille était avec une date au 16/6/11.
Bien vivante, mais une mousse beige qui retombe très (trop) vite.
Odeur de pruneaux, poire verte, date et une pointe de cassonnade.
Première bouche très amère (beaucoup plus que prévu à la vue et aux
arômes), pas de céréales mais des fruits verts...
Deuxième plus équilibrée avec du pain frais et une pointe de pomme.
Troisième nez très fin.
Troisième bouche où une belle amertume souligne le malt.
Longueur très jolie, en croissance de complexité et avec une certaine 
douceur qui sinstalle.
La levure est plus rectiligne que la Prior mais soutenue.
La finale va "a mas", sans doute pas à messe, mais sympathique certainement. En Flandre, les gens disent quils vont déguster une 
"Paterke", donc cest un surnom de sympathie, et cette bière en effet 
mérite dêtre connue, elle est valeureuse.
Un petit Pater et deux Ave....
St bernardus for people who are driving. Subtly sweet aroma full of fresh yeast. Taste is a subtler version of the abt 12. Delicious
Bottle from Coppers in Newcastle. Mahogany coloured with quite high carbonation. Rich malty and toffee with sweet chocolate notes and a spicy red fruity warming finish.

Bottle. Reddish, light brown colour with an off white head. Aroma of cookies, spices, molasses, wine and port. Flavour is medium sweet with medium bitter. Kind of yeasty and well balanced. Another good beer from Watou.

From back log 
Head: off white, large, foamy 
Colour: dark brown 
Smell: hopy, dried fruits, tad sweet, yeasty bitter, malts, bit of candy sirup 
Taste: start is malty deep rich and full bodied , sweet , chocolat, some grainy touches, candy sirup, dark brown bread, end is bittersweet, earhty after
Bottle. Dark reddy brown with a generous tan beige head. Dry Belgian yeast with nice fruity presence. Banana, clove, red berry. Light pepper and a fair whack of  caramel. Foamy. Very nice.

23/III/2012 33cl bottle @ Multatuli (Gent) - BB: 25/II/14 (2012-261) 
Little cloudy red brown beer, sediment floating around, big irregular creamy beige head, pretty stable. Aroma: pretty hoppy, dried figs, bit sugary, flowers, some banana peel, touch of caramel. MF: good carbon, medium to full body. Taste: banana, some citrus. Aftertaste: pretty bitter hoppy, caramel, banana.

Bottle (750 cork/cage) Pour is reddish brown with a tight creamy tan head that last forever.
Aroma is soft fruity malt. Dark fruit, whole wheat bread, light toasted maltiness.
Body is a touch on the light side.
flavour is dark fruit again. hints of coffee and toast. Light herbal bitterness in the finish.

33 cL bottle into St Bernardus glass @ The Pub in Brugge.  Healthy creamy head over a red brown beer.  Red fruit flavour, full bodied.  Hoppy lightly fruity aroma, like a lot of reasonable Belgian beers.  A pretty decent and flavoursome beer, not extra special though.

From notes.  First reviewed 11/30/2011.  Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle into a my St. Bernardus Watou goblet.

My pour is a hazy faded caramel brown color with ruby edges. A fluffy eggshell cap leaves nice lacing down the sides of the glass.

The aroma is a bit soft. Caramel malt and cocoa are most noticeable, with spicy Belgian yeast and dark fruits in the background.

The flavor starts sweet and stays that way all the way through. Caramel malt brings out some cocoa, molasses, and brown bread in the malt. A fairly soft dark fruit presence of figs, dates, and raisins is gentle and fairly hard to distinguish. A bit of clove and other spices are present in the middle and leading to the end. The finish is clean, with a little spice and a soft sweetness.

The creamy carbonation never stops, it just keeps coming. The very intense carbonation scrubs away any residue after each sip and goes beyond creating a smooth feel. There is a light graininess noticeable after a few sips as well. The body drinks on the light side for the style.

The carbonation is really the X factor in this beer. The nose and flavor are nice and standard for the style, but the carbonation really explodes on the tongue. I think it takes a little bit away from the experience, but this is still a nice beer.
Tap. Hazy brown with creamy  head. Smells like raisin bread with a citrus note coming in. Sweet. Round mouthfeel with carbonation kicking in.

750 ml. Cloudy brown body with a fizzy, off-white head that recedes to small pools. Aroma of candy sugar, caramel, toasted grain, herbal earthiness. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Slight musty, earthy taste along with sweet sugar and toasted grain. Slight metallic taste in the background was well as some raw grain. A bit thin, but easy drinking.

Bottle, approximately two years or more old.  Whoops?  Pours a deep mahogany and dark ruby hued brown with a medium sized beige head.  Big oxidization on the nose, soft and sweet, caramel and sweet candy.  Medium bodied, a nice caramel sweetness, touches of paper behind the oxidization and malt, but nothing overbearing.  Gentle and easy.

Bottle from Belgianshop. Pours dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits and malts, light spicy. Taste is moderate sweet, raisins and plums. Fillling mouthfeel. Well hidden alcohol. Good.

Lovely Belgian head forms off the pour; big and unabashed, creamy and dense two fingers of foam that holds well and leaves a very fine lace. The beer a hazy mahogany with very fine, very sparse carbonation.  The nose is heavily spicy, earthy, with notes of heather, peat, bitter herbs, liquorice root, bog-moss, burnt cashews and scorched treated pine, quite unusual and original. Strong, rich flavours penetrate quickly in the mouth. The body big, the feel rounded and smooth with a creamy finish. Sweet, plummy fruit, very vinous Shiraz-like flavours seem to dominate. Very earthy, peaty in back, quite dry, a little liquorice, fusel alcohol, rough woody notes and that boggy moss of the aroma. I like it. The finish is not too long, quite woody as the other flavours fade off. Wonderful stuff. A delicious Belgian ale that can proudly sit alongside the big boys of this brewery.  (33cL, BB 18/08/14, Cellarbrations Carlisle)
The aroma and appearance invite you in with bitters and citrus notes.  But the ale is more complex with little citric flavors and more of the hops and yeast coming through.

AparÃªncia: cobre escuro, espuma mÃ©dia e cremosa, pouco persistente
Aroma: forte, complexo, doce, fermento,  torrado, doce, banana, caramelo
Sabor: leve doce, leve amargo, leve alcool, complexo, torrado, caramelo, banana, frutas escuras (?)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle poured into a goblet

a: muddy brown hue, large off white head with very good retetnion, light lacing. 

s: dark fruit: plum, grape, and slight banana.

t: nice biscuity base, plum, grape, nut. Nice flavor profile, well balanced

m&d: light to medium bodied, very drinkable
Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.
a stinky delicious dubbel, one of the best.  It has a fruity aroma, tons of taste all through the palate,  and a medium sweet, medium bitter aftertaste.
Medium brown color with a thin white head. Nutty aromatics along with some savory aromatics. Banana and malty flavors on the palate. Balanced mouthfeel with a long finish.
Opaque chestnut Pour with generous Sudsy White head.  Fresh Aroma.  Stingy carbonated palate.  Nice earthy, malty flavor with a nice finish.  Amazing how well this masks the 6.7% etoh.

Draft at Birrerria Paradiso.  Raisiny red-brown.  Thin beige head.  Mellow nutty, raisin, date.  A little macro of a mouthfeel for an Abbey Ale, some metallic tones.  Raisiny, brown sugar, but pretty mild.  A little bit of a mess, while still fairly tasty, lacks the rich chocolate tones I remember from the bottle.  Surprisingly pedestrian, mild brown chocolate tones.

Bottled. Brown color with a tan head that start creamy but just keep a lacing until the end. Aroma is malty. Flavor is quite spicy and dry, kinda watery, medium carbonation, mouthfeel is dry, with some sweetness.

"Purchased at ""The Liquor Shop"" in Tyngsboro, MA on December 27th as a gift set of St. Bernardus Beers w/ a chalice
Stored at 39 degrees in my fridge until New Years Eve
Served at 48 degrees into a St. Bernardus Chalice
Label reads: 19/09/14
A - Deep amber color typical of a Dubel from Belgium. Two finger head was produced at the pour recommended on the side of the bottle. I tried to see through the ale but simply cant. Its not completely dark but its dark enough. A bit of sediment settled to the bottom.
S - Dry fruits hit the nose first followed by classic Belgian yeast smell which always makes me smile. The dry honey scent is so classic among these beers. I picked up some toffee or vanilla undertones.
T - A very surprising taste.There is a lot more carbonation than I expected and the beer is dryer than I assumed it would be based on the smell. The finish is like a dry champagne and the start has taste of figs and cigar smoke (the good kind)
M - Lively dry carbonation fills my mouth with one swish but not all of the beer bubbles up. Its still a medium bodied beer and, at 6.7%, thats not too surprising. Its a very tasty beer with a nice mouthfeel.
O - I wouldnt buy this again. The Bernardus 12 is still my favorite. This is a decent beer Id serve to friends while eating chips & salsa or some of my Trappist Pate served on crackers. Its a great belgian beer but not very memorable."

caramel nose and taste. Also a recognizable aroma as i like to say " water van de ijzer". Most of the west flanders brewerys has that aroma/taste.
Nice, good balanced beer.
amber, cloudy, tan foam, hay, dough, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter, medium sweetness, very bitter,

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of white fruit, citrus, dark Belgium bread, dough, toasted malts.  Very dark brown with a small off-white head the mostly diminished and left ok lace.  Flavor is malty sweet and not bitter.  Palate is medium bodied and oily average.  Overall a nice malty brew with a Belgium yeast flavor.  A decent brew.
chocolate, herbs, basement aromas, butterscotch, brown, tan foam, brown foam, light sweetness, very bitter, heavily sour, sticky, flat, long finish,

On tap at Alquitara (Madrid). Hazy brown colour with a good formation of a frothy and off-white head. Nice lacework. Aroma is toasty, slightly caramelish and spicy. Flavour is sweet at the beginning with a final slightly bittery. Dense on palate, bready and toasty sugar notes. Dry final. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium. Texture is oily.

330 ml in St. Bernardus chalice pours cloudy brown with off white head. Delicious aroma of banana, bubblegum, toffee, fruity sweetness, while grain bread. The taste is smooth and very full, even more than the smell. All the above plus some more fruit, pear and plum. Smoothly sweet and so good, tho still not as awesome as the prior 8. It does open with a little warmth as the full grain and yeasty esters hide at cooler temps.

33 cl. bottle @ home. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Yeasty aroma with some caramel. Taste is likewise. As mentioned by others this beer needs some time in the glass before its unfolds its whole palate of flavors. so pour at room temperature or at least above 12 degrees Celsius.

[Rated 12/06/2009] Bottle. Pours dark caramel colored, aroma is of raisins and fruit, strong and pleasant. Flavor is a little light, though, with a rather bland finish. While I enjoy it I dont think it is put quite well together unlike some of its bigger brothers like Abt. 12.
Bottle in a gift pack from the beer store. Pours brown with a lingering head. Aroma of fruits and other stuff. Taste of fruits, hops, some caramel. Gets better the longer it sits.

Pours a muddy brown with a very thick beige head that sticks around. Needless to say the lacing is impressive too. Aroma is fruity with a slight alcoholic tinge.Taste is highly carbonated carmel and root beer. Finishes firly dry with a sweet aftertaste. Not bad, mainly a sipping brew

Hazy dark amberish brown with a generous light tan head. Belgian malty nose with a bit of rustic toffee, toast, dried cranberry, and a touch of raisin.  The maltiness on the flavor wasnt vey complex and kinda let me down. It had some dark fruitiness and some berry tones, as well as perhaps a bit of smoke, accompanied with some dark semi sweet Dubbel maltiness. As it warms, it actually becomes a little more complex in as much as the individual flavors gain a little more contrast. Adds a little more raisin and a touch of toffee as well. Definitely better when closer to room temp.

From a 330ml bottle on 1/1/2012. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a medium head. Has an aroma of green apples and a touch vinegar. In the mouth, you get some dark fruits and more apple and vinegar. The carbonation starts out a little high but improves. Cant say I enjoyed this one a whole lot.

33 cl. bottle, poured into a trappist glass. Dark brown colour with ruby hues. Medium sized white head that fades to a thin layer. A lot of spices in the aroma: Soy sauce, bread, herbs, slight cough drops and some bitter hops.
Light bitter taste, very herbal and spicy. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Long lasting finish with a strong herbal, yeasty and spicy note. This beer is for sipping, the flavour really unfolds, if the brew is allowed to rest in the glass for a while.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a dark brown colour with a good size head and good carbonation.
Very clear dark hoppy aroma with hints or chess nuts there. 
Taste is a very nice balance of hops, yeast and fruits.

Clear reddish-brown with a small, yet resilient, off-white head. Aroma of sweet fruit, toffee, caramel, raisins, and sugar. It tastes of sweet fruit and malts and yeast, with a nice little hop bitterness at the finish. Medium bodied, moderately carbonated, ever so slightly boozy. Really good stuff, it smells like its going to be a sugar bomb, but the sweetness is nicely subdued.

33cl bottle. Hazy brown with a big tanned head. Nose : Dried fruits, alcohol, fruity esters. Ice-cream with raisins. Sip : Milk like, mouthful feeling and creamy. Medium carbonation. Sweet with dried fruits aromas, bananas. After couple of sips in the aftertaste, the bitter hops come out and make a great closure. Im a bit bored with belgian dark beers to be honest. This one added some finesse to the texture and the aftertaste leaves nice feeling.
A little thin on the palate, but has a nice sweet and nutty aroma with a solid complexity on initial and after taste.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a medium creamy off white head. The aroma is anise, dark fruit, light acid, spices and raisins. The flavour is dakr malts, toasted caramel, ligth acid, dark fruit, berries and has a dry bitter finish. Excellent dubbel.

330 ml bottle, ABV is 6.7%. Will soon be available at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Brown colour, huge off-white to beige head. Pleasant spicy aroma, notes of brown kandij sugar, dried figs and oak. The flavour has the same elements as the aroma, and is not too sweet. A very drinkable dubbel!

330 ml bottle bought @ Bierkompass.de and consumed on December 6. Gusher! Pours very hazy dark chestnut with a big brownish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is malty sweet and yeasty with pumpernickel, caraway and some hints of alcohol. Taste is sweet and bready with cereal, orange zest, golden syrup, apples and yeast. Finish is slightly sweet and slightly bitter and lasts for quite some time.

Cloudy dark brown/caramel color with nice collar. 
Sweet smell of caramel and good abbey beer.
Little sweetness / taste of caramel, strong aftertaste. Very tastefull!

Bottle.  Pours a brownish color with a thick head and lacing.  Aroma is caramel, bread, coffee. Taste is lightly bitter with a smooth trail.  Medium bodied.. thinner than the average Belgian ale.  Pretty good.

330ml bottle from Cracked Kettle
BBE 24.06.14 - Pours brown with a massive foamy head. Aroma has notes of fruits, yeast, raisin, caramel and syrup. Taste is slightly sweet with notes of caramel, toffee, bready malts and spices. Finish is warming and smoothly fruity. Well balanced, tasty dubbel.

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours chestnut brown with a medium-large off-white head. Good retention. Bright malty aroma of caramel, dough, dark fruit, and yeast. Medium sweet fruity flavor, medium body, heavy carbonation, sticky texture, and a dry, bitter finish.

Bottle from Beers of Europe
Brown-amber, quite hazy, frothy white head which dissipates to thin layer, reasonable lacing.
Aroma of caramel, malt, yeast,bread dough, sweet malt, some fruit, hint of molasses.
Taste of breas, yeast, caramel malt, some peppery spice bitterness in the middle, hint of alcohol.
Palate - medium to high carb, light to medium body, smooth but light. Finish is dry, bit of malt, some lingering bitterness.
Overall - Easy drinking, lighter version of the bigger St. Bernardus ales. A very good ale but I prefer the stronger, richer versions.

Caramel, toffee, and brown bread aroma.  More of the same in the flavor.  Tastes very similar to the Prior 8, but relies more heavily on carbonation than alcohol for balance.  Not quite as good as its big brothers from St. Bernardus, but still a really, really good beer.

Pours a hazy chestnut brown with a thin white cap. The aroma is sweet, over ripe fruit, yeast, basement, big on the raisins. The flavour is also big on the raisin sweetness, with some bready malts, bit of spice and yeast in the middle, a sort of sour cherry, peach tartness mixed with an off bitterness in the end trails off into the finish, great brew!
Light beer, easy to drink. Tate a little like rochefort 6. Very good harmony. Taste it.
750 ml pours a dark brown color  tan head. Aromas of caramel, cereal, and yeast. Very smooth, a great beer.
Bottle pours dark reddish brown with thin tan head. Aromas of caramel, cereal, clove, belgian yeast. A little bit spicy, mostly extremely smooth and creamy. Fairly thin body.

Fles 33cl
Kleur: roodbruin met een flinke creme schuimkraag die snel kleiner wordt.
Geur: fruitig en zoet.
Smaak: Redelijk zoet, prikkelend. Met een scherpe nasmaak.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Purchased 6-8 weeks ago.

Appearance: Moderate head. Lasted around 5 minutes, but not very full. Murky red-brown color. Dark area, but when applied light to, could see good carbonation. Great lasting lacing effect. 4/5

Aroma: Smells sweet with a slight citrus and yeast smell. Slightly sour. Almost a soapy smell to it. 8/10

Palate: Watery texture. Lively. 3/5

Flavor: Sweet and acidic flavor. Long duration lasting long after it was all gone. 7/10

Overall: I was slightly disappointed that there was not a thicker texture to go with the dark color, but this is a decent dubbel nevertheless. Certainly not the best Ive tried. 12/20

Dark red body with a big white creamy head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel, cereal, apple and a strange acidity. Smooth easy drinking if not a little thin palate. Flavour is balanced, with yeast and a relatively dry finish.
Bottle. Poured dark brown. Good level of bitterness, if a little light on the palate.

From notes: pours hazy nut brown with a small white head.  Mild banana ester aroma mixed with some yeast and spice.  Medium-bodied with some depth to it.  Flavor was mostly nutty, with some yeast in the finish.
Hazy light brown coloured beer with small brownish head and no carbonation visible. Full sparkling and creamy palate. Finish is malty bit roasted with a bitter dry ending.

Pours a nice dark brown color with brown foam head. Aroma is roasted, nuts with a strong bitter taste. Im very pleased by its palate for the bitterness has an interesting aftertaste and it overall develops great in the mouth.
Solid belgian dubbel, Brown sugar, dark roasted malts,  Classic example of a belgian dubbel.

Bottle 33 cl, Cracked Kettle. Pours cloudy mahogany with a great beige creamy head leaving lace. Aroma is malty, buckwheat, sourish, fruity, prunes and fidges. Flavor is very malty, fruity, bitter, sweet, phenolic and apples. Finishes bitter sweet and fruity.

Huge head!  Brown with a red hue.  Off white head.  Weeee.  I smell brown sugar and molasses?  Probably molasses.  Bitter yet sweet.  Has some dates in the flavor.  Bitter dates.  Is that such a thing?  Probably.  Guy on the label of the bottle looks pretty happy.  He probably drank some of this beer.  Weeee.

Aroma is of dark fruit with a hint of alcohol.  The flavor also includes dark fruit and is malty, although not overly sweet.  Although not as thick or complex as other dubbels, this was pretty good, more solid than exceptional.
Bottle pours a hazy brown with a huge creamy light brown head. Scent is caramel, spice and yeast. Taste is sweet fruity, spices and yeast.

poured from 330ml bottle, spicy fruity aroma, creamy white head, lovely hazy brown liquid, the taste and smell improves dramatically as the beer warms, not watery at all but maybe a bit too highly carbonated, a little bit prickly overall a nice beer, but wouldnt want too many of these ina session

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 Reviewed from notes (2007).

A: brown-amber body with a beautiful bubbly light tan head, light lacing

S: Rich, roasted malts, hints of spice, chocolate, and dark fruits

T: Follows from the aroma... decadent roasted malts with warm accents of raisins and cloves with hints of chocolate

M: Medium bodied with a healthy amount of carbonation leaves the mouth with a soft tingling sensation

D: A beautiful example of the dubbel

Slightly hazy amber with a creamy beige head, medium-full body with high carbonation.

Aroma: rough herbal hops, faint malty sweetness and fruity esters.

Taste: bright fruit esters, dark sugar, slight vinegar sourness, funk, rough grassy herbal hops.

Bottle.Pours cloudy brown with an off-white head.Aroma of malt, sugar, spice and yeast.Flavor is sweet and malt with some caramel and spice.Medium body, average carbonation.
Nice beer

Small bottle. Typical Dubbel appearance - murky brown body, big off-white head. Mellow malty aroma. Mellow dark fruity taste. Dry finish. Soft and very drinkable. However, I would rather pay a little extra and have the Abt 12.

Chestnut brown pour cloudy thin off white head light sticky lacing ... aroma of caramel malts, sweet fruits (raisins) and some candi sugar .... taste is smooth and a little creamy with a fruity yeast (raisins), light candi sugar, very light nut and burnt caramel malts with a dry smooth lightly toasted finish ... not bad but not great ... the mouthfeel saves it

Malziger und etwas stechender Geruch. Leicht fruchtiger und metallischer Antrunk, dem eine malzige Note hinterhereilt. Im Mittelteil intensiviert sich das Schokoladige, kann aber nicht so recht überzeugen. Abgang hefig mit Lebkuchenaroma. Auch hier sehr nebelig und undeutlich auf der Zunge. Viele Aromen - leider auch ein dumpfes Bier.Test vom 9.7.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Bottle in trappist glass. I keep forgetting to try these when theyve warmed up a bit - a big difference. Faint but sweet aroma. Brown colour. Sweet flavour with a slight spicy bite. This aint a 12, but its still a great beer.
Pours a dark amber with a off white head into my Chimay glass. Hints of Banana, Toffee and rasins. Very smooth mouth feel. Definately will try this again.
Hazy dark reddish brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit, yeasty and light spicy. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. Smooth. 250407

Lets see what the few words in my tasting notebook tell me.... Grains, fruit and raisins. I remember this being a rather good beer and will definitely want to try this again when a good opportunity and a reasonable price appears.
Bottle at Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Unclear dark brown color. Smell malts, caramel and sweet. Taste the same with a slight bitterness. Decent abbey dubbel.

25 cl btl. Nice head, that lasts, nice amber colour. Nice lightly dusty nose with fruitcake, creme caramel, peach and apricot. Fulbodied with some length. Soft and friendly with a little fruicake and a touch of bitternes. A nice "light" abbey ale.

330mL bottle poured hazy brown into goblet with moderate off-white head with good retention and lacing.  Aromas of roasted malt and some yeast.  Nice balance of sweet and bitter.  Nice mouthfeel and medium bodied.

Pours a cloudy light brown with a small amount of head. Aroma is of honey, jasmine, spices and bread. Taste is of honey, raisins, grains. Has light carbonation, good smooth body with a medium finish, no sign of bitterness. Very tasty dubbel.

Bottle:
Medium off white head on top of a darker brown colored beer.
Smell is a good mix of malts, caramel, darker fruits, hints of sweets, spices.
Taste light toasted malts, caramel, sweets, dark fruits, nuts, bitter and hints of toffee, barleys, yeast and spices.
Nice biter sweet aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, medium to full body and a light creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle from Csak a jó sör. Poured ruby-brown, with a lively, quick to disappear tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, plum, raisins, molasses, yeast, and hints of licorice. Caramel sweet taste, pretty strong on the palate. Dense body with high carbonation. Long lasting sweet aftertaste with some roasty notes. Good!
Pours a dark cloudy brown with a nice white head that laces well. Spiced bready aroma with some raisins and apples

Details: 33cl on tap at Den Toogoloog.
Tasting: Dark brown color with a deep red shine and a decent medium size bubble beige head. The aroma has hints of nuts and proceeds to a sweet malty aroma with some slight fruity notes and is quite appetizing. The flavor is malty with a nice refreshing fruity flavor and a light bitter ending that has a slight amount of coffee in it that creates a gentle dry aftertaste. The mouthfeel is as soft as silk and the body is medium which together with the well balanced flavors make it very drinkable. I always like St. Bernardus on tap more then the regular 33cl bottle because I find the beer much more soft and balanced while still offering the same and even more flavor. This Pater 6 is no exception on that and I have no problem drinking this beer all night. 
Conclusion: A well balanced flavourfull and especially drinkable dubbel.

Bottle.  Pours hazy dark chestnut brown with a medium, fizzy light tan head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, honey), light earthy hops, and light fruity esters with notes of dates and figs.  Flavor is heavy malt (caramel, cookie, bread), light hops, and dark fruits.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation with a tart, lightly dry finish.

Poured from a 11.2 ounce bottle into a Chimay goblet. Best before 7/30/12 stamped on back label.

Appearance: Pours an opaque medium brown color with orange-red highlights and a 1 finger greyish-white head. Sediment settles on top of the head which has nice retention. Decent lacing.

Smell: Belgian yeast, spices, sweet malt and a touch of dried fruits.

Taste: Belgian yeast and a touch of dried fruit up front followed by cloves and other spices in the middle before finishing with a bit of mildly bitter hops. Aftertaste is fairly dry and light.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a high amount of prickly carbonation.

Drinkability: Slightly above average drinkability. Despite only having a fairly low ABV% for a dubbel, this one feels a little heavier. Youll have no problem getting through the bottle, but you may not want another one in the same sitting.

Overall: Very good dubbel overall. St. Bernardus makes excellent beers and this one is no exception. I would recommend giving this one a shot.
330ml Bottle - Dark brown with a foamy head. Fruity aroma with caramel,dried fruit,marzipan and a hint of spice. Fruity and rather rich taste with notes of spicy malt,dried fruit,nuts and caramel.
Pours a dark brown with moderate head. Smells absolutely delicious, I want to eat it. Oh man, sets perfectly on the tongue and palate...salivation begins on contact. Very nice, love it.

Bottle.
Dark reddish brown with a huge tan head.
Aroma: raisins and dried fruit, some yeast, grass.
Taste: raisins, very fruity, some spices, brown sugar, but not too sweet, dried grass/hay.
Medium-bodied, moussy.
Bottle at De Groote Witte Arend. Ambeer colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, caramel, dried fruits. Flavour is fruit, caramel, dried fruits, alcohol, spices, sugar. Nice beer.

Date: July 9, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Light opague or muddy brown with medium amount of head Aroma: Slightly sweet, maybe caramel Flavor: Almost like a champagne, slightly sweet/fruity (caramel with slight banana as it warmed), tons of carbonation and a very dry finish  Other: After having the 12, I had high hopes for this one, but it fell a little short.
Big Bottle. Medium brown colored body with a red glow to it and some deep orange tints. The aroma is coffeish and caramelly. Nice fresh bitter/sweet fruity flavor, good heavy finish. Pretty good.

Copper-brown, clear and has a cream coloured, soft head. Aromas of chocolate, caramel and a lovely yeasty breadiness. Enticing and subtle rather than an overt assault on the senses. Theres also a stonefruit apricotty aroma that begins to filter through.
The mouthfeel is prominent and settles like sherbert on the tongue. A touch of fruit juice sits alongside slightly overdone toast and dates. It sits prickly on the palate and softens into a lingering aftertaste where the subtle complexity of glace fruit and allspice comes forth. Mmmm. A lot to like.

Mmm I love this style and I drooled when I saw this on the shelf at BOTW.   Orange/red/hazy, with thick foamy head that lingers forever and leaves a foamy swath on the sides of the glass.  Sour nose with dark fruit - plums and some candied oranges.  Palate is a tiny bit thin, but still decent, sour, a bit more of the dark fruit and candy.  Very nice.

Pours a dark chestnut brown color thats almost completely opaque with golden ruby edges and a one finger frothy off-white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring. Small spots of lace left behind.

Slightly earthy, sweet malt aroma with lots of zesty spice and vinous dark fruit. Theres a slight medicinal character with hints of pepper and candy sugar that compliments that dark fruit notes. Hints of grape, plum and dark cherry along with some slightly roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and alcohol.

Medium bodied with a prominent spicy character up front that lingers over the earthy hops, vinous dark fruit and sweet malt into a sweet and slightly dry finish. Hints of pepper, clove and candy sugar as well as a slight syrupy medicinal character. The malt profile s sweet and slightly roasted with lots of caramel and chocolate and complimented by the dark fruit notes. Hints of plum, fig, grape, dark cherry and raisin. Well balanced and very complex. Another really good beer from this excellent brewery.
Pours a dark tan color, 1" haed that melts away to good lacing, medium to high carbonation, classic Belgian beer, very smooth, hard to nail down the flavors. A very drinkable beer!
Its a good dubbel and i can see that, but its not my favorite one. Might have been the moment though, might taste this one again sometime.
Una bella sorpresa, lavevo in cantina da tempo, forse comprata dal Besagnino, e lho assaggiata solo ieri. Biscotto e ancora biscotto, dolce ma non stucchevole

33cl bottle at the Doerak, Delft.
Dark amber pour.  Thin white head.  A decent dubbel.

(Bottle 0,33l)
Strong sweet, fruity, spicy aroma. 
Cloudy red-brown-orange color. All time light brown head. 
Medium sweet. Strong spicy taste. Creamy texture. Light fizzy. 
Medium-full body. Alcohol warm, light astringent finish.

Pours coffe/chocolate colour with medium white head. Very light on the nose and aromas can hardly be distinguished. Some fruit (plum) and maybe some dark berries and hops. Medium carbonation,medium bodu. Fruity taste with some hops and bitterness in finish. Enjoyable
(bottlede)That jovial boozy monk still makes me smile . .  Divinity in the rich seductive maltiness...silky and soothing .  The nose in these beers is sublime.

Malziger Antrunk, etwas säuerlich. Der Malzton wird im Mittelteil vollmundiger, es bleibt aber noch Platz für einen wässrig-säuerlichen Beiton, der das Bier zum Abgang merklich mit sich zieht. So wird das Malz zwar aromatischer, nimmt aber weniger Platz im Aromenspektrum ein, die Folge ist eine erkennbare Wässrigkeit. So negativ das auch klingt ist das Bier dennoch gut gelungen, es ist angenehm malzig und würzig - nur an der Vollmundigkeit hapert es etwas. 	 
Test vom 12.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 13,10,9,9,10,9 - 9,60

Bottle at home. Pours a nice dark reddish amber color. Aromas of fruit, and some other hints, maybe some spices, maybe caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and a hint of hops with a nice bittersweet finish.

The beer pours a dark amber color with a white head. The aroma is a mix of some dark fruit, Belgian candy sugar and caramel malt. The flavor is more of the same. I get some candy sugar and Belgian yeast notes, as well as a little bit of sweet dark fruit - mainly cherries and figs. The alcohol is present but is fairly faint. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice Belgian dubbel.

33cL Bottle - Pours opaque brown with a small soapy off-white head.  Sharp aroma with raisin, fruit leather, blueberry, raspberry, coco, and yeast.  Light palate with a watery feel.  Fruit forward with nice acidity.
Bottle Pours a cloudy orange/amber. Aroma of butterscotch, syrup, dark dried fruit. Flavour of dried fruit-plum, cherry, raisin, red wine, caramel and roasted coffee. Fruity and quite complex.

Bottle. Pours a murky brown with a sizeable white head. Raisin and plum fruity aroma. Flavor is dark malt, not quite as sweet as I expected ... mild, dry fruitness with yeast and a touch of wooden cask. Overall, I actually like this better than the 8.

33cl bottle. BB 03/2013. Poured cola brown with a frothy head. Aroma is malt, raisin and spices. Flavor is malt, caramel and spices, quite sweet. Not that complex, but overall very easy to drink, no alcohol detected.

330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy caramel brown with a medium frothy head.  Aroma is faint, some raisin, candy sugars and a little soapy.  Taste doesnt have much to start, some toffee, raisin ester finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a smooth head. Head has long staying power and doesnt dissipate for some time. Nose has lots of dried fruits and distinct belgian esters. Taste is very smooth. Flavor notes emphasize the belgian yeast characteristics. There is some dark sugar/candy flavors going on, but they stay in the background. nicely drinkable.

deep hazy amber, lingering tan head.  Moderately sweet and slightly spicy aroma.  Medium bodied.  The flavor combines the sweet raisin bread flavor with a moderate clean hop bitterness in the finish and a rather slight tartness.  A delicious beer, drinkable and tasty.  Id love to taste this side-by-side with the 8 and 12.
Bottle in De Paas, yeasty aroma. Fruit and malt in flavor, nice beer.

Serving: 750 ml bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a deep chestnut brown indeed.  There is a well sustained off-white head to go with.  The nose is dark fruit, spice, and yeast, but in a more restrained level compared to its high strength siblings.  The flavor is more muted than I thought it would be with light notes of biscuit, caramel, toast, yeast, stone fruit and a bit of Belgian spice.  No real sweetness or much bitterness either.  Light to medium body with abundant carbonation leading to a short to medium, malty finish.  Tasty and certainly sessionable if a bit lacking in flavor.
Nice and spicy. NOt too strong but nice head. Nice aroma and aftertaste too.

Dark chestnut color. Small head. The taste reminded me of the ABT 12, but lighter with much less taste of alcohol. Taste dried dark fruits like cherries and prunes and yeast. Subtle hop flavor. A very nice smooth drink.

Bottle; Pour is indeed a chestnut hue - perhaps a touch of amber is present here. Immediately I notice the heavy cola like carbonation in this St. Bernardus glass - perhaps its just my bottle. Slightly funky nose initially - a little soapiness from the off white head, but the fizzy bubbles disappear fairly quickly, leaving a light haze and a small rim. Its growing on me - finally. Bready malts, grassy hops with a touch of herbals, pepper, and a touch of sugars rounds it out. Not my favorite - on to the 8.

Hazy reddish brown brew with a stabile, whipped creamy off- white head, which laces and remains finger thick.
Sweet-spicy, fruity nose.
Medium sharp and slick (moderate sticky) mouthfeel with an aroma of caramel, belgian yeast, herbals and some citrus.
Flavours of berries and peppery spices.
The long, medium warming finish brings herbals and spices along, which drains the palate nicely, makeing appetite to the following síp.
A well rounded, tasty and easy drinkable belgian ale.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle @ home. Slightly hazy red/brown appearance with a foamy light tan head. Big candy sugar, dark brown malty, Belgian yeasty, banana nose. Well carbonated, Belgian yeasty, dark brown candy sugar, caramel malty flavor. Candy sugar and quite carbonated finish.

750 bottle.  Pours a deep ruby brown with a thin off white head.  The aromas are flowers, fruits, and dates.  The mouthfeel is slightly sticky and sweet with a nice carbobation and a medium body.  This was a nice beer.  Cheers!

bottle from Watou, neutrally mmalty-yeast aroma, medium bitterness, medium sweetness, good taste but same as in antother bernadus beer...little bit strange yeast backcover.lively, long finish, full body,
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: rich head, dark brown pour. mild aroma. pleasant taste. drinks lighter than it looks. well balanced. mild hopiness.

0,33 l bottle, Csakajosor, Budapest.
Deep opalescent mahagony color with a pillowy, stable tan head. No comment, perfect. Fruity aroma with plum, raisins, herbal hops and roasted grains, caramel and some molasses, dark chocolate. Thick body, complex flavor. Dark fruits like plum and raisins, honey, dark chocolate and some vanilla, nice belgian yeasts, mild herbal hop in the finish and aftertaste. Fine!

Bottle, 33cl. Pours an opaque, deep copper/maple colour with a magnificent Belgian offwhite head. Aroma contains dry fruits, sweet malts and come great yeast character. Taste is rich and yeasty, again dry fruits and sweet malts. Hides alcohol well, low bitterness.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours brown with a lacy, thick, light beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel, and hints of vanilla and light hops.  Average texture.  A pretty good dubbel, and more appealing to my tastes that most.
Pours amber brown with a nice head and leaves a lot of lacing. Nice yeasty aroma. Nice strength to the taste with hints of bread. Taste lingers long after you swallow.

The beer pours dark brown with a little ruby red highlights. The head is light tan, not a ton of retention or lacing.

The aroma is nice and malty, with raisins and caramel.

The taste is nice, very smooth and drinkable. Pretty sweet throughout.

Overall, very good.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a chalice. The bottle has a best before date of 16 04 12. The back label also lists the abv at 8%.

Appearance: It has a dark burgundy colored body with a light haze and some yeast floaters. This is capped by a light beige head of frothy light foam. From the pour it left some yeast sediment on top of the head which looks like a dusting of cinnamon. The head hangs on well, slowly fading as I drink and making some nice lacing on the glass.

Smell: There are fruity and estery yeast notes of raisins and apple peel with a slight hint of spice and funk. This is all comes with a nice sweet bready maltiness as well.

Taste/Palate: Wow, this one has good complexity with fruity and spicy yeast, sweet bready and nutty malts. I get notes of cocoa powder blending with notes of walnuts and hazel nuts like Nutella within the sweet bready maltiness. Fruity notes remind me of raisins and as it warms I get some cherry as well. Hops are light and help to balance with mild bitterness and dryness in the finish. The palate has a solid medium body with mild carbonation.

Notes: This beer has wonderful complexity and drinkability.

draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo, NY> muddy , somehat muky, yeasty brown pour. fluffy tan head. lighter malts, with touch of raisin & other dried fruitiness in the aroma. Taste was similar to aroma. Not overly complex, but easy & pleasnt drining. medium to fuller mouthfeel.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a nice reddish brown color with a bit of an off white head and some lacing. Nose brings caramel, dark fruits, apple, and brown sugar. Good amount of slightly-dry sweetness in the taste with some dates, raisins, brown sugar, caramel, bread, and hints of dark rum. Nice, creamy mouthfeel that really aids in the drinkability when combined with the taste.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-20-2010

Poured a amber brown color.  Generous head.  Big fresh malt aroma with sweeter tones, raisons.  Taste is medium sweetness.   Not much bitter to speak of (sorry hop heads).   Medium body, slick and creamy texture.  Soft carbonation.  This brewer makes great beers.  I prefer the higher alcohol ones to balance out the sugary sweetness, but still very drinkable.  Nice.

Pours medium brown with a giant, foamy, near-white head. Nose is fairly weak and standard for the style, with belgian yeast, brown sugar, and touches of hops and spiciness. Flavor is overwhelmingly malty on the front, transitioning to a deeper and slightly roasty dark-malt and yeast combo on the backside. The abbey yeast is very forward in this ale (about as much as any abbey Ive had), and the lower than normal alcohol for the style is noticable in the lack of the usual boozy and warming note dubbels normally exhibit. Nonetheless, this is still good stuff and an enjoyable drink if youre looking for less buzz power than abbeys normally pack.

Great pour, nice nut brown color, lots of head, tons of suds, yeasty topping.

Taste is nice, smooth and sweet, very complex, sort of sour as well at the end.  Get a good taste of the yeast in there as well.  Very drinkable, abv presence not found, tasty.  

HIgh quality, this brewery is awesome.  I recommend it highly, very impressed.

Finally taking the time to review this one... Usually it is a gusher and this time is no different, but I am used to it now and didnt spill. Served room temp.

It pours a thick murky looking brown, not the most amazing looking brew. The head foams up very easily and dissipates just as quick.

The smell is amazing though, just fruity, sugary, malty, yeasty goodness.

The taste is large for a dubbel. Though the 8 is still even fuller. But this one has its own nice subtleties, form the dark fruits to the immense yeastyness. There is also some nice clove character to the taste. Very good.

Its a good ass beer, what else would you expect from these guys?

Serving type: bottle

11.2oz bottle.  Served at cellar temperature.  Pours hazy red/copper/brown with a large and long-lasting off white head which holds a great cap and leaves tons of walls & spots of lacing.  Aroma is fruity with apples, pears, banana, raisins, melon, toast, a strong yeast component, some spice.  Very good strength.  Flavor follows with more fruit, pears, apples, bananas, raisins, yeasty and bready, caramel, toffee, noticeable alcohol for 6.7%.  Mouthfeel is effervescent with strong carbonation, thin to medium bodied.  A very good Dubbel with all the qualities of the best in the style.
2011 - 02 - 18 330ml bottle. medium brown colour. foams out of the bottle. almost no head. smooth roasty round taste.

Bottle - Pours rosy brown with next to no head and lovely floaties swimming around. Subtle warming alcohol on the nose, with yeasty breadiness, honey sweetness, a bit of tropical fruit, and some sweet raisins. Taste is sweet and fruity up front, with booze-soaked raisin bread and yeast prominent. Taste finishes with dark chocolate, light herbal hops, and some mineral notes. Pretty full-bodied, bubbly, and viscous. A really nice dubbel.

draft at redlight redlight.  pours a cloudy almost opaque amber with a very thick and creamy off-white head that leaves great legs.  the nose is quite enticing with a big malt and hints of autumnal fruits.  extremely smooth with a wonderful flavor of semi-sweet malts.  this is one they probably serve in valhalla.  i dont know for sure but i would guess you can order it there.
Amber pour with frothy off white head and lace. Medium brown sugar aroma. Brown sugar, sweet malt, with a hint of sour.Medium bodied with aggressive carbonation. Good beer.

330ml Bottle.  Pours a opaque red-brown color with light head.  Aroma is hay, Belgian yeast, and raisins.  Taste is fruity malts with only a mild sweetness.  Theres a heavy doughy yeast flavor along with a slight resin hops taste balancing it out.  Body is light to medium.  Carbonation is medium and soft.  Finishing is mild and long-lasting.

St. Bernardus Pater 6 is a dim, hazy, red-brown ale with lots of particles in it.  The head is a big, yellowish, off white foam that has excellent retention and lacing.  It has a fruity, leathery aroma with notes of grass, hay, phenol and raisins.  Its pretty light and lively with big bubbles.  The finish is clean, light and dry.  It foams up in my mouth and throat.  The flavor has nice balance: a little sweet and a little bitter.  It tastes like the aroma, with lots of hay and raisins.  Prunes are pretty prominent and apples and cinnamon come out after a while.  It leaves the lips a little sweet.  This is nice for a session ale.

Bernardus 6 is a wonderful dubbel.  Nice aroma.  Im currently drinking a draft "6.". Wonderfully balanced with a great nose.  I cant wait to have one fresh in Belgium in march when im attending the zythos 2011.

Hazy brown, thin head, no aroma.  Faint candy sweetness is followed by roasty aftertaste. Thinner palate balances multitude of flavors.  Still trying to get my tastebuds around this.  Candy sweetness lingers.  Curious and slightly sock like but not unpleasant somehow.

Bottle. The color of liquified raisins with a medium white head, somewhat small for the style. Understated aroma of sweet malts and prunes. Flavors are very typical of a well made dubbel with dark fruits, a hint of smoke, and maybe a bit of pumpernickel. Nothing is very strong and the high carbonation helps tie it all together. Not a memorable beer but as perfectly crafted and smooth as I can imagine.

All my god
This beer is awesome 
On tap at Mekong
Very balance, great Belgian aroma and malt
Outstanding beer

Pours cloudy, dark brown with a red cast. Extremely full head, lingering. Nose is bread, dark malts (without being overtly chocolate, coffee, or roasty), and a bit nutty. Thinner body, vigorous carbonation, mild sweetness and more subtle bittering.  Palate is nutty, has hints of dark fruits, a bit of chocolate, and some nice Belgian yeasty/clove character on the finish. Its a milder dubbel, a sessionable dubbel if you will, and its good, but not something Id reach for normally.

Browned, wood-aged amber body with a thin, but phlegmy viscous head. Piquant nose of Old Spice cologne & Brut, some clove, and deepened veins of malt split apart like fresh molten earth. Estery alcohol pinch underpins the experience along with a snap-back of belt-leather. Malty and estery body along with some clove notes with a sprucy finish that cleans and refreshes the palate.
Bella schiuma persistente, corposa al punto giusto, gradevolissima, scende sicuramente più facile della Abt. 12

Bottle. Dark brown, average and mostly lasting head. Moderate malty and sweetish aroma, light spiciness and citrus, light alcohol. Body is medium, malty and lightly flavor, sweetish sharp and dry spiciness, light alcohol. Finish is short, malty and lightly sweetish, light alcohol. Light bodied dubbel, too much alcohol considering the body.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet.

3.5 A: Murky dark brown, almost black. Slightly off-white head does not retain well and leaves moderate lacing.

3.5 S: This is similar to the 8 only not as potent. Slight raisin and plum aroma. Slight graininess. Pleasant, but weak.

3.5 T: Same as smell. Similar to the 8, but much less tasty. Plum, raisin, tobacco and lots of yeastiness.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good bubbly carbonation. Creamy.

3.5 D: Good beer, but not at this price.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2009 00:34:49
Bottle. Dark copper color - cloudy. Very malty aroma. Sweet, esthery flavor. High carbonation. Pretty good.
Malty, spicy, caramel in aroma. Nice head and color. Tastes nice, but not as much as you want. Sparkling palate. Overall nice, but nothing exceptional.

33cl bottle.  Pours a reddish-brown with a white head.  Aroma is fruit, yeast, and spicy.  Medium on the palate with big carbonation.  Taste is fruit, sweet, and a nice bit of malt.  An excellent beer, that is pretty easy to drink at 6.7%.

Pours a nearly clear ruby tinted medium brown with a 1 finger, creamy beige head that has excellent retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is sweet malt, toasted cereal grain, lots of overripe tree fruit, a touch of dark fruit, toffee, spicy and floral notes and a nice dose of yeasty white bread. Flavor is cereal, apples, grass, toffee, hints of dark fruit and fruit cake. Palate is light to medium bodied, with a surprisingly thin feel and medium carbonation. A nice dubbel with a, more ligth and refreshing than most, but not too interesting in the flavor department.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with purplish hues.  Aroma is sweet malts with notes of bread, banana, and dark fruit.  Palate is a little chewy, but perfect for the style.  Taste brings is sweet and brings out some alcohol.  Damn good.

Another winner from St Bernardus.  Bottle pours medium brown, slightly cloudy, with decent off-white head.  Aroma of fruits with slightly sour tones.  Taste dark fruits and malts, typical dubbel taste but with a bit of a bite due to the carbonation and hops.  Finish mild hops.  Medium palate, carbonated.  Alcohol disguised.

Nice dubbel, especially as it warms.
Brown body, firm small head. Medium carbonation brings up red fruit and sugar. Good sweetness here, although the aftertaste is too short and its not terribly smooth. A well balanced beer though.

Poured into a St. Bernardus trappist glass. Appearance: pours deep chestnut brown with just under a two finger tan head that is creamy and lingers leaving great lacing down the glass. Aroma: not very strong but some nice bready, yeast notes, cereal malts, and some dark fruit. A bit of flowery hops too. Taste: smooth and malty but not sweet like caramel with some toasty flavors in the finish much like a brown ale. Some raisin notes develop as the beer warms as well as some fruity alcohol esters. Hops are there to balance with some flowery notes but nothing jumps out at you. Overall: creamy and delicious with different complexities with each sip. Only downfall is the price or I would drink this all the time.

33ml pours a dark chestnut with a nice tan head that rests atop the beer from start to finish. Aroma is of bread and dough, also some dried dark fruits. Flavor is medium bodied with a very yeasty flavor. Highly carbonated with a dry finish. Pretty good but lacks complexity of other beers brewed by this brewery.

Pours a deep brown with big rocky head. Aromas of dried figs and raisins. Palate is dominated by the belgian yeast with dried fruits. Highly carbonated, sprightly. Finish is long and firm and surprisingly dry. Quite simple and one dimensional. A lack of complexity keeps it well below a "4" rating.

11.2 oz bottle.  Deep but clear chestnut brown with a craggy meringue head.  Lacy swirls.  Nose is porcini mushrooms, yeast and light molasses.  Medium body with a foamy tang.  Taste is raisin, wood and brown sugar finishing a bit vinous.  Simple, drinkable, good.
Cloudy brown pour from bottle with a thin head. Aroma is yeast and dark fruits. Taste is raisins, spice and light booze.  Smooth and very drinkable.  Cheers!!

4-dec-2010
33cl bottle at parents. Dark brown beer with average lasting beige head. Aroma is malty, ahd taste is lightly sweet with a hint of dark fruit. Nice long aftertaste, good beer!

Appearance:  cloudy medium brown; rich creamy light tan head.  Aroma:  ginger snaps, molasses, candied brown sugar.  Taste:  lightly bitter spices and yeast, with notes of sweet brown bread and brown sugar.  Finish:  dry and with a light mineral tang.  Notes:  Body is sharp and crisply carbonated.  Flavors are nice, but on the mild side.

33cl bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Dark, cloudy amber brown with thick, creamy beige head.  Aroma is brown sugar and bread.  Flavor is pretty much the same.  Full body, high carbonation.  Finish is dry and lasting.  Very drinkable beer.

A very decent, almost textbook, example of this type of beer, i.e the medium strength Trappist style dark ales (rather than dubbels generally. ) 
Looks very inviting, dark unclear brown with a large head. Aroma of dried fruit, plums, caramel and surprisingly a slight trace of alcohol. Lively fruity flavour of toasted malt, raisins, plums . Fruity finish. Medium to full body.

Bottle, 33 cl. Brown beer with a medium white head. Aroma of malts, some light caramel, dark fruits and some hops also. Taste is malty and light sweet at first, has a background taste of dark fruits, some hints of light caramel and has a nice hoppy, light bitter finish. Great beer!

Also got this bottle from the 4 pack with the St. Bernardus glass. Deep chestnut brown color with tan head that dissipates quickly. Fruit, brown sugar, and some herbal hops in aroma. Palate is medium body with fair carbonation. Flavor is slight brown sugar but overlayed by fruity and tangy, cidery flavors, with a clean aftertaste with a touch of apple. Nice, but I favor the Abt 12.

From a cool Saint Bernardus 4 pack that included a nice, wide glass designed for foamy ales like this one.  Light and fresh aroma of herbs and fruit.  Dark brown pour and a light head.  Very foamy out of the bottle, but it settles quickly.  Unexpectedly tangy and light flavor - Belgian yeast, lemon, light toast.  There is a pleasant fizz and funk on the palate.  Pater 6 is dry and tasteful, and it would be a great session brew.
darker amber beer with an offwhite head. smells malty with a corriander-like sicyness and fruits. tasts malty, ocorriander-like, of some pears aftertaste malty, corriandery, bittersweet

not my favorite dubbel. The Prior 8 is much better in my opinion.

bottle poured into its own trappist goblet. Yellow brown in appearance. Small white quickly dissapating head. weak aroma of dough and malt. I got a strong taste of olives at first but that taste began to fade as the beer warmed up and aired out. on the flatter side with a full body and a drier finish.

Inte mycket att säga om denna.
Inga halleljuabetyg från mig. Smakade rent av lite gammalt.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a beige head aroma malts spics some fruits and hops taste malts spices fruits some caramel and hops
Draft @ Restaurant t Klooster. sweetness in the aroma. Quickly becomes quite flat, giving a somewhat dry mouth feel. Although a nice brew together with my dinner.

Tap. Rich brown pour with a foamy clingy tan head. Mild spice nose. Kind of a thin flat mouthfeel - not much zing here. Taste is mild dark fruit, bread, and a little spice. Pretty solid, but not spectacular.

Drank from an 11.2oz bottle.Appearance: Typical Belgium dubbel - brown with thick, foamy, white head (regenerates easily). No lacing though :(Aroma: Very mild. Reminds me a very weak pumpkin beer with hints of spices and a touch of alcohol.Taste: Much like the nose, starts out like a pumpkin beer with notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, coriander (no pumpkin, though). A fairly rich, bittersweet dark chocolate sweetness across the middle. Flavor "paters" out as I drink it. It becomes more mild, homogenized and dare I say, watery. Still, its tasty and satisfying.Mouthfeel: Noticeably thin and tepid. I dont like an intense mouthfeel, but this could use some more energy.Drinkability: Due to the mild flavor and thin mouthfeel this is quite a chuggable brew. At only 6.7% ABV this is practically a "lite" beer for Belgium!Overall: Very similar to the Prior 8, but without the dense body. I liked it, but I didnt love it.

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAd-D4mMbyA

Dark, but not black. Very small, cream colored head. Laces as you drink.  Creamy, malty caramel overtones in the taste with some dark fruits at the finish, which is a little dry.  Medium bodied and creamy. Carbonation is present, but not overwhelming.  All in all the abt 12 is still much better than either the Prior 8 or the Pater 6. However, I much prefer the 6 to the 8. Great brewery nonetheless. A go to when available.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a slightly murky deep amber brown with a creamy long lasting light tan head. Aroma is very bready, lots of dark fruits, plum and a very nice sweet burnt sugar candy note. A touch of tartness sharpens the fruit character. Flavor starts very sweet and fruity, nice sweet character before a slight tartness that really nicely balances what would otherwise be a very sweet and doughy beer. Caramel sweetness with a touch of raisin in the finish.  Medium creamy rich body and a sharp carbonation. A very nice dubbel, very enjoyable.

The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass as well. Dark brown, nice head. Starts fine malty, not too dry, a little bit spicy with notes of cinnamon. Modest fruity like plum. Finish well balanced, modest sourish, still fine malty. Nice!

Poured a cloudy brown color with an off-white head and minimal lacing.  The aroma was malt, dark fruits and a whiff of booze.  The flavor was mostly dark fruits soaked in booze.  More unchecked alcohol than I expected.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown with a small beige head. Very sweet aroma with dark fruits, brown sugar and caramel. The first sips had a metallic finish. After the third sip this vanished. Starts sweet with caramel and dark fruits all over. Those sweet notes remind me of a good Dunkler Bock. Great aftertaste with some chocolate and caramel notes. Very nice brew. Gets better when it warms up a little.

Brown-copper body and reasonably solid head. Aroma is barley, wood, leather, pumpernickel. The taste is a nice mix of soft barley, grass, and chocolate. Very mellow and unintruding, would be great for a session beer.

Bottle from Beer World, Brussels. Pours a murky nougat brown body with some sediments and a mid-sized near-white head. Nose is molasses, hints of yeast and lots of nutty, nougat-like tones; distinctly reminiscent of a traditional nut-based bread spread for kids that used to be popular in Norway when I grew up in the 70s and 80s: "Hapå"! So amusing to find that same flavor in a top-class dubbel from Belgium, about 25 years after when I used to eat Hapå... :-) Tastewise, this beer has notes of caramel, bread, dry hops and molasses. Very smooth composition. St. Bernandus Pater 6 is the core of the abbey series and can, in my opinion, be considered the "mother" of these brews when it comes to the flavor profile, as it is more distinctly pronounced here than in any of the others.

Bouteille de 33cl. Marron foncé, presque opaque, mousse assez fine et résiduelle. Arômes de miel et de chocolat, bien équilibrée, bonne longueur en bouche et très agréable au palais. Une abbaye savoureuse. Trouvée à Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.
Milk chocolate brown color with small tan head. Aroma is rich and fruity with strong malt notes. Flavor has delicious caramel malts, light roastiness and some sharp fruity notes.

Dark brown beer with medium and beige head. Aroma is great, raisins, dark dryed fruits and sweetness. Flavour is not at the same level than aroma, dark fruits, quite simple and quite dry aftertaste.
