First lot of carbonation that later nice to drink. Aroma is pleasant, flavour is simple; easy and uncomplicated dubbel.
Bottle. Pours with a large, but quickly diminishing, off white head over a clear red-brown body. Aroma taste of spices (coriander), caramel, sweet bodied, with a balanced finish. Nice.

330 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu. Rated @ 22.5.2010.
Hazy brown colour with a small beige head. The aroma is nicely fruity with dried fruits, caramel and even chocolate. Medium sweet aroma with caramel, fruits, raisin and malts. Light bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel and decent carbonation. Light version of the other St. Bernard brews.

33 cl bottle. Pours brown with a off white head, quickly disappearing . Aroma is bready, roasted and caramel sweet. Mouthfeel is medium and a bit thin for me, but the bitter ending is pleasant for sure. Not bad at all, but I still prefer the 8 or the 12.

Completely to standards for the style, this beer pours a nice brown color with a foamy and lingering head.  Nice looking, good on the palate, but rather dull.  The nose catches a slight quantity of yeasty spices that are present in the palate but accompanied by a mildly unpleasant sweetness.  Its not bad but not something Ill ever purchase again.  Just not the kind of beer I like to drink.

330 ml. bottle.   Pours a dark amber with lots of carbonation. Biege head that leaves fairly quickly.  Aroma of fruit, malt and molasses.  Tastes of sweet malt and raisins.  Very smooth and warming.  Excellent.

Bottle, as part of a variety 6-pack. Pours a hazy dark copper amber with a finely bubbled, exuberant golden head. Low aroma of yeasty caramel and some dark fruits. Flavours of yeasty dark caramel, raisins, and subtle spices. Mouthfeel is overly carbonated and thin. Enjoyable, but my higher expectations were not met.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Finally! 0.33 L bottle brought home from de Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Big, fine-bubbled lightly tanned head. Body is clear, beautifully chestnut colored. Inviting yeast aroma, bubble-gummy and fresh fruity.  Marzipan-scented malts,  a note of bakery, and a tangerine-like frutiness. Strong malt body. Gently sweet, both fruity and malty. A rounded biscuity toastedness, mild spices, raisins, nuts and cream caramel. Soft and rounded in the mouth. Full, still easy drinkable. A really good Dubbel, a benchmark.

Heavily carbonated copper with a rich head of tiny stacked bubbles. Aroma of dark malt, dark spice and yeast. Kind of like a burnt Belgian nut brown ale in flavour than a heavy dubbel. Tasty roasted malt, nuts and spice.

Pours out pretty dark brown. Good sized big white head that holds pretty nice. Sour-sweet smell of caramel and red fruits. Sweet fruity and some caramel taste. Easy to drink, maybe misses some body. Not bad, just need a extra punch i think.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark, translucent amber with about 2 fingers of frothy, tan head. The head dissipates quickly, but leaves some frothy lacing that slides off the glass. The aroma is apricot, raisins and some doughy yeast. The flavors is mostly fruity sweetness and a tart crispness with a slightly bitter finish that lingers. It has a medium body, with lots of carbonation. A good beer, but not worth what it costs.
Brown with nice head. Aroma malty with chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, yeast. Taste the same and some bitter coffee. Full body, text smooth, carb average, finish sweetbitter.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a thick off white head, over clear, amber (SRM 7) body.....nose is sweet malt with caramel/toffee, cereal, very light musty cellar....taste is light sweet to start, then light raisin, bit of fig, slight plum finishing with a mild bitter sweet, and slight mustiness....mouth feel is medium, carbonation high. This is a fairly typical Dubble. It is not as rich and complex as the best, but is thoroughly drinkable. BJCP 7/3/13/4/6
Pours an orange copper colour with a large off white head. The aroma is sweet and fruity. The flavour has banana, clove, caramel, apple, and a slight metallic finish. Not bad.
Nice reddish brown colour with a thin white head. Aroma is very fruity with a slight yeast note. banana and such. Flavour is nice. some bread flavour and spices, not bad, but pretty thin.

St. Bernardus
Pater 6
Pours brown with a reddish orange tinge and a medium off white head. Excellent retention. Aroma of stone fruits, Belgian yeast and thick malt. Some banana on the nose as well. Flavor does not stack up to the aroma. Understated with a slight metallic flavor. The malt holds court here, with some of the yeast to show it is a Belgian, but it isnt caramelly enough and it isnt boozy enough. Lots of bubbles almost to the point of creaminess. Only OK.
Draft at redlight.  Pours dark amber.  Fruity aroma of cherries, apples and dates.  Flavor is lightly roasted with dark fruits.  Drinks well for lower alcohol.  Great!

draft @ redlight redlight.  Nutty aroma with caramelized sugars and hints of fruit.  Pours dark copper amber color with a thick off white head.  Nutty with toasted malts and caramelized sugar with hints of dark fruits figs and dates.  The beer finishes fairly dry.  Nice!
Brown body, light brown head. Veery fruity, orange, chocolate, light yeast aroma. Has much complexicity in flavour - raisin, toast, chocolate, cola and yeast. Sour & balanced mouthfeel.
33 cl bottle. Murky brown with big foamy tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, roasted malt, fruit and yeast.

Smells like bubblegum, flowers and alcohol. Hints of cinnamon. Quite a bit of grainy malt. Not sure if I like this aroma or not... Theres a bit of funky, cobweb-ish notes. 
Flavours are a bit watery, but still with a solid malt flavour. A nice smooth Belgian yeast character, with mingling leather and mustiness. Flavours of bubblegum and banana, with tiny hints of chocolate and spice.
Not too bad, but not that great :( Perhaps because my bottle was a gusher and the lees was mixed in.

Appearance- This beer poured a nice dark brown with huge frothy tan head. Lacing was present throughout the life of the beer. .

Smell- Huge fruit smells such as apples, citrus and dark fruits. A nice sweet biscuity smell with a slight hint of alcohol.

Taste- The wonderful fruit tastes really come through here. Mostly dark fruits but as in the smell I got apples and citrus also. There is an interesting brown sugar taste which is present as well.

Mouthfeel- This beer has a nice medium body with medium carbonation. Its an easy drinking beer.

Overall- Fantastic. Surprisingly my second favorite behind the Abt 12. I really enjoyed this beer a lot.

Mmm dont know if this a good bottle as it was bought from a bottle shop that stores their beer next to a window! Still lots of prune, fig and spice on the nose and in the mouth, though a slightly off putting taste (storage?) that keeps me from rating this higher. Still very nice though but will have to re rate.

Originally rated April 2006. Best before date is written 09 05 08 on back label. Pours a dark red-brown that cannot be seen through. The creamy foam head is tanned, large, leaves good fat chunky lacing and has very good retention. The aromas are quite nice, with some good nut and purfum Belgian yeast. Raisins and some other dark fruits are noted in the background. Semi-watery mouthfeel with a tannin finish. The taste starts off with some caramel mixed with grapes and malts. Nuts appear in the aftertaste. One of the lighter St. Bernardus brews, with easy drinkability, but still a good brew from a great brewer.

Bottle 33cl. A cloudy amber brown ale with brownish head. Smell is on yeast and burnt notes. Aroma is on bread, cereal and toasted malt, body is medium. Notes of fruit, agrumes and nuts, hazelnuts. Finish is quick, easy drinking beer.

330ml bottle. Dark brown to copper red in colour with a flat even light tan head. Aroma of musty fruit and dust. Strong warming flavour of prunes, raisins and dried fruit. Smooth in the mouth and envelopes the whole mouth. Solid and enjoyable effort.

Poured a hazy brown with a foamy white head.  Strong aroma of dark fruit, raisins, yeast.  Taste is slightly fruity with some bready malts.  Also plums and toffee.  Finish is a little bitter.  Maybe too much carbonation?  Overall very good.

330 ml bottle. From Poperinge, Belgium. Courtesy of Brandman.
Dark reddish brown colour with small to average tan head.
Dark fruits, dark malt, orange, plums and chocolate in aroma.
Flavour is dark malt, dark fruits, hops, chocolate, plums, raisins and toast.
Quite easy yet balanced and refreshing Abbey Ale.

33cl bottle. Chestnut with a thick, fast-fading, off-white head; aroma of caramel and spicy Belgian yeast; rich buttery texture with some sour fruit and lots of toffee flavours; semi-sweet rounded finished. Very drinkable.

750 ml bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a hazy plum amber with some visible yeast sediment at the bottom of the glass and a huge, active off-white head that settles into a small, foamy cap.  Aroma of bready malts, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, berries, overripe pit fruit, pepper, raisins, nuts, and spices.  Flavor of bready malts, Belgian yeast, pepper, overripe pit fruits, spices, pepper, earth, leaves, grains, and biscuit.  Starts malty and spicy and finishes very dry.  Dry, spiced aftertaste.  Medium-bodied, with a bready, foamy mouthfeel and a lot of carbonation.

Aroma is weak with hints of vanilla and dark fruit.  Appearance is as the description says a chesnut brown with tight lacing and a persistant head.  Flavor is dominated by vanilla, caramel, and dark fruit.  Mouthfeel is rich and creamy.  Nice brew.

330 mL bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot in Chicago, expiry 05/11/12, served in a Trappist glass. Pours cloudy chestnut with a tall, rocky off-white head. Head quickly recedes to 5 mm but remains and leaves a small amount of lace. On the nose, dominant aromas are of yeast, fruit, flowers and nuts, along with molasses and earth. The flavour is a lttle sweet up front but this is quickly replaced with a moderate bitterness towards the end. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, medium in body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. The finish is quite astringent. Overall, this is a reasonable dubbel, but nothing compared to the Prior 8. For a dubbel, it is very light in body. It is a bit too dry and astringent for my taste in dubbels. 2010-05-19
bottle. cloudy, amber, red, brown in color.  tan foam.  bread, earthy aroma.  medium sweetness, medium body, soft carbonation.  Tasty beer, but nothing really stands out about it.

Bottle.

A - Rusted, crimson brown that is just a little cloudy somewhat tea color. Large rocky and foamy white head with decent retention that settles into a thick, creamy layer of lacing.

S - Very well spiced with some dark fruit (especially raisin) but it isnt heavy on the dark fruit, especially for a Dubbel. Healthy dose of candi sugar and molasses along with a touch of yeast aroma. Some nutty and sweet malt aroma. Pretty typical Dubbel aroma but a little less dark fruit and a little sweeter.

T - Similar to the nose with some light dark fruit flavors (raisin and a bit of fig) along with some golden fruit, specifically apple. Some sweet malt and candi sugar provide some sweetness in the background. Light nutty and cocoa presence in the background. Well spiced with a lot of clove and coriander with just a slight peppery and ginger taste.

M - On the lighter side of medium body with average carbonation. Smooth and creamy.

D - Very drinkable. Lighter Dubbel but still quite complex. Very smooth and easy to drink beer that is able to mix the stronger, complex flavors of a Dubbel, but still be light easy to drink.

Notes: Best before 24/09/12. Good lighter bodied and subtler Dubbel, but still full on flavor and complex. Not as dark or as much dark fruit as other stronger versions of the style, but they are still present and provide a lot of flavor. This is probably just as good as the Prior 8, just a bit different. Another great beer from a great brewery. Definitely worth a try.
Bottle exploded on me. More ended up on the floor than my glass. Whats left poured a soda like brown. Nose is nuts and lightly toasted malts. taste is toasted malts, nuts and caramel.

On tap at the Maple Tree Inn in Blue Island, IL:  Deep dark murky pour and very little head (but, being married, Ive gotten used to that)  Nose is sweet and dark fruits, and yeasty esters.  Taste is sweet malty dark fruit (like raisins and dates) and fruity yeasty notes with a   strange dusty astringency in the mid-palate, and finishing again on the sweet malty notes.  Very nicely done.

Murky dark brown appearance. Summer rain and apple orchard with a cane sugar and caramel backbone. Ultra clean on the tongue. Medium bodied. Fruit, caramel and mildly astringent. Alcohol is barely detectable throughout. Slightly different character than its older brother, the Prior. Slightly less full-bodied and slightly less sweet, it is however undeniably a family member. Might even be better balanced for some. Cant wait to try em side-by-side. What a brewery!

Dark amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of malt, some yeast, & subtle dark fruit; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, caramel, light dark fruit, some bananas, and nuts; Nicely balanced; Overall, not in the same class as their 8 - but a decent dubbel.

Bottle. Poured a murky brown color with a two finger pillowy white head. Aroma was molasses, figs, dates, and plum. Flavor was a little weaker. Fruits, sugar and candies. There were floaters in the beer. The 12 and 8 are better this one was still better than average though.

Bottle at Bryghuset No5.
Brown with a beige head, some lacings. Aroma moderate to heavy malty (brown sugar, dark fruits), moderate hoppy.Flavor moderate sweet, llight bitter. Medium body.

(11.2 oz bottle).  Pours a reddish-brown liquid with white head-beautiful. Aroma of dried fruit.  Not sweet at all and only a slight bitter finish.  Subtle sourness.  A little disappointing considering the brewer.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2016 [4/10] Cloudy brown, head settles to a nice coat. Aroma is light and fruity - yeast, 
cherries, citrus and spices. Pretty carbonated mouthfeel. Quite sweet with 
light yeastiness and a drying bitter herbal kick at the finish. Sophisticated but frivolous. Terrific. [3.7][9/13] Just a bump to the score - just a casual delight thats deftly more than the sum of its parts. [3.8]  [10/16] A bit fresher I guess. Bitterness is quite firm. A slight metallic touch. "Sophisticated but frivolous" is right.

Bottle. Hazy dark amber colored, light brown head. Aroma: sweet malty and caramel.   Taste: Citrus with brown sugar touch with bitter, dry finish. Drinkable, but old monk has much better beers than this.

Sweet yet soapy aroma leads to a very nice dark reddish amber.  Sweet fruity taste with a touch of sourness.  Medium body with fizzy carbonation make this creamy beer finish nice on the tongue.  Overall a very good beer that is sure to please a wide range of tastes.
UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 330mL bottle, pours a brownish dark amber with a medium head. Aroma of caramel malts, various spices and figs. Flavour is about the same. One of the better dubbels.
Pours a nice dark reddish amber color. Aromas of fruit, and some other hints, maybe some spices, maybe caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and a hint of hops with a nice bittersweet finish.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Huge banana clove some dark fruits and malts. Nice Belgian from these monks.

From California to Belgium to Switzerland to Russia and beyond, real beer knows no boundaries. At the same time, beer styles also know no boundaries, but thats a quandary for another day and a subject of great debate. Today I am looking at the Pater 6 from St. Bernardus out of, where else, Belgium. Ah, St. Bernardus, how I love thee, let me count the ways


The lightest of St. Bernardus dark beers, the Pater 6 was a subtle hue of brown, mahogany, and amber polished to perfect brilliance. A fluffy cappuccino head slinks her way down into a fine collar while lace decorates her countenance. Life is sweet and so too is her nose, exuding a perfume of the finest dark fruits possible: plums, raisins, prunes, dates, and licorice root. Darkly sweet right from the start, she fades into crisp red apples, and pears, finishing with cinnamon sticks and toffee crunchies. A nip of lemon in the very end ensures my attentions while toast and wood offer a constant underpinning of support. Excellent. Diving right in, I savor her lightly effervescent and slightly sticky mouthfeel. Red apples, pears, plums, and prunes garner my favor first before maple, caramel, and brown sugars take me for a ride on the sweet train. These are the best kinds of sweet possible; dark, rich, moist and tantalizingly seductive. Children need not apply. Lemon zest cleanses and revitalizes after each quaff, calling me back for more. Crunchy toast takes her place in silent approval, allowing her compatriots to hog the spotlight of my affections. Thats ok though; I appreciate her self-sacrifice and loyalty. Cinnamon sticks, nutmeg, and paprika add spice and verve to each quaff while lingering long in my breath. Not overly complex and yet more than satisfying, she is crisp, crunchy, sweet, dry, and refreshing.


Very few Belgian breweries can claim to have previously brewed for the mystical Westvleteran monks, but St. Bernardus can. When Westvleteran chose to start brewing their beers themselves, that may very well have been the best tragedy that could have befallen the brewery. From that moment on, St. Bernardus brewed abbey style ales in their own tradition, and every time I sup one of their liquid treasures, I am reminded of how I am better for it.
Bottle.  Pours murky brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast and dark fruits.  Taste of raisins and hint of spices.  Tons of carbonation.  Easy drinking.  Good beer.
Sweet, floral fruity aroma.  Nice red-orange amber with a solid fluffy tan head.  Lighter on palate but a nice roasty flavor  and earthy tones.  Subtle sweetness.  Excellent.

Rather muddy brown with a tall, rocky, head. Fresh aroma of chocolate and raisins. Rich malt flavor: chocolate, a bit of nuts, dried fruit, cookies. Well-balanced, very flavorful and rich for its size. Sweet but chewy, rich. Drinkable and tasty. Love it.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Deep brown with amber glow, medium soapy, tanned head.
Aroma is full of fruits, caramel
Flavour is thinner than expected, but there are nice bitter hops and some sweet fruit and caramel. Very nice beer.

bottle bb 12/13/2010 consumed 12/05/2009.

gushing bottle pours auburn brown... slurry, really. there is so much yeast in suspension that this thing is thick. the wispy almond tinted head is peppered with flecks of yeast. 

malty aroma... brown sugar/candi, over ripe fruit, cinnamon, peppery spice, yeast and old raisins. 

the flavor is much the same... not terribly complex. it is good just not deep... lots of malt, brown sugar, cinnamon, yeast and a (good) dirtiness similar similar to freshly pulled beets with a pronounced grainy bitterness on the finish. 

it is medium bodied. prickly sudsy carbonation keeps it crisp and clean. 7/3/6/3/14/3.3

bottle part of a christmas gift pack with glass poured a murky cheesnut brown with athick off white to tan head aromas are of yeast,bread dough and fruits and the flavors are of the same with some  honey sweetness a very livly beer that retains its superior lacing thourgh out the session god bless the monks amen

750ml bottle.  Poured a cloudy deep brown in color with a thick and creamy head and ample lacing.  A deep aroma of malt, dark fruit and spices.  The taste was bready with a yeasty maltiness up front. Some candy sugar, caramel, and light cocoa flavors through the middle.  Followed by a subdued spicy flavor that emerged in the finish along with a touch of alcohol.  Finishes very dry. Mouthfeel a little thin.
Dark golden hazy with a small white head... Aroma of yeast and bread.. Flavor follows suit with fruity notes... very carbonated with a dry finish... medium bodied

Bottle. Poured a cloudy rootbeer color with a thin off white head. Nose was yeasty with some dark fruits. Thin mouthful with a fairly light flavor. This is an easy drinker for the abv which goes completely unnoticed. Lots of carbonation.Overall flavor is light yet complex.  Finish is very dry.

Pours a remarkably cloudy brown with a big head that leaves some good lace. The aroma has some pear, brown sugar, cherry, and floral notes. The flavor is nicely sweet without being cloying, lightly spicy and nutty with some cherry notes. The palate is full and well rounded. 
A unique lower alcohol offering for the style, quite tasty!

super fluffy cloudy head, reddish amber color. Aroma is of apricots and alcohol. Flavor is a very smooth and sweet malty fruity deliscciousness. Bready and yeasty. Great stuff. bottle at Sunset Corners, Miami.

bottle thanks to fratto.  murky brown pour with a cream head.  nose is alcohol, malts, yeast and dried fruits.  nice on the palate with a flavor that pretty much matches the nose to a t, maybe a little more yeast but thats about it.
Bottle from the Whole Foods on Lamar.  Murky brown pour with a big tan head.  Aroma is sweet, yeasty, and fruity.  Taste is apple, raisin, malts, lots of yeast and spices.

From a 330ml bottle poured into a Trappist glass at 45°.  Color is a muddy amber with good carbonation and a very thin tight tan head.  Aroma of bread, caramel and apple.  Coming in with a lighter medium body it goes down smooth with a soft fizzy feel.  Finish is mildly sweet with a dried pear and raisin then a hint of vanilla and honey backed by a spicy white pepper taste.  After taste is dry with a light bitterness.  This is a very good brew with great Belgian flavors.
Bottle courtesy of Fratto. Murky brownish red pour. Nice head. Lightly generated scent. Flaky butter. Sharp flavors of dark fruit and light popcorn. Interesting but hot.

Dark orange / light brown beer with a very foamy head that went away quickly.  Aroma of fruits such as apricot. with fruity and yeasty flavors.  This is one of those times where a beer surprised me and is really good.

( 750ml bottle thanks to fratto) Pours murky orange brown with nice creamy head. Nose of Belgian yeast,, fruits (apple and golden raisins). Taste of metal, watery, dark fruits and golden raisins, cream, rum, and a nice creamy well carbonated finish.

Pours a light brown color with a medium to thick head.  Smells roasty with a hint of a  fruit bouquet.  Creamy, roasty caramel taste with a slight bitter taste.  Slight carbonation level.  Malty aftertaste.  Decent brew.

Pours a two finger off-white head that fades slowly to a thin layer, leaving some lace. Hazy brown color.  Not much to the nose. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is hard to nail down like a brown with hints of dark fruit, dry finish.  $17.00 for a gift pak of four 330ml bottles from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Pours a cloudy tea brown with a slight amber hue. Slight amount of flocculation. Smells of prunes, raisins and candied pecans. The mouthfeel is a bit thin. The flavor is well balanced and not overly sweet.

Poured from 33cl bottle.  Brownish gold, kinda murky, with a cream colored head.  Nose was yeasty, doughy, a little banana, vanilla, and dried fruits. Taste was on the sweet side, fruity.  Medium bodied with a mild oily finish.  It is the least favorite of their Christmas gift pack.

Not too much aroma here. Opaque brownness is slightly cloudy with some sedimentlike ingredients when held up to the light. The palate is less complex than other St. Bernardus beers Ive had, but still as subtle. Nuts and malt are the main flavours here. Almost too subtle of a beer - not enough oomph for me to become a regular favourite.
Big dense creamy head, brown coloured, lots of carbonation. taste is herbal, malty, hints of cacao, hoppy and bitter, maybe a bit of cinnamon in it?Nice.

33cl bottle shared with larryLSB.   Ugly murky brown color, but a nice creamy, medium-sized light beige head with decent lace.   Instantly smells like St. Bernardus yeast, with that doughy, dried date, fig, and raisin quality.   Almost comes of as cinnamon raison oatmeal with more dried fruit thrown in actually.   The flavor is medium-sweet with no detectable hops and just a touch of bitterness.   Lots of overripe and dried fruit, maybe a little squishy banana.   Creamy mouth-feel, and about medium consistency.   Finishes with some tendency toward dryness, but a slight sweetness caries through.   Just a little to one-note sweet dried fruit for me.   Serviceable, but feels a little uninspired.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2010 Draft at World of Beer.  Pours a dark mahogany brown color with a beige head.  Belgian yeast, roasted malts and dark fruits in the aroma and flavor.  Slightly dry mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours a murky light brown with dirty white head. Aroma has alot of fruity esters, resembling light green apple and mild citrus, faint brown sugar, malt, a little barnyard, toast. Flavor of light fruits, faint dark fruit, toast, musty, some toasted grain, light malt. Mouth feel is light-medium body with high, fizzy soft carbonation. Overall, very tasty!

Poured into a snifter a murky golden brown color with a thick white head.  Aroma of fruity esters, some malts, and belgian mustiness.  Taste is fruity, fig, less dates, and a nice hop kick on the end.  Sharp and full bodied taste.  Just great

11.2oz bottle (2009) into a Chimay glass.  Pours cloudy brown with yellow around the edges and a 1.5-finger fluffy off-white head on top that fades relatively quickly into a ring and a fluff in the middle, mild lacing.  The aroma is musky Belgian yeast, brown malts, and fruity esters, especially sweet raspberries and currants.  The flavor is very mild, clean, and smooth - I feel like I could drink this all night.  Hints of fruit with Belgian yeast, a nice subtle malt profile, and more.  Good stuff!

Bottled. Deep caramel brown with very thin but lasting off-white head. Big brown sugar and molasses taste, light hazelnut and espresso taste. Yeasty throughout. mildly spiced. sweet with a dry finish leaving a toasty feel on tongue. Lighter sticky palate. A little oily looking and similar feel on tongue.

ANOTHER great beer from St. Bernadus!!

hazy brown in color - fruity/malty aroma - really enjoyed the taste on this - a little toned down from the other beers; very smooth; no alcohol taste and carbonation/spiciness on the backend..

12oz bottle.  Deep dark brown pour with thin off-white head and soapy lacing.  Dark fruits, roasted malts and yeast in the aroma.  Tastes of caramel, bread and raisins.  Dry earthy finish with a lot of spices mixed in.

11 1/5 ounce bottle. Pours a soupy brown with a small yellowish head. Aroma is generally malty with Belgian yeast; the same aroma as the Abt but smaller. Flavor has a good malty body, with light molasses/maple/brown sugar elements. Good carbonation, thicker viscosity. Basically a smaller sibling to the Prior and Abt, but easy to identify as being in the same lineage - there is no doubt that this is in the Bernie family in other words. Quite enjoyable, despite its reservedness relative to its bigger siblings. Overall, very good.

330mL Bottle. Rated blind. Third out of a set of 12 Abbey Dubbels. Apple-forward yeast and a 

bit of pils malt sugar. Quiet. Pours a brilliant, hazy blood-orange red, 

with a lacy, sheeting off-white head. Flavor is odd. Oxidized pilsner 

malt, sulfur, more minerals, and aged green apple skins. Very slightly 

solvent-like, which is unappealing. Kind of thin and alcohol forward. I 

wish I was digging this, because its ultra-dry, yeast-complex, fruity, 

peppery, and well carbonated, but somehow Im yearning for darker malts, 

more complimenting yeast and less conflicting minerals. GUESS: Westmalle or Ommegang

330 poured into St. Bernardus trappist glass. Finger head, brown-red almost coffe appearance. Smell is very delicate and subtle of zesty spices and citrus.  Taste is slightly bitter, with a bit of hops and sweetness. Once again very delicate. High carbonation, dances on the tongue.

Pours murky amber, medium cream head.  Aroma of apple and sweet malt or caramel.  Taste is direct with initial apple and caramel flavor followed by diminished lingering taste of the same.  Somewhat sour aftertaste. Neutral texture. Overall, good.

medium brown with mild/moderate white head.  not the most aromatic brew, but some notes of esters.  moderate to high carbonation for the style.  some bitterness right off the bat, more than usual for a belgian.  some candi sugar sweetness with some esters coming through then the alcohol, which adds some complexity, but also a little heat, before a bone dry finish.  solid dubbel

330 mL bottle.  Pours brown red with an off-white head.  Aroma is apple and molasses, caramel, touches of dark fruit and mustiness.  Flavor is of molasses with some green apple and a slight mustiness.  A little thinner than Id like.

Tasted side by side with the Prior 8.

Pours dark brown with a surprisingly small bubbly head, much smaller than the massive thick head on the 8.  It recedes to a small cap with little lacing.

The aroma is sweet with candi sugar and Balgian yeast.  Plenty of fruity esters but with an interesting nutty character and some chocolate malts as well.

The taste has the sweet malts and dark fruits up front with a lightly toasted bready malt backbone.  Overall, its a sweet, malty taste with less spices than the 8.

The mouthfeel is fairly light with lots of carbonation.

This is a very good beer, though Id put it a notch below the Prior 8 as its not as complex and is a bit thinner in the body.  But, thats some pretty stiff competition and this is still better than most dubbels out there.

Nice fruity aroma with that distinctive Belgium doughy, yeast smell.  Fruit is almost a raspberry smell.  Cloudy dark brown/amber in appearance with a nicely balanced two finger tan head.  Medium body.  Slick mouthfeel, very lively.  Finish is long with only a slight hint of bitterness.  Flavor is of dark fruits and hops.  Very nice beer.  Recommended.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 750 ml. bottle.  Pours an auburn brown with tan head.  Aroma of yeast, nuts, earth, spices, light fruit tones, prune.  Tastes like classic belgian brown ale, with a nice spiciness, and sour prune on the finish.  I had to come back and update this up, and up the rating.  At first I had drank it in the wake of the 12 and rochefot 8, went on a belgian spree, and this one didnt stand up to all of them.  But coming back to it, it really is a phenomenal beer.  Cheers.
UPDATED: MAY 23, 2013 Clear pale brown with thin but well lasting head. Aroma is quite yeasty and a little fruity too. Taste is a little sweet with light dried fruit flavours and some yeasty notes.

een donker bruin biertje met een witte kraag. lichtjes een zoete smaak maar voor de rest een beetje flets ook de afdrong is te iets te plat kan zijn dat het bij het redelijk lage alc. gehalte te maken heeft.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2011 Served at 48-49F. Malty, fruity aroma, not bad, but not great either.  Beer looks great, pours a nice color just lighter than Guinness.  Mouthfeel has moderate carbonation.. average, but with some nice creaminess.  Flavor is good, creamy, citrusy, malts and hops.

Bottle. It smells fruity, very malty and light sour. The very small light brown head disappears fast, the body is clear and red-brown. The taste is light fruity, malty, but not really strong. The finish is long and mild, light bitter. It is lively-creamy, the body is light to medium strong and with a lot of carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours a light brune body with a huge yellow head.  Yeasty beer, with banana, raisin, toffee tones.  Chewy and nutty with caramel bread y notes and 
a mild warming.  Another great offering from the monks.
Dark brown colored with a thick rocky head. Aroma is slightly salty and quite sour. Rich, full taste of wood, spices and some citrus fruits. Good carbonation.

A: Poured with a large, off-white head.... slowly diminished down to about 1/2-finger. Fair lacing through drinking. Body is a muddy brown and very cloudy, with no particles noticeable.

S: Light yeast, cloves, and fruity sweetness (bananas?).

T: Very nice flavor... the yeast and breadiness is noticeable first, then the fruity sweetness of bananas comes through. Finishes with a very light bitterness, barely noticeable at all. Average duration for the flavor.

M: Body is light-to-medium bodied with a very creamy texture. Lots of fizzy carbonation that almost burns the tongue.

D: Extremely drinkable, a very consistent dubbel that I really enjoyed. The carbonation was almost offensive, but didnt quite get there. Otherwise, very good.

A Mes rate. Tap at Paradise Fest.I was amazed to find Id not rated this one. I drink it in Quinns while watching the Mighty Reds regularly. Thank god for an iPhone in the middle of Grand Place madness. Hazy amber with an impressive white head. Excellent balance of herbal hoppage and sweet caramel yeast. Good citric notes up front and some excellent spice. Typical Bernie character. Superbly made. Great stuff and effortlessly drinkable. I was chatting to some new and very random friends. I nearly nailed this before I had even started rating!

330ml bottle, as pictured.

Bottle-conditioned dubbel pours a hazy copper with a huge, fluffy off-white head. Good retention, decent lacing.

Aroma is of yeast, malt and citrusy hops, with some alcohol peeping through. Medium carbonation, smooth but tickling mouth feel.

Taste is grapefruit, roasted malt and a wee bit of aniseed. Not too sweet, with a nicely bitter-and-sour hoppy finish. Slightly alcoholic after taste, but not too obtrusively (particularly compared to some other abbey dubbels and tripels).

For an abbey dubbel, this brew appears to be rather refreshing and sessionable - not too dangerously so, at 6.2 % abv. Quite delicious, and not too heavy. Will drink again.

bottle - poured a torbid toffee color, creamy head. Aroma prunes, raisins, dates and spice, hint of alcohol. The flavor is more of the same with the spiciness increasing as the beer warms, the finish was just a bit more bitter than I would have expected.
Good dubbel.

Pours a deep dark hazy brown with a large light brown head. Aroma is candi sugars, yeasts, fruits, rasins, spices. Flavor is yeasts, rasins, fruit, a little roastiness, candi sugar, spices, caramel. Not overly sweet, and very carbonated. Decent Dubbel.

I dont drink a lot of Dubbels, so Im compairing this to the American Ales that I am more familiar with.  Nice carbonation, and good aroma.  The flavor is a little sweet for my taste, but i drank this right from the store.  I imagine it would balance out with age.

Bottle. Pours a lightish copper with a lasting beige head and lots of chunky sediment. Aroma is malty and a little boozy, with notes of toffee, raisins and sweet spice. Flavour is reasonably sweet, but nicely balanced, and has brown sugar, dark fruits, cola, citrus and more sweet spice. Mouthfeel is excessively carbonated but aside from that this is a very good dubbel and another great beer from the fantastic St. Bernardus brewery.
Flaske: Mørkebrun uklar øl med masser af klumper i. Krydret sødlig duft. Dejlig spids på tungen med en rigtig god smag. Dejlig lille øl.
Very hoppy, smells rank. Hard on the stomach but once you get passed that there are some interesting flavors, sweet. Cinnamon perhaps.

Bottle from Theatre of Wine, Greenwich. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Nice carbonation. Aromas of bananas,toffee,candy sugars. Flavours of brown sugar, caramel, summer fruits, citrus. Good hoppy finish.
Pours with an ample head.  Nice malty palate. Feels like its missing something to me that Abt 12 has in spades...
Pours hazy brown with a thick foamy beige head. Aroma of raisin, dark fruits and roast malt. Taste is mild alcohol with raisin, berry, peach and lot of roast malt.

Bottle from Sams.  Pours hazy light brown with orange tint.  Large but brief off-white head that fades but retains nicely. Nose of brown sugar, malt, some mild spices and cola. Dark summer fruits. Tastes hints at some earth and slight metallic/coppery notes.  Finishes thin. Very light palate.

Bottle 0,33 l. Murky lighter brown, good beigish head. Nose is perfumy, malty, fruity, quite deep. Flavor is sweet malty with perfume, flowers, cola, vanilla even. Very full and interesting flavor. Good.

Color: Orange copper
Aroma: Complex, light spice (nutmeg?), caramel, candy sugar and roasted malt.
Flavor: Spice (nutmeg?), caramel, candy sugar and roasted malt. Finishes with candy sugar and lightly burnt caramel.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 dark amber coloured body with a off white head a malty sweet fruity aroma a spicy fruity malty caramel sweet taste with a sweet bitter finish
Bottle. Cloudy brown pour with large beige head. Sweet, fruity aroma. Dark fruity taste, sweet, caramel very Belgian. A decent Belgian abbey beer.

Poured from Bottle with a best by 10 xx xx date into a goblet.

Pours a murky brown with some floaties. Thick creamy head disappears into a lid with somewhat inconsistent lacing, sometimes thick, sometimes none at all.

Smells exceptional. Floral, sweet, fruity. Very similar to the Westy 8. If the flavor is even close to that, I have found my new go-to beer and a new favorite style.

Drumroll...it is similar! A nice sweetness but not cloying, with a taste mostly of grapes. A nice hint of bread and cola as well.

Mouthfeel is a tad more carbonated than the Westy, but the body is very good and light.

Drinkability..this is my new go to beer. Its not nearly as difficult to find as the Westy of course, but still not extremely easy to come by here.
Dark brown in color. Aromas are sweet and spicy especially cinnamon. Nice aromas. Not really as thrilled with flavors or palette. Light and quick. Didnt really stick with me.

Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with a huge beige head that lingered forever. The aroma was very yeasty, tangy and sweet with moderate ripe fruits and light butterscotch. The flavor was tangy, chewy and malty with a strong yeasty note and light cherry and caramel elements. The finish was long, tangy, yeasty and fruity. Fairly full bodied. Well done.

April/May 2008:  St. Bernardus Pater 6 smells pretty yeasty and has a vague fruity maltiness in the flavor.  There is also a creamy banana flavor, a mild bitterness, a slight oxidation character, and is toward the sweeter side.  As far as appearance goes, the beer is hazy/cloudy, amber in color, and topped with a large, foamy, lasting head that creates puffy lacing marks.  It has a medium to medium-full body and has a smooth texture.  It is pretty good overall.

750 mL corked and caged bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #630 for this beer.

Coca cola brown, tanned high and lasting tanned non homogenous medium size bubble head.

 Yeast and heavy caramel. Very nice. And thick aroma. Slight hint of hop to offset sweetness of smell.

 Aroma does not translate as well in into flavor. Very neutral.

 Watery feel, some fizz though not much, but light-medium body.

 High scores for the aroma. And for being somewhat complex.

 BJCP characterises as a Dubbel.

 Purchased in Kihoskh

Sampled at MCBF. Who in fuck is giving this low scores in aroma? Are their nostrils the radius of a pin head? The aroma on this is in your face- brown sugar, fruity ale esters, candy, and yeast. Medium bodied with that typical Trappiste earthy mouthfeel. The beer is a nice blend of cheryy, caramel, dark fruits, yeast, and spice. Complex without being extreme.

Bottle, 330ml, from St. Bernardus "Mixed Selection" 6-pack.  Pours dark amber brown with 1/2" enduring headand excellent lacing.  Aroma of alcohol and sugar, with some fruit.  Flavor starts sweet with apricot, walnut(?), and some brown sugar and spices.  Medium body, finishes somewhat malty and bitter.  Very nice, easy to drink, lacing remains long after glass is empty.

Bottle, 330ml, in Trappist glass. Pours dark ochre, with decent, but quickly thinning, head. Mild aroma of mixed fruits, with sultanas predominating. Quite light-bodied, low carbonated on the palate, with sugars and caramel surfacing. Decent ale.

This Beligan ale continues the prior success and enjoyment of St. Bernard brewed beers.  Very enjoyable for the style.  Pours out a dark amber brown, cloudy with a solid 2" thick off-white head.  Drippy lacing left behind was very nice to watch, like lattice work on a wedding cake.  Aroma is solidy built around candi sugar, brassy malts, brown sugar, yeast and a bit of dried fruits.  Flavor starts out with a punch of sweet candi sugar, caramel, dried apricots, spices and a bit of yeast.  Very enjoyable.

330ml bottle into chalice glass. A dark brown hazy beer with a medium off white head. Nose is fruity sweet nutty malts and light hops. The taste is similar with a caramel malty presence and a nice dry spicy hop finish. Thickish body for the ABV. Not bad at all.

(330 ml bottle (best before 4/16/10) from McKean and Charles) Pours cloudy brownish amber with a finger and a half of off-white head. Aroma of spice (cinnamon?), light candy-malt, brown sugar, fruit and some yeast. Mouthfeel soft, fairly smooth but a but fizzy. Lightly sticky on back end. Big, weepy rings of lacing that are well-retained. Flavor of light spice, cinnamon-like over light sweet candy-malt and fruit. The fruitiness is almost cherry-like. Hints of brown sugar and smoke. Very nice and refined although aroma and flavor could be a bit beefier.

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of cereal, cookie and nutty, light herbs and dough for the hops and yeast, with hints of cherry, red wine and brown sugar. Head is average size to start, fizzy, off-white, with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is red/brown, murky, then clears up to show some tiny particles. Flavor starts lighty sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic. Palate is medium, oily, with a carbonation thats lively bordering on fizzy. A well rounded Belgian Ale that could easily be drunk a few at a time.
Bottle. Pour brown colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, hops and caramel.

One of those, "I cant believe I havent rated this one" brews. Hazed light brown color with a tall, bone colored head. Aromas of a trail mix, with nut and raisins. Light German chocolate and a bit of funky yeast. LIght fruit and caramel in the start. A light nut and rye notes in the middle. THe feel is a bit thin to me. Dry finish with a mild caramel and toasted nut bread linger. A Belgian amber, if there is such a thing.

A very nice surprize. I enjoyed this on the gold course one recent afternoon. A nice beer to enjoy as you chase a white ball around. Very heady and light to drink yet the after taste stays with you from drink to drink. I cant wait to enjot this beer while sitting down to truely note the characteristics of this brew

Source:  330 mL bottle purchased from McHughs in Dublin. Glass: Orval Trappist glass. Appearance: Muddy brown pour with a thin layer of off white head.  Aroma:  Aroma was very fruity, with sweet malt present. Flavor: The flavor was sweet malt, dark fruit, candi sugar and lots of cinnamon. Palate:  Medium/full body with solid carbonation.Overall:  Absolutely excellent.  Would love to pick up some more of this.
33cl bottle from hopduvel in ghent, light brown beer, good nose, full taste malt en yeast , a bit sweeten with  sugar but all well balanced, good beer

11.2 oz bottle from a four bottle mix pack that includes a very nice goblet. Lots of escaping carbonation, pours with a medium head that collapses in a few minutes, leaving behind some sticky lace on the glass. Has a pleasant smell of freshly baked holiday fruit cake- the cake part being dominant with the fruit in the background. Body is of course thinner than the 8 or 12, but still sweetly malty. Quickly tapers off to a somewhat astringent finish leaving behind some hop bitters and grippy yeast lees. Good, but I will go for the 8 or 12; love this brewery.
There is not much depth to this beer. It is pleasant in a subtle way, almost the flavor of a brown ale when moving through the mouth. There is not much carbonation to overpower the flavor either.
Bottle.  Pours a brown opaque color with a nice, fluffy, tan head that hangs around for a while.  Nice balance b/w fruitiness and bread like flavors.  Medium-heavily bodied.  Good stuff.

Bottle.  Cloudy brown pour with a nice thick frothy off white head.  Aroma of plums, bananas, yeast and malt.  Taste of malt, brown sugar, dark fruit and a hint of caramel.  Medium body, nice even finish.

330 ml bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Cloudy, deep copper, decent tan foam.
  
Aroma:  Yeast, light earthy funk, some minty herbals, some light molasses, brown sugar, candi sugar, banana and bubble gum esters, much like a dunkel Weizen me thinks, cereal.
  
Palate:  Medium body and fairly full effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose and very much like a dunkel Weizen with some nice malts, lots of esters, light minty herbals and plenty of yeast/brad dough.

Delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 Bottle.  Brownish orange color with a typical big foamy head.  Sweet aroma of yeast and malt.  Nice solid flavor of fruit, malt, and yeast.  Better than most Belgian Ales Ive tried.  Excellent smooth palate with soft carbonation. A good representation of the St. Bernardus brews.

Another solid offering from St. Bernard, the monk pours a light orange color with a big, pillowy head. A nice cornucopia of aromas fills the nostrils with smells of raisins, yeast, and a noticeable malt texture. The tastes are as if the smell was the beer itself, just an overall well rounded brew. LC-CP

been sruprised for a while that I hadnt rated this then I realized I couldnt find it anywhere in SD.  Picked this up yesterday while on a beer run with my brother at Chevy Chase.  bottle gusher at roomish temp.  Pours deep orange with a tan head.  Nose is sweet and fruity and richly malty.  Taste is sweet and fruity with a dubbel like quality.  Tasty.

Bottle-Twas my Easter dinner beer.  A cloudy, ruby color brew with a small head and not much lacing.  The beer was plenty carbonated.  The aroma was mostly sour fruit with some wheat aroma.  The taste was fruity and hoppy with a touch of wheat.  Old rating.
Quite nice. Not a st. bernardus 8 or abt. 12, mind you, but very good. Dark brown with a bubble gum aroma and a sharp yeastiness to it.
Dark copper, auburn brown ish color with a playfully large head. Aroma is highly wheats and breads. Its enjoyable but does more to highlight how good the 12 is than stand on its own.
It has a nice dark color with a pretty nice nose to it, when poured into the right glass. The taste is not too bad, almost a suble feature of nuts. Overall not that bad.
pours a dark hazy amber with an beige head.  bread, spices,  light, drinkable, medium bodied.

Pours a murky brown color with a large creamy head. Nice lacing too. Aroma is nice - crisp and spicy with bread, yeast, and sugar. Taste is the same with a dull  earthy finish. Im generally not a fan of Belgian ales like this, but this one is quite good. Drinkable and enjoyable.

11.2oz bottle (Best before 16 05 11) and served in a tulip.  This beer poured a cloudy, dark amber with a two-finger thick head of tan foam that lasted.  Very nice lacing.  The aroma included caramel, dark fruits (plums, apple), and some spicy yeast esters.  The flavor had thin caramel notes, caramel apples, fruit skins, and also some breadiness.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and had crisp, aggressive carbonation.  While lacking the complexities of its bigger brothers, this is still a decent brew.
Reddish brown with a quickly disappearing beige head.  Some caramel aroma but not sweet.  Spicy toasted malt flavor with a dry, slightly sour finish.  Nice light carbonation.
some caramel smell and flavor along with some roast malt a little sour.  The program wants me to write more about it but I just dont have anything else to say. Its a so so beer.

Bottle @ Victory Bar...  Poured a hazy ruby-brownish with a thick, beige head.  Spiced, toasted malt aroma.  Light carbonation and a thin base to the palate.  Creamy yeast and malt notes.  Very spiced and sweet bread-like notes with a smoked almond character in the finish.
This reddish brown ale poured with a huge beige head that  bubbled away in short order.There is a fruity aroma and a nut and spice flavor with some banana ester. There is a long dry peppery finish.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009  general - 0,33 bottle, at home

 appearance - tee brown with of brown head, strong and firm, a bit hazy

aroma - sweet malt and nuts
taste - mature and good, first milky smooth sweetish then more aicidic and even bitterish, meadow and herbs
other remarks upper level, however not so good as its freinds (e.g. Bernardus Abt 12 or pater 8)

Bottle: Cloudy, reddish-amber coloured, lasting creamy beige lacy head; sweetish-fruity nose with a good dash of toasted malt, nutty aromas, too; medium bodied; moderate to robust sweet-bitter flavour; lingering sweet-bitter finish with a dryish chocolatey touch in the aftertaste. A ggod one..........

Brown bottle, 330 ml, best befire 30 09 11, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on March 25 2009; eye: chestnut with caramel reflections, slightly hazy, light effervescence, voluminous beige head that falls and turns into a thin sheet, slight lacing; nose: yeast, caramelized malt, light spices, light fruity; mouth: yeast, caramelized malt, light spices, light fruity, finale in yeast with good presence of spices and presence of malt and hops, medium body, quite carbonated, slick, lightly bitter and sweet, a bit thin; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 330 ml, meilleure avant 30 09 11, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 25 mars 2009; il : marron avec des reflets caramel, très légèrement voilée, légère effervescence, mousse beige abondante qui tombe et se transforme en une mince couverture, très légère dentelle; nez : levure, malt caramélisé, léger épices, léger fruité; bouche : levure, malt caramélisé, léger épices, léger fruité, finale en levure avec bonne présence dépices et présence de malt et houblon, corps moyen, pas mal carbonatée, coulante, légèrement amère et sucrée, un peu mince; en résumé : bien aimé

12oz bottle. $3.95 First off, I have to say that I am becoming a big fan of St Bernardus. One of my highest ratings so far has been given to their Apt 12. With this one I was not really expecting anything great based on the other reviews and the style but I was pleasantly surprised. I really like this. It has a nice creamy head that, like many other belgians, seems to be alive. Pours a nice brown color. Unlike many of the other belgians I have tried this one does not hit you over the head with alcohol taste making it very drinkable. Subtle flavorings of spice and fruit. Cant wait to taste the other St Bernardus to see if this trend continues.
Nice looking dark amber with a big fluffy head. Aroma of yeast, very bread like. Flavor rich and smooth. Very clean and crisp finish.

Pours dark caramel color with light tan head. Belgian yeast and candy sugar aromas. Fruity taste with light candy sugar and some maltiness. Belgian yeast flavor is also noticeable. Medium body with lively carbonation.

Had a medium brown golden pour with a light tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, and malt sweetness.  Light roasted and low dark fruit noticed in the malty body.  Had a slightly dry finish.  Good brew but not spectacular.

Date: 20/2/09
Beer info: Bottled in brown 330ml bottle 6.7% abv bb 11 04 11

Sampling Notes:
Served lightly chilled in chalice.
Bit of a gusher. Pours a biggish offwhite mess of dense foam atop a murky sort of coppy body.
Fruit cake sort of nose. Brown sugar, bready yeast, sweet cake, dried apricot and sultana. Bit of alcohol and grassiness in the background.
Smooth, creamy mouthfeel, carbonation is pretty low, medium bodied. Slight alcohol dryness on the finish.
Brown sugar-like malt body, hints of orange and dried fruit. Bread and cake, with a bit of grass on a dry and quite bitter finish.
Seemed a bit too easy to drink. Nice enough sort of Belgian pale ale, not overly complicated or strong, probably why it goes down so well.

Enjoyed via 12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown with an ivory to light tan head.  Nose is rich with dark fruits and high crystal (80-120) malts.  The palate certainly does not disappoint, with wonderful notes of raison, silightly burnt candy, and a nice spritzy carbonation.  The finish is a great blend of sweet and dry.
Bottle. Pours with a medium tan head with some lacing. Medium amber in color. Somewhat thin, carbonated mouthfeel. Flavor is somewhat malty and plenty spicy. Not bad.

Bottle at O´learys Copenhagen Central station. 
Plum-greyish colour with a smal head. A lot like the 8 but with a thiner (to thin) body. Some sweet flavour with a resemblance with Listerine...
Bottle. This is very much alike St. Bernadus Prior 8. It smells the same but with less power. The taste is a little more spicy.

Pours cloudy brown, hint of ruby, thin white head with moderate retention and minimal lacing. Floral, fruity aroma, lots of apples and a slight hint of spice but also some mustiness where I could do without. Flavour is overwhelmed to an extent by aggressive carbo though some mild spiciness does come through. Mouthfeel is thin and domintated by carbonation, reminds me of soda water. Bleh. Not sure whether it was the bottle or the beer, but I wasnt sold.

Pours a cloudy chestnut brown with a thin head with half-decent retention and minimal lacing. Grainy vegetal (oat bran?) aroma, damp sawdust with just a hint of sweetness underneath. Unusual! Taste is odd as well - vaguely sweet with light toasted grains, some diacetyl, nearly no finish whatsoever. Body is quite good, though, despite any other shortcomings - very very creamy, if a bit thin, and plenty of carbonation. I really dont like the damp grain taste of this beer, its odd. If it were marketed as such it would be fine, but as a basic Belgian ale its a direction into which I have no wish to foray.
Tap.  Poured dark reddish brown.   Aroma and flavor were well balanced roasty malts and yeast.  Lacks complexity and was lighter than I imagined.  Overall though, very nice beer.

Gusher.  Muddied brown, wild and uneven head.  Some good abbey yeast on the nose, but old dishwater too.  Same taste of something turned and forgotten, like socks or a cardboard box that got damp.  The hints of the Bernardus 12 are there, but only underscore that something is not complete here.  I need another bottle.

Pours a rich ruby color with thick frothy off white head.  Aroma of concord grape, light green apple and belgian spice.  Taste is dark fruit, concord grape, and yeast and belgian spice.  As per usuual, St. Bernardus has a smooth creamy finish.  great brew.

Thanks bro!  Pours a plum color with a lot of particulate and a medium creamy off-white head.  Aroma is intense green apple, concord grapes, a bit of alcohol, and plum and other dark fruits.  Taste is dark fruit, a bit of green apple, and some bready yeastiness.  An enjoyable sipper.

pours slightly thick, med brown, highly carbonated.  nice slightly sweet aroma.  moderate to full bodied flavors of yeast, bread, powdered sugar and a fairly clean finish.  maybe a touch of clove and cinnamon.  Overall its fine, but for the expensive price, I will not be getting this again.

bottle.  Hazy deep golden pour with two finger white head with minimal lacing.  Fruit hides the hops on the nose.  Clean crisp taste with sweet fruit hints with hops and spice coming in near the end.  Nice and smooth all the way!
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Red-amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. MOderate bitter slightly fruity flavor. Average mderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

(bottle) pours a clear, bubbly reddish-amber colour with a huge fluffy off-white head. aroma of bread dough, caramel and yeast, with notes of sweet spices, dark fruit, apples and toffee. flavour is the same, but less subtle, with more apples and a touch of grain. medium-bodied with smooth carbonation

Light solid brown with a finger of light tan head, plum and prune aroma.  Sweet malts, light candy sugar notes.  Taste is nice and sweet and malty, more prunes, light banana note and very bready and yeasty spicy on the finish.

Hazy deep amber pour with a good foamy head that lasts throughout.  Aroma is lots of ripe fruit, sweet malt and yeast.  Flavor starts sweet and fruity, with yeast and spiciness coming through on the finish.  Nicely carbonated and smooth on the palate.  Very good.

Pours deep amber into the glass, with a nice eggshell head that keeps 1/4-inch retention and foamy lace.  The nose is of dark fruity esters and spices.  The flavors are reminiscent of a porter, with bready notes, dark dried fruits, yeast and deep malts.  The finish is of a nice red (Cab or Port) wine, round and conclusive, somewhat vinous.... a lingering close without crispy bitterness.  Mouthfeel is whole and substantiating, nicely complex.  Great blend of yeasty bread and dark fruits in this offering.  Nice trappist Belgian.

Malty aroma with fruity notes, some citrus, slight mustiness, perhaps some bread crust.  Color is a muddy orange with foamy off white head. Flavor is dried fruits and rich malt, light chocolate and woody notes, some orange peel, perhaps a little dried fruit and licorice.   Crisp palate, decently carbonated, light bitter roasty duration.  Pretty good.

Bottle conditioned, 330 ml, aged 4.2 years. Red chestnut colour with large white, lacy, head. Vinous aroma, full of plum and prune, the body is medium depth, again vinous, porty with a rich fruity, sultana flavour and a yeasty, bready note, a bit like christmas cake. No spicing that I can detect, which is in its favour. A really pleasant Belgian Ale.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy dark amber color with a medium frothy light tan head that lasts awhile. The aroma is very fruity with raisin and plums and cherries. Good sticky lacing on the glass. The taste is a light malt with a faint fruit in the finish. Easy to drink, a good belgian ale from St. Bernardus.

Style and Glass: Belgian Ale, Trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 6% in 11.2 fl oz. estimated at 150 C
Purchased at: Joe Canals Lawrenceville, NJ as part of a $17.00 gift pack with glass.

Aroma: beautiful scent, flowery, cherries, peach, cloves, spicy, fruity, oak.

Visuals: simple, beautiful packaging, cloudy iced tea, deep reddish brown, nearly opaque, staying white head, intricate fresh lace.

Taste: deep and balanced, hearty fruity malt, some fleeting hops, lighter body than expected.

Palate: crisp, clean, but obviously unfiltered, longer fruit based finish.

Overall: A wonderful brew. A bit expensive for what it is, understandably so, but a very nice experience.

http://beercritic.wordpress.com/200

St. Bernardus certainly knows how to make a good beer. This one’s not as good as the Abt 12 but it’s still pretty darn good. LOTS of different flavors in this one. It blends nicely and goes down easy.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy, medium-brown, with a puffy 2.5 finger beige head, good and lasting lacing.  Smells of figs, caramel, pears, and hay.  Medium, velvety, crisp body.  Fruit flavor, much like the aroma, with some lemon.  Very mild bitterness that balances all of the sweet malt about midway through, even less bitterness in the aftertaste.  Well balanced.

Clovey date nose.  Brown color with hints of amber, big head, nice lacing.  Flavor was sweet pepper raisins, slight bitterness of orange pith.  Medium bodied, big carbonation, finishes smooth.  A solid beer, almost seems like a "light" version of Prior 8.

Pours a dark red brown with a thin tan head with decent lacing left on the glass.  Aroma of malt, ripe plum, sugar and malt, very sweet smelling.  Very candylike at first, powdered sugar with banana, yeast, malt and a slight sourness as it finishes.  Light feel but carbonated, a bit fizzy.   Good abbey but would rather have the 8 or 12 any day.

Tinge of pink to the frothy big head good carbonation in a red brown pour that is misty with a fig aroma malt raisin banana flavour smooth malty banana fig raisin good hop flavour with mild bitter yeasty notes slight tang plum and mild cherry taste finish really fruity dry smooth.

Pours murky orange with a foamy white head. Heavily carbonated. Aroma is of bananas, spice, malt, and yeast. Taste is very sweet fruit, mostly lemon and bananas with malt, spice, and yeast. Very earthy taste. Light, creamy mouthfeel.

Great looking beer.  Pours a cloudy brown, with a nice frothy off-white head.  Very little lacing, but all is foregiven.  Light aroma of pit fruit and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is a light malt, roasted nuts, bread, with a touch of hop bittering.  Palate is a bit fizzy and carbonated for my tastes.  Overall a good basic Belgian ale

I drink this Pater in remembrance of Father Dan OSullivan at St. Irenaeus, who married me to my wife and baptized our kids, who enjoyed any beer I brought him and with whom I shared my first DFH WWS. Pours deep brown with a big head that needed some time to settle. Nice smell of raisins and plums, with sweetness emanating from the glass. After that buildup, the taste actually runs a little light. Sweetness is NOT that heavy. Instead, like a modest ale, it simply delivers a nice blend of malt and some nearly German-type hop sharpness. Lot of chunky foam and lace sticking around the glass. Fruitiness not as apparent in the taste. This bottle, at least, slides in more like a basic fine ale. And thats just fine by me.
Pours reddish brown with a decent white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, slightly yeasty, as is the taste.
bottle at ørsted cph. aroma of caramel, malts, toffee. appears dark brown witha small white head. flavor is wery well balanced, sweet caramelly yeasty of nature. delicious.

Pours a light brown with pinkish orange highlights and a big white head.  Aroma is very fruity with some nice yeast spiciness.  Flavor is softly sweet with some plum like fruit flavors and clove spice.  Awesome mouthfeel and extremely drinkable.

Poured a clear but fairly dark body with good lasting, tight white head. Not big on the aroma, notice the alcohol and then some drieds fruit if you are looking. Taste is smooth, malt driven with a touch of spice, simple but very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours murky copper dark brown with a mostly diminishing white head. Aroma: clove, nuts, molasses, alcohol, raisins. Definitely a perfect blend between malts and fruits. Medium bodied with a silky mouthfeel. Aftertaste is mostly bitter dry with lingering sweetness and alcoholwarming.

Poured deep cherry red, almost opaque, with a generous two-finger head that left a nice creamy film and excellent lacing. Malty aroma with dark fruit like raisins and plums. Same pleasant fruitiness is featured on the tongue, with some molasses, caramel and black pepper. Medium to full body, silky smooth mouthfeel, lively carbonation, and wonderful dark fruit aftertaste.
Nice dark brown head, lighter flavor than the Prior 8, but just as tasty.  Quite malty, with a subtle hint of dark fruits, carmel, and just a little vanilla.  Another winner from St. Bernardus!
Dark brown with medium tan head.  Aroma of raisins and malt.  Medium-mouthed, flavor of raisins, caramel.  A junior version of the Prior - in strength, not in flavor.  Very nice.

Pours a hazy, muddy brown with a smaller off-white head that dwindles down quite a bit. Lacing is mild. Aromas of yeast, spice, and alcohol. Taste is very tart and a bit sour. Lots of molasses, unsweetened cocoa, toffee, caramel malts, dark fruits (raisins, plums), and black pepper. Mouthfeel is a bit thin. Aftertaste is very dry. A decent dubbel and a very complex Belgian. But this is nowhere near my favorite for the style.

I’m not going to even go in depth with this one.  Basically, think "St. Bernardus quality" in a brew that allows you to have 3 or more without getting completely plastered.  At its core this is a watered down Belgian - and I mean that in the best way possible.

Sampled on draught at the Brasserie V in MAdison: Pours a deep dark copper colour with a huge beige head. Aroma is pleasent, very fruity- like bright fruits and roasted malts. Taste is full slightly citrusy and yeasty but balanced and rich.
A neat beer with an aroma of darwk fruit and caramel. The flavour is balanced with fruit, malt and a soft bitterness. Quite fine!

Pours dark brown, beige head.
Aroma is malty with nice earthly notes and spices.
Taste is malty with some nice caramel addition, light dark fruits (cherry/prune), candi sugar and a good carbonation. Leaves an enjoyable tingly feel on the palate.
This one is a few steps under the greatness of the other Bernardus. Still a very enjoyable brew with just the right amount of alcohol.
Amber/brown, with an off white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, and sugar. Flavor is malt and fruit. Medium body.
Bottle 33cl. Cloudy dark amber colour, small but dense off-white head. Lively carbonation. Malty, hoppy in the finish, underlined with that wonderful belgian yeast. mmmmh.
Pretty sweet.  Nice color on the pour.  Fluffy white head.  Fruity taste some hops and light malt.  good.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 Crushed with Jakebra.  Very full bodied.  St. Bernardus brews always have that high carbonation that makes for a sexy mouthfeel.  Lots of sweetness and awesomeness in this brew.

Dark amber with big, foamy off-white head / Musty nose of cardboard and dark fruit / Medium body, malty and mildly sweet, with decent finish / Musty, muted, cooked flavors of malt, raisins, figs, and oak / Never sure how fresh these beers are, but based upon this - good but overrated.
A bottle tasted at Vastarannan Kiiski with Mirjukka. Pale brown head. Pale reddish copper colour. A soft slightly malty taste with some hints of raisins.
Bottled. Hazy and dark brown in colour with a rather large off-white head. Sweet and malty with notes of dark dried fruit - caramel and yeast.

Super sudsy tan head atop an auburn brown body, this belgian warns you with a whiff of raisins, molasses and mildly sweet malt.  The fruitiness persists pleasantly through the finish.  Very smooth, very satisfying for relaxing with.

Huge carbonated off-white head.Dark brown color with ruby highlights.  Aroma of raisins, some malts.  Tastes of fruit-raisin, malts.  Smooth, not offensive at all. Not quite as rich as other offerings from this brewer.

330ml bottle (Vastarannan Kiiski, Helsinki, Belgian Weeks)
Bold orange, tiny head. Sweet fruity nose, and that’s matched in the palate too, which is very soft. Good malty body, but quite sweet. There’s a bit of tomato in the taste, weird. Very characterful fruity beer.

(Bottle, 0.33 l, at Vastarannan Kiiski, Helsinki, on 2008-09-25) Amber. Hazy. Small white head. Very fruity nose with some sweet aromas, too. Full bodied palate with little carbonation. Sweetness, bitterness, raisin and also tiny hint of sourness. Not bad at all.
not as good as any of the others ive had, but its decent, more bitter and less effervescent than any of the others, for the price tag, i wouldn’t revisit it.
bottle 250ml at Vastarannan Kiiski Shared with JK54B 170908 murky light brown creamy head fruity, malty dash of sourness sweetish dried fruits aftertaste warming foody
Brown pour wtih a light tan and very creamy head.  Aroma is fruity, spice, sweetness and some yeast too.  Flavor is full and rich...very malty and damn good.
Bottle. Pours deep red brown with a creamy beige head. Sweet fruity aroma, with apple, yeast and some spicy notes. The flavor is also sweet, fruity and yeasty. Very solid.
Another great beer one could assume these to be the top of the top the brewery makes very wonderfull beers

Bottle. Poured brown with a creamy off-white head that leaves light lacing. Sweet aroma of fruits, malts, and a hint of spices. The flavor is also sweet with dark fruits and malt backing. Medium body, fizzy carbonation, and dry. Nice.

A hazy ruby/nutty-brown colored beer, with a off-white foamed head. The aroma of some sweets, some spicey, with notes of caramel and yeast. The taste of a little chocolate with some caramel and little dark fruits, like raisins. The aftertaste is a little bitter and dry.

Bottle (in NZ), pours a hazy reddish-brown with a filmy head. Whiskeyish oaky and smokey aroma, with hints of citrus and medicinal notes. A heavy malty palate, quite a bit of carbonation. Some sweet fruit at first, also chocolate flavours that become more obvious in the finish, which also has some of those whiskeyish characteristics again. Worryingly easy to drink!

12oz bottle. Earthy, malty nose with sweet fruits. Pours a murky bubbly brown with a big rich head. Taste is very malty with some fruit sweetness on the backend. Very well balanced. Long lingering notes of chocolate of caramel, not as strong as in the prior 8 but similar. Very very good.

Murky brown pour.  dissipating white head.  Malty, fruity aromas. Solid Earthy malt tones in mouth.  Sweet fruit and light.  slight tinge of alcohol in the finish.  Nothing overly exciting but still delicious.

From a small bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a chestnut-mahogany body with a creamy medium beige head.  Nutty, Christmas nose.  Spicy, effervescent and piquantly sweet.  Like many St. B beers, had a brown sugar signature flavor.  Killer!
(Bottle).  Aroma is sweet plum.  Pours hazy reddish brown with a large head.  High carbonation, flavor is pleasingly sweet, not overpowering.   Overall, a light feel, and a very pleasant experience.
Pours a dark caramel brown with a tan head.  Aroma and taste have hints of toffee, caramel and alcohol.  Palate is thick/oily with a smooth finish.
Bottle. At best a watered down version of the Prior 8. Taste is too sweet for me, lots of brown sugar and mouldy St-B-yeast. Won’t drink this too often. There are better St.Bernardus beers.

Bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy brown color with a medium sized beige head and decent lacing.  The aroma was moderately sweet fruits, bananas, yeast, and slightly oxidized.  The flavor was yeasty, fruity, spices, brown sugar.  This was medium bodied with moderate sweetness.

A very good beer.  Almost tastes like a juice, but deeper.  The brown color is a bit foggy, but it still tastes pretty good.  I drank it out of an official St. Bernardus Glass.  I am a true fan of Belgian Ales.

Pours hazy brown with two finger head. Nose of plum, figs, molasses, some spicy yeast, and caramel. Flavors are quite sweet- lots of plum and raisin with some spice and brown sugar sweetness. Palate is medium bodied with a semi-dry finish. Came up a little short in my book, but tasty just the same.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, easy to drink, balanced, cloudy, good head, good brew

bottle.  Pours a dark, opaque brown, big chunky off white head that sticks around throughout.  Aromas of raisins, black currants, and a cloyingly sweet maltiness.  Flavors blend very well... starts with a light touch of floral bitterness, heavy raisin and fig flavors, and some yeast notes.  Very even on the palate, a decent amount of active carbonation, and a nice, smooth clean finish.  Very good brew.
Bottled. Poured a dark bround w/symmetrical and lasting head. Some raisins & rum aroma.  Taste similar w/yeats caramel malts. Pretty good.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown.  light two finger tight foamy head.  Aroma is of pizza dough with a bit of earthy dark fruits.  The flavor is even better, dark fruits, spices, a bit of a bread flavor, caramel, and malt.  Medium body, has a good smooth feel.  Overall this is a very good beer.  Not as heavy as many, and more balanced flavor.

Muddy brown, thin beige head. aroma of red aples and molasses, mixed with a bit of rum. Flavor is molasses and fruit, like maybe figs or prunes. Surprisng amount of alcohol heat for 6.7% beer. Nice earthy, rough finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with some light pouring through and a two finger or so head that is fairly dense.  Has aromas that are woody and nutty with a bit of bread dough, yeast and spice.  Flavor is a little different, however, as it mixes dark fruit, sawdust, allspice and rye bread.  Thought this would be much different, although this is pretty darn acceptable.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I would expect nothing less from St Bernardus. Taste of sweet fruit, caramel, malt. Mid to full bodied and yet easily drinkable.
A "gyenge" Pater csak az alkohol fokában az.Mármint a többihez képest.Sötét színű,sűrű,édeskés,gyümölcsös,karam ízű főzet.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2008 0.33l bottle, pale brown pour with tan head.

Quite light for a "dark"; beer, fruity, sweet and caramel flavours, some malt, no alcohol.  Very enjoyable and full of flavour.

Bottle, Stirchley Wines and Spirits, Birmingham. Poured a hazy brown colour with a dissipating white head.. Some fruit, yeast and spice in the aroma.
Flavour was sweetish and malty. Some dark fruit and spice in there somewhere. Carbonation was a bit on the heavy side. Nothing special on the whole and expected a lot more.

Melted caramel in color with a medium, tan head.  Fruity aroma backed by malts, spices, light molasses, and a touch of sourness.  Full bodied with lively carbonation.  Very flavorful.  Spicy yeast, malts, caramel, and some fruit as well.  While I wouldnt call it earth shattering its a very solid belgian.

cola brown pour with a medium sized dirty white head.  Aroma is up front pear and heavy malt.  Flavor is caramel,  pear,  orange,  kiwi,  and a bit of spice.  Finishes prickly carbonated,  very easy to drink for the style.  No hint of any booze,  lightly refreshing which is weird for the flavors I am getting.

Beautiful head. Simple, yet complex. Or rather, there are a variety nice flavors & aromas that blend perfectly together to make one solid profile, however when analyzed delicious moderately sweet bready caramel malt lays flat and soft on the tongue, while grapes among other fresh fruits coupled with an interesting, yet very gentle yeast character floats harmoniously above. Decently smooth on the carbonation, but a tad too thin and watery.

Deep cloudy brown, huge tan foamy head. Strong aroma of dark sugar, malple, nut, fig, barely, and yeast. Very nice complex aroma.  Flavor is like a high quality strong pilsener, with the skunky hops. Also tastes like roasted caramel barely malt, and raw brown sugar. The feel of this beer is good and refreshing, and nicely carbonated on the taste. Refreshing, full, finish with a nice bite.
pours dark brown really cloudy with a big foamy head. nose is pure bread yeast, bread, breadyness. some spice too it as well. but mostly bread. tastes thick and bready, malt yeast bread. very decent.

33cl bottle from Total Wine Tampa. Pours dark reddish brown with a one-finger whitish-tan head. Good head retention. Smells of fresh fruit, bread, slight sweetness, caramel, hints of chocolate. Flavor is flowers, clove, malty, bread, yeast, with a hint of caramel on finish. Nice, medium-bodied mouthfeel.
Bottle from Stateline.  Pours lighter than 8, but still looks great.  Lots of cream, malted notes, and some familair molasses notes as well.  Finish is more alcholic than the 8, also thinner.

What a nice beer from St. Bernardus.  Shock I know, because all of their beers rock.  This one had a great pour with wonderful lacing.  Its aroma was a creamy malt that also was prominent in its flavor.  Overall such a great beer, a much try.
Bottle. Pours a body similar to Prior 8, but with a bit lighter with reddish hue. The aroma is dark fruit and molasses.  Taste is fruit and alcohol.

A delicious and great Belgian beer. Ive always loved St. B and was looking forward to trying this. Aroma was nice and full. Strong dark caramel, fruit, spice and yeast. Pour was a perfect deep murky dark brown with a 3 finger off white head. Taste was very unique and delicious. Strong biting yeast, dark fruit and a hint of banana. After the swallow there is a strong caramel aftertaste. Almost as caramelly as Saranac Caramel Porter. Strong carbonation rounds out this great beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured hazy copper color with a large light brown head that lasted with good lacing. Very complex  herbs and yeasty banana aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Full complex fruit and spicy sweet flavor with solid sweet finish of moderate duration. Very good brew.

bottle.  pours a brown color with a 1 finger white head.  spicy and dark fruit aroma.  big soft body with a lot of carbonation.... very nice palate... some raisins, grapes, sugar and malts.  some yeast on the finish.

11.2 oz. bottle from Total Wine.  Pours a murky brown color with a slight off-white head.  Aroma is of toffee and dark fruit.  Nice malty taste with hints of brown sugar, maybe.  Somewhat dry in the finish with some bread and lots of carbonation at the swallow.  Good beer, but not Bernarduss best.

Strong, immediately noticeable aroma, quite fruity. Very little head. Pours an interesting color, murky light brown. The fruit fully comes out in the taste, raisin like, definite dark fruit flavor. A bit too much carbonation for my taste. Even so, a delicious beer that Ill be back for more of in the future.

Bottle: Dark brown color with a rasinish aroma.  Very smooth medium carbonation, lightly sweet brown sugar flavor.  I had the Prior 8 last night and it spoiled me, this seems like a junior version of that.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2008 Pours dark murky brown with a large frothy creamy beige head.   Great cinnamon and brown sugar aroma, nutty and vinous.   Flavor is fluffy cinnamon and brown sugar coated green apples.   A little bit vinous and a tad nutty.  Candied malt, some banana and also dried fruits.  Flavors are not particular strong and finish with a hint of alcohol.   Extremely fluffy mouthful, a little bit too much too swallow.   Similar to Witkap-Pater single.

On draft at the Federal Grille in Allentown, PA. Fairly clear brown pour with minimal head. Flavor is malts, dried fruits, mild spice, and a dry finish. Nice mellow alcohol warming. Nice Belgian brew.

pours a murky, muddy brownish amber with an off-white head.  aroma is malty, with some fruit (ripe red apple, some tart berry), with a little spice and some alcohol.  taste is wineish, a bit sour some more of the ripe apple, a little fig & grape set in heavy at first, followed by a mellowing where the malt comes through with some sweet notes, then finishes a little dry and leaves a fruity (again, im getting a lot of ripe red apple) resin on the tongue.  mid-light body with some prickly carbonation.  not a bad brew, definitely a session-type. overall a tasty beer thats not as complex as the abt 12 or prior 8, but a good drinker nonetheless.  id like to try this alongside st. bernardus tripel, as im seeing some similarities.  NOTE: judging from other reviews, mine may have gone a bit bad, will re-buy & rereate when i get a chance.
