MIld alcohol rears late and lingers with anise (a flavor I couldnt place until I read the previous ratings... good call by nick76). 



<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>
Brown mahogany pour with a decent sized tan head.  Watery palate, mildly malty fruity flavor.  Pretty basic.

The aroma has caramel, (a basement like) yeast, bread, and cola. The appearance is red brown with a medium head. The flavor has bread, caramel, anise, and a little licorice. The palate is typical for the style. Overall its good.
Dark chestnut brown body, nice creamy medium head. Strong malty aroma, toffee, spices, dark fruit, alcohol. Full bodied malty caramel, wood flavour, coffee in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a wonderful mahogany color with a thin light brown head.  Sourdough bread aroma with some nice candy like sweetness.  Dark fruits and spices as well.    Malt dominates the taste and finishes with a  slightly bad apple cider taste.  Mouthfeel is a little creamy and carbonated.
Malt, alcohol, flowers dominate the aroma of this hazy brown beer.  The head is rather lose and dissipates quickly.  Very heavy with a sour flavor that dominates the malt.  Finishes clean.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Great looking murky brown.  Yeasty.  Enjoyable, yet a bit disappointing.  Malts.
Slightly hazed brown appearance, thick head formation. Bready, toffee aroma, mildly toasted. Yeasty fruitiness, banana and raisin, roasted nuts, mild spice, slightly dryish toasty finish.
33 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Brown colour with a nice white head. aroma of yeast and sweet caramel. Flavour of yeast, spices, sour and some roasted malt. Not the best from this brewery.

Dark red, slight brown colored. Medium beige head. Chocolate, sweetness, fine spices in aroma, mild toffee and licorice too. Medium bodied. Chocolate, sweetness, mild spices and alcohol in flavor, mild licorice lasts with some alcohol. Somehow these St. Bernardus products have been slight disappointments because being too sweet, actually this gets best points of these (6,8,tripel and 12).

Sampled from bottle.  Pours murky cocoa brown with a sudsy tan head and thick lacing.  Aroma is gentle and quite complex: rich malts, carmelized sugars, and fruity exters.  Very nice.  Flavor is not as complex as the aroma, oddly enough.  Balanced towards the sweet side and dry with tart fruits.  Medium-bodied and moderately carbonated but still seems a bit thinner than what I expected.  Enjoyable.
From bottle.  Pours a medium orange brown with frothy tan head.  Nose is yeasty with a sweet bread aroma.  The body is very carbonated with dark fruits and spices.

It was a dark burnt orange and very coludy when poured from a 11.2 ounce bottle.  The head was a creamy white about a 1/4th inch in height and it did not last long.  However, this is one carbonated brew.  There is no lacing left on the glass, a snifter.  It has an aroma of sweet caramel and light fruits and tastes about the same.  It finishes clean and the high carbonation makes it refreshing.  I could sit down and drink a lot of these.

This pours a dark but in no way opaque burgandy with orange hues.  The head is large, offwhite, finely bubbled, and incredibly long-lasting.  The nost is lightly sweet and somewhat citric with hints of cherries.  The palate is very similar, revealing a light alcoholic flavoring and a medium to high sweetness (though not nearly as sweet as the hyper-fermented brews).  The carbonation lightens and "covivializes" the light stickiness of the malty sweetness.

Another dark pour from the saint.  Light chocolat brown head that faded quickly.  Very easy drinking and would make a great session beer, but not nearly as complex or good as the other St. Bernardus beers.  Had much higher then expected carbonation.
Average.  Easy to drink - some malt and not overly spicy.  I find the body a bit light though.  Aroma is of raisins, light hops and average malt.

Bottle.  Cherry - orange malt aroma with alcohol sharpness.  Dark copper with moderate head.  Sweet orange/raisin flavor with moderate carbonation and acidity.  A bit on the weak side - like a more robust flavor in Belgian ales.

Partly because it is in a beautiful St. Bernadus goblet, but this is one of the nicest looking beers that I have ever seen.  Deep burgundy color with a nice off white head.  Great lacing.  Very yeasty aroma with some dark fruits and a hint of spice.  Fruit more noticeable in the flavor along with some candi sugar.  Fairly dry but very smooth and lasting finish.  Very nice.
Pours a dark amber with an off-white head.  Great lacing.  Aroma was very yeasty with hints of raisins and caramel.  A gentle malt taste with a nice warm alcohol finish.

11.2oz bottle pours dark amber with a creamy offwhite head that stays well and laces the sides of the trappist glass.  Aroma is mostly yeast, also notes of raisins, caramel, and cloves.  Flavor is nice raisins, caramel, lots of yeast, some candy sugar, and some cloves.   Palate is light airy and smooth to drink with a nice dry finish.  Pretty nice..

Pours dark ruby with thin, mostly maintained off-white head. True to its heritage, this beer leaves resilient Belgian lacing. Aroma of raisins, plums, cloves, and bubble gum. 
Taste begins with sweet caramel and plums, there is a brief but intense chewy/malty note, and the beer fades away leaving a trail of fruity esters. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and viscous with high carbonation. This beer has candi sweetness and caramelized wort sweetness. The yeast would dominate this beer if it were not so wonderfully balanced by the toasted malts. Impressive balance and complexity, quite delicious!
[bottle in kulminator] fruity, raisins, caramel. good body finish is sweet and dry. pretty standard but nice dubbel.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark orange-brown with an average size fizzy off-white head. Nice sweet aroma of malt, yeast, spices, fruit and alcohol. Flavour of bready malt, yeast, brown sugar, fruit, spices and alcohol. Speaking of alcohol, I found it a little too noticeable for a beer thats only 6.7%. Considering how great most St. Bernardus beers are the flavour was a bit of a letdown. The finish is quite fizzy, theres lots of carbonation. Full bodied. A decent Belgian Ale.
weak orange/lemon peel, spiced aroma, high carbonation, chocolatey/yeasty finish, warms in back of throat, alcohol taste is even throughout, pretty good, still like the 12 better

Dark brown with a small head that thins quickly.  Smells of licorice and toffee.  The taste contains toffee, bananas and a hint of coffee.  Extremely subtle and gentle, it doesnt overpower the palate.  Finish is slightly bitter but not bad.

Vinous, sweet grape, anise and caramel and the slightest little bit of peppery spice. Hazy amber, brown with a thinning, off-white head.  Great chewy licorice, dried fruit (raisins) and caramel and a bit of brown sugar.  Very yummy, much like the 12, but not as strong or rich.  The finish has a slight earthy twist.  Sweet, almost dry on the palate and fairly full bodied.  Thanks to Brigadier for sharing this bottle.

Dark brown hazy beer with a small off-white head. Aroma of yeast and liquorice with malt in the background somewhere. Taste begins like tiramisu: sweet sponge soaked in alcohol with some coffee notes. Then comes sourness before a slight bitterness. But its all very subdued, restrained and gentle.

From the bottle.
Pours a light caramel with a modest head; the nose is a straight-forward lemon-and-spice Belgian aroma; the flavor is biscuit malts with a hint of rye and a long finish of bitter and slightly soapy hops. I dont sense so much by way of complexity, though. Mouthfeel is spritzer-like, with small bubblles; combined with the dry finish and the mere 6.7% alcohol, this is a relatively refreshing and easy-drinking beer as Belgian ales go.

This bottled brew bottled in 2004 poured a large sized head of foamy/frothy top of unnoted size long lasting unnoted colored bubbles very nice lacing.  The body contained average carbonation, was very hazy and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of malty floral yeast with a vinous note.  Its mouth feel is initially tingly with a  slightly tingly mellow palate and a mild brown malt aftertaste.  Its flavor contained brown malt vinuous mild malty yesty notes.  All-in-all very nice brew.

330ml brown bottle. Poured with a generous tan head, somewhat frothy, some sticky lace. Reddish brown colour, some haze. Cookie-ish malts aroma, almonds (?), fruity with a mild spice note, sort of like mild banana bread. Amazingly soft palate, very mild carbonation. Body is full, slightly oily. Malty flavour, some sweetness in the middle leads to a dryish finish with some yeast and a slight tease of hops.

Gift Pack 33cl, perfect condition. Extremely fine cakey/bready maltiness with a soft mouthfeel and softly sweet (almost banana) frutiness, and delicate baked-in spices mingling on the top of it. Prickly teasing light spice aroma. Elusive and yet satisfying - the best "Light Beer" on the planet, relatively speaking of course!  ;) Highly drinkable and worth finding.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2006 Aroma is very malty (makes me want to have a malted milkshake) with hints of hazlenut.  Color is light brown with a magnificent  three finger tan head that looks like you could walk across it; if you were 2 inches tall.  Very malty in the fore..somewhat syrupy with hazlenut and cocoa notes.  Slight  fruitiness in the finish.
Great appearance, aroma is quite subdued. Very noticeable yeast character (not a bad thing at all) but othewise a well done beer, if not especially notable.

After having enjoyed so many bottles of St. Bernie Prior and Abbot over the past several years, I was terribly happy finally to have found a few bottles of this.  The Pater is clearly in the same tradition as the other two: as soon as you pour it you will instantly recall the familiar and wonderful St. Bernardus aroma of hazelnutty chocolate.   The flavor is the same as the big brothers, just scaled down here.  Its fun to have another take on the classic St. Bernardus flavor, but its tough to feel other than that ther is something missing in this: it doesnt have that same remarkable balance of the Prior.  Nor does it really make the most of its smaller frame.  ITs like looking at a guy whose suit is a bit too big.  Or "everything you want in a beer, and less".

Dark cloudy auburn colour with a foamy tan head.  The nose is yeasty and spicey with hints of fruit, pepper, alcohol - nice and fresh smelling.  The body is malty with a fair amount of yeast.  Fruity with a defenite alcohol presence.
warm fruity and refreshing with a light malt and hop fullness to ballance things out.  a little too sweet for my liking but still very good.  the alcohol is subdued like in most light belgins.

[Bottle, 33cl, Fresh, exp: 09-05-08, 14c]
Rich and hazy brown sugar color. Good white head that diminish to a thin film, leaving some laces. Aroma is dominated by the brown sugar but traces of pale malt + fruits. Taste is very sweet, nice but simple. I should leave my other bottles age more.

Dark Red Coloring with Sandy Head.  Dark Bread Taste, Bread Dough, Dry Fruits, Heavy Mouthfeel....Some Alcohol Warming Works its Way up and Ends with a Dry Bitter Finish.  Solidly a Great Tasting Belgian.
Creamy off-white head. Noticable spice in the aroma. Sweet malt and fruit flavors.
Very fruity scent, similar to a wine.  Ruby brown body with a medium white head.  Sharp fruit flavors are present with the typical Belgian cottony taste.

Very fruity yeasty aroma. Weird, not unpleasant smells that remind me of cleaning products. Hazy brown with a loose head. Tart and fruity flavor with some earthy fig and cherry. Finishes moderately dry. Spritzy mouth feel.

Beige creamy full lasting head. Mahogany color. Aroma is moderately fruity with vinous, yeasty notes. Flavor is fruity with raisins, chocolate, banana and light caramel tones, ending  in a caramelly long finish. Medium to full bodied.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color ale with a huge off-white foamy head. Aroma of sweet raisins with the distinctive Belgian yeast. Taste can also be distinguished by the sweet malt and raisins with a candy like sweetness also present. Body is a bit too thin but carbonation is quite good. Another fine beer from a great brewery.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 Every beer has its day. And Pater 6s day was the day after Thanksgiving 2005. It was a glorious day. The sky wasblue  the air was crisp. The ocean was very clear but a bit cold. We decided against the turkey leftovers and ate Pad Thai  off my foot insead. Oh yeah, I forgot the beer was reddish brown in color.

Pours medium brown with a nice flluffy light tan head. Pleasant fruity aroma - grapes, apples, pleasantly sweet aroma. Taste is fairly sweet caramel, some dark fruits, with barely a touch of bitterness. Palate is fairly light. Not detecting any alcohol in the palate, but a very slight warmth in the belly. From Grapevine in Austin.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: Pours dark red with a large eggshell head that leaves good lacing. Very fruity aroma, with Belgian yeast and spices. Fairly sweet at the beginning, with toffee, caramel, and raisins. The sweetness really comes through on the finish, which is excellently malty.

Deep amber color, with orange highlights and tan-colored foamy head. With some spicy notes, brown sugar, caramelized malt, fruity of figs, raisins, hint of chocolate, with a sweet malt aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a fruitiness note of figs, raisins, dates, a chocolatey accent, brown sugar, molasses, caramelized malt leading towards a sweet malty finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 One of my favourite beers yet.  Very foamy head, but next to no carbonation once the head dies down.  The head is unusually tasty.  Very aromatic: extremely fruity, and never in an unpleasant way.  Tastes much like wine.  Sweet, but in a completely acceptable way.  Oddly, I taste a lot of alcohol, but its not unpleasant.  Sort of caramelly, but in a subtle way.  Very enjoyable, and although pricey, not unreasonably so.  In my opinion, this beer beats out a number of more expensive and rarer competitors.  Its also my favorite among the St. Bernardus brews.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2006 Bottle (330ml).  Poured clear deep copper with a beige lasting average head.  Aroma of sweet whole-wheat bread dough, raisins, fruits, spices - really nice light caramel roast malt.  Taste is mild, follows the aroma, somewhat lively and sweet.  Pleasant, was expecting a blond, so bonus.  Very mild.
Dark red color with a thin head.  Good malt and bread aroma.  Malty flavor with a sticky sweet syrup finish.  Slight fruitiness.

Murky brown pour topped with a fluffy mocha head. Plums and prunes in the aroma. Roasted malts too, with a mild alcohol waft to back it all up. Wood and prunes in the mouth, roasted malts, with a fruity alcohol aftertaste. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied. Pretty good.

Tasted in Toronto.  Obtained from LCBO as part of some form of winter / fall line up.  Tasted in Orval trappist glassware.  Appearance is reddish brown with thin browinish / tobacco coloured head.  Somewhat murky and amazingly disturbing....Aroma of plums, dried fruit and alcohol....Maybe even on a good day christmas pudding....Flavour is somewhat dry and crisp....not nearly as sweet, matly, deep dark and delicous as I would have expected....more on the slightly sweet to dry side with hints of nastyness lingeriing in the background, but only as a minor player and not as a lead character.  Oh well, such is the beerian play of life....

Light, soft aroma of sweet malt, hits of vanilla, yeast. Neat and clean. Light brown with ruby hue. Impressive crown on top .Full bodied, bready malt based ale. Alcohol is present but this only help making great winter warmer. Very nice.

(bottle) Hazy and dark amber colour with a frothy tanned medium head. Light sweet malty nose with caramel, yeasts and dried fruits. Light sweet flavour, medium bodied, moderately carbonated. Slight sweet roastmalty start with caramel and a note of raisins and dried cranberries, dry and medium bitter finish. Tasty but still pretty decent Belgian Ale.

The Lure:Prunes and dates converge on the yeasty brown sugar. Cocoa powder amicably joins in to create a fine perfume of obvious trappist influence.

The Festivities:An expansive, big-bubbled mouthfeel spreads its effervescence all over the cocoa/yeast merger. Bread flour and raisins rise into a fluffy cake. A meek roastiness offers mild bitterness. Very easy to drink, this is clearly a smaller version of the 8 & 12.

Transcendence:A clear mind yields thorough results.
Pours a murky brown. Light mango and fig aroma with a faint black licorice undertone. Lively feel. Hides the alcohol well.
fruty yeast, nice aftertaste, slice bitternes.

No#52. Aroma is very yeasty, and quite fresh. Taste is excellently malty, mollasses and nuts have a part to play aswell, sweetish great finish. As good as i expoected as i really wanted to get one of these before i came over.

Bottled.
Hazy red brown coloured with a yellow head.
Aroma of dried fruits with notes of caramel and fruits.
Sweet fruity flavour with notes of dried fruits, yeast and hops.

Dark cloudy brown with a thick, light beige head. Aroma of pear, dough/yeast, noble hops and a touch of champagne. Flavor has notes of apple, caramel, light brown sugar, some dark fruit, toasted malt, light chocolate and floral hops. Pleasantly sweet, fruity finish. Alcohol content very well hidden. Medium body with soft spritzy, bubbly carbonation which mellows as it warms. Great head retention. Enjoyable.

Dark orange-amber with cream-coloured head. Loads of higher alcohols compete with a complex mixture of white pepprs, toffey, caramel and dark malts. Some fruity esters of banana an raisins gets involved as well. Somehow I think that this beer will be better if stored for a while. However, it is highly drinkable as it is!
Brownish colour. Fluffy light brown head, which is mostly lasting. Aroma of caramel and licorice. Full body with lots of taste

Bottle, Brussels, May 05.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy medium brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread, nuts), moderately yeasty (mold, cobwebs), with a note of raisin.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.
Slightly hazy brown. Fluffy head with nice lace. Light hints of drak fruits, but not in heaps. This reminds me of a low alcohol Qaud. Everything is similar but toned down.

Appears a hazy brown with a large clumpy head that lasts. Plenty of lacing is left behind.
Smell is of fresh dough, figs, raisins, caramel, fruity mango and peach.
Taste is of the above aromas in a yeasty batch with a definite sugar content but not a real sweetness.
Mouthfeel is fizzy, slightly sweet, medium bodied with the yeast coming through.
Drinkability is good with this classic Belgian dubbel.

Pours a deep opaque brown with ruby highlights and a thick and persistant fluffy beige head. The nose is fruity reminding of berries, nuts and Irish cream. As you take a first sip the rich generous foam hits the tongue, velvety and smooth with a slight tingle. On all sides beautiful thick lacing clings to the glass. The flavors are well balanced mingling roasted caramel, dark fruits and some spiciness. Complex but not overbearing. Relatively light palate with a very creamy feeling and an easy finish that invites you for another sip. Peaks around 8°C. I was surprised to see this one rated so low!
dark cloudy brown pour, lots of off-white frothy head. sweet dark fruit aroma.  spicy, mild sweetness, raisiny flavor. good light carbonated mouthfeel. not bad!

12 Jun 2005 - (Auberge La Meneure, Thannenkirsch, Alsace) - Sweet fruit and some earthy over ripe fruit aromas.  Cloudy red-brown colour, fantastic lacing and head.  Spicy hop sweet fruit but not over the top witheach.  Light mouthfeel and well balanced taste/finish, with lingering fruit.
A rich brown color with a tan head. Very deep and rich flavor with dark fruit flavors (currants, cherries). Seems light and watery, yet still full.  An interesting Belgian ale.

In the 0.33L bottle from Dirty Johns. Mighty tasty beer. Poursa purple-brown in color with a large boisterous head. Sludge in bottom comes out black. Very fragrant with a delicious combination of fruity berries and malt. Thick palate which fights you all the way. This tastes like an abbey ale without the high alcohol or tartness. A very satisfying brew.

Dark brown in the glass with a rocky inch of light tan head.  Aromas of dark malt, brown sugar, licorice, caramel.  Some fruit on the nose, too, with banana and a wine-like floral quality.  Flavors are less dense, but still complex, with a sweet banana-orange and clove undertow to the caramel of the malts.  Palate is a bit thin, with just a bit of fine carbonation.  The rating seems too low for this beer.  Judging from recent reviews, maybe they have just now got this one right.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Ruby brown with persistant head. Malty aroma with caramel, banana, yeast, nut. Good warming mouthfeel, fruity finish. I enjoyed this.
full bodied brown ale.  lots of fruit in the nose.  a bit spicy and malty.  medium finish.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 Pours medium brown, huge off-white head. Dark fruits, spice, bread/biscuits, faint alcohol. Flavor on par. Ripe fruit, light spice, metallic character through the middle, dry biscuits and alcohol through the finish. Billowy mouthfeel, turns slick. Well attenuated. Metallic character is detracting a bit.
(Bottle)  Pours a cloudy brown body with a reddish tint and a small creamy beige head.  Aroma of toffee, toasted malt, nuts, and spices.  Flavor of toasted malt, banana, and caramel.

wonderfull looking beer, brown with a HUGE biege head. aromas of fruit, yeast, camille and sweat(farmyard?). taste: caramel, fruity, bubblegum, bit bitter, alcoholic sweetness. finish is long and fruity. silky mouthfeeling. very nice!

Mid-brown colour with a dense head; plum, cream, spice and chocolate aroma; sweet/bitter taste with black chocolate, pepper, toffee, roast and fruit aromas; bitter finish with black chocolate, burnt, liquorice, toffee and chicory aromas.
Now Westvleteren Red has gone, this will have to do. A beer packed with flavour and character. It drinks like a beer 2 or 3% stronger. Has some very pleasant dark malt flavours.

Bottle at Ommegange. Deep brown in color with a nice fluffy head. Aroma is fruity and malty. Raisiny. Hoppy and malty flavor. Full bodied beer. Earthy and woody notes. Well balanced beer. Drinkable. Very nice.

Deep tawny brown colour with a lasting, fluffy, beige head. I would have assumed that this was an abbey dubbel but what do I know. Quite a reserved beer if it is. The aroma isnt very pronounced. Bits and pieces of caramel and wood. On the palate its dry, with some roasty malt, licorice and dried fruit but, again, its not very forthright. The mouthfeel is a bit chalky, with earthy and woody edges. Not very rich. Finishes distinctly bitter. Nothing wrong with it, but it doesnt have enough presence to score higher. 2001 bottle (I think - best before date was 31 December 2004, so it might have been a bit past its best) frombeersofeurope.co.uk.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 First off, I dont agree with your opinion, Kevin.  Aroma is a blend of oatmeal and malt.  Head looks like a thick bowl of cream of wheat.    Flavor is a fleck of that Belgian sourness followed by a rush of yeast, oat, and malt.  A very biting finish.  Good stuff; Id buy more.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Beautiful clear deep red color with a fluffy white had and weepy lacing. Nose of cookie dough cookie dough and plum/raisin with notes of notes of pepper. Nice raisin flavor with a short earthy bitterness that balances it out. Much lighter in body than either the 8 or 12 but that almost makes it nicer to drink. The malt develops as it warms. Very nice beer.
Very complex aroma with spice malt and sweet fruit. Cloudy brown colour eith excellent head and lacing. Sweet malt fruit flavour. Smooth palate.

bottle. Smokeless Joes. muddy copper-orange body with a small, long lasting off-white head. beautiful aroma - plum, dark fruits, bread,  and alcohol. rich malty body, light yeast finish with notes of chocolate. nice soft body. pretty damn tasty.
Pour is cloudy brown with nice tan head...smell is yeasty and bread malty...taste is the same...deliciously chewy...great easty drinking session quality...

Bottle. Yeasty, malty aroma with a hint of metal. Chestnut brown colour, quite stable head. Nice flavour, a little sweet, malty and hoppy. Long bitter aftertaste. I like the mouthfeel, it is creamy without being thick.
Gorgeous mousse-like head of foam on a deep ruby brown/garnet body. Smooth, some hop bitterness, spicy, clove-ish, apple fruity aroma/flavor, some caramel. Delish.

bottle. sitting at lumps computer and we each have a glass of this. pours a ruby brown with a dark cream colored head that lasts throughout. aroma is raisin, watermelon, dust and yeast. very smooth flavor that is spicy, lump mentioned ginger, i can see that, also a nice hop bitter like a weak iced tea,everything in this one mixes well. the sweet vanilla flavor that comes out as it warms is great. there is an almond flavor in the finish later on in this one also. another good beer from a good brewer

Bottle. Very thick beige head on a dark garnet body. Nose is very musty and old. Taste-butterscotch, cherry, caramel, ginger, and apple. Very interesting layerd taste. The flavor is very smooth with a slight hop bitterness that is just right. I dont too much care for the strong mildew/old book/dust aroma, but the flavor of the beer really makes up for it. I could easily drink this.

Pours a rich opaque nut brown with a frothy tan head into a Chimay chalice. Yeast can be seen floating on the foan. (yes, I poured it in!). Lots of thick lacing. Smell is spicy, spiced sweet apple and tart Granny Smith. Cinnamon and clove and funky yeasty aromas.

Taste is much like the nose. Spicy and a bit peppery or a gingery bite to it. Fruity apple flavors and grainy. Dryish too, which is odd. Some hops if the finish and aftertaste and a little thin in the mouth compared to the general flavor explosion. Really tasty and drinkable. Does the happy monk do anything wrong? Not even a favorite style of mine and they still knocked my socks off. Highly recommended.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Best before:  August 13, 2007.  Light ruby pour with a thick, creamy light-tan head and tons of tiny floaties.  Some ample lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is very subtle.  Some hints of strawberries.  Very high carbonation that detracts from the flavoring.  Nicely balanced body, but a little toward the thin, watery side.  Some hints of tangy strawberries.  Crisp and refreshing with some light wheaty touches.

2001 Bottle.   Pours a very dark mahogany color with a bit of yeast resting on the bottom and a thin, off-white head.  Aroma is yeast, raisins, prunes, oranges, cinnamin, and light carmel.  Taste is a smooth blend of banana bread with nuts and raisins.  Very slight citrus flavor in the finish.
Bready,candied fruits,mild malt. Rich and tasty. Too easy to drink. Another nice beer from one of my all time fave brewers.

Shared w. Greg Clow at Smokeless.  Nose is bready, floral, some maple.  Rusty with a thin head.  Rich malt, plum, maple, wood, cherry, tingly hoppy finish.  Id like this one more if it was paired with food.

Copper red, deep caramel body with a thick frothy and lacing tan head.  Light aroma of sweet fruit.  Taste of candied caramel and light malt with just the right kick of carbonation to balance the palate.  Nice, smooth beer, but definately the "lighter" of the St Bernardus greats.
Brown with a tan head and some sediment.  Sour aroma with spices and woody notes. Slight fruits notes present in the aroma as well.  Really spicey with quite a bit of malt and yeast. Very dry finish.

Bottle, Smokeless Joes.  Dark brown pour, small white head.  Very carbonated appearance - slow down bubbles!  Spicy and malt what is now to me a "St Bernardus" aroma.  Thin crisp mouthfeel.  Muted spicy yeast taste - like a watered down 8.  Not outstanding really, especially compared to the high standards of the other beers from them, but on its own, a very quaffable Belgian.

Bottle shared with rudolf at Smokeless Joe. Hazy reddish-brown colour. Aroma is musty, earthy and malty, with some dark rye notes. Flavour has some brown sugar and malt notes, with a bit of dark chocolate. Finish is warm and tingly.
Had this at the Het Elfde Gebod bar in Amsterdam.  Smells like a freshly roto-tilled yard but has a fizzy soda-like feeling in my mouth.  Also reminds me of bread.  Like roto-tilled bread.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Light dark colour, hazy - almost like melted milk chocolate... Malty with a very light mouthfeel. Incredibly pleasant - and easy - to drink. Only medium body. 170893
Whats up with the happy guy on the label?  Anyways, this had a slight, lingering head with a fizzy mouthfeel.  Nice earthy, malty, bready flavor.

Nice lacing, big frothy St Bernardus head.  Seems to get bigger the lower the numbers.  Theres dark chocolate, sweet malts, a touch of brown sugar and a hint of port.  This is a delicious beer keeping with the always fin St. Bernardus tradition.

From the bottle this pours a medium amber, very clear with a small bubbled white head. The aroma kinda caught me off guard, very pilsner like, crisp and hopped, but the spice gradually showed as it warmed. This brew had a light malt base with a light hop finish, i think this was served a bit too cold as the spice only showed after i let it sit a while. Afterwards a nice balance of light malt and faint hopping blended into a refreshing light belgian brown ale.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2005 Picked this up as a 4 pack sampler with a nice St. Bernardus glass from Shangys in Emmaus PA.  Very nice full bodied abbey.  Head stuck around for quite a while and was a nice addition to the overall enjoyment of this one.

Bottle. Medium ivory head that was mostly lasting, fair lacing, fine-large sized bubbles, transparent, and a brown hue. Malty, caramel, spicy, light chocolate, and light alcohol. Sweet, malty, caramel and vinuous flavor. Tingly, bubbly and dry mouthfeel. Medium body.

Bottled (BB 11/2007)
Chestnut brown, a bit hazy, good off-white head.  Aroma has roasted malts, soy sauce and cheese plus hints of "Bernardus" licorice. Medium-bodied. Bun yeasty flavor, cloves and raisins,  late light alcoholic bitterness. Some licorice also in the flavor. Quite easy to drink Belgium. Well-balanced "low-alcohol" abbey ale.

Bottle, Smokeless Joes in Toronto. Dark ruby brown with a small white head. (3+) Dark sugar and malt in the aroma, minute touch of burnt licorice. Sweet malt up front, and a very dry alcoholic finish. More fruity brown sugar and licorice. Average palate, thin for a Belgian.

Very heady with tight foam.  Copper/ambler color with floating particles but quite clear.  Grapefruit and spice aromas.  Cloves, ginger, citrus notes with a suble maltiness.  Good beer to start with if you are afraid of Belgians.  Cheers!

Beautiful deep crimson, near-mohagony color, huge head, cocoa-toned, dripping lace on the glass. 
Nutty aroma, cola-ish, deep and earthy, some spices, hints of chocolate...nice.
Taste: yum, more of the same nuts and cocoa from the nose, very tasty, like a mellow dubbel, or a more lofty brown ale. Delicious. And thats only the start of it...this is simple and complex at once, a very deceptive ale, almost light and unassuming, but ultimately stirring with character, the flavor getting livelier and more exceptional the further in we get. 
given time, I could think of a million uses for a beer this great, but the best one is as an active ingredient to an oncoming case of happiness.
Im going to have to make this beer a more intimate part of my life, and keep it well at hand, for anytime I need a jolt of delight and deliciousness.

Bottled.
Dark amber.
Fresh, ozonish aroma. Rather vinous.
Champagneish palate and rather thin.
Shiny amber, offwhite head. Somewhat yeasty aroma with malts. Weak malty flavor quite thin compared to other St. Bernardus-brews...

Hazy dark amber colored, white head. Sweet malty and caramelly aroma, somewhat sticky with notes of yeast. Malty flavor with brown sugar hints and yeast. Dry finish. Drinkable but not very interesting.
Cloudy, brown, with a good-sized tan head. Cidery nose with yeast; tangy, light sweetness. Flavor is light, almost watery. What is there is fairly bitter with biscuity malt and  a light lemony tang.

Excellent session beer of great depth and complexity. A gem for only 6.7%. lots of fruit forward notes with good spice and hop notes. Clean malt background with no hint of astringency. Toasted almonds and cocoa with Bananas pears and turbinado sugar.

Appealing reddish to dark reddish brown, cloudy, white head, aroma ... slightly above average, some notes of dark fruit, though faint, flavor is mainly that of mild dark grapes, sugar, and some bread, finish is light and slightly bitter.

Very pretty hazy ruby/brown with a quickly diminishing big head to a very thin soapy froth. Aroma is a bit thin. Palate is very light and soft. Mildly acidic. Caramel, burnt sugar and very earthy. Peculiar chocolate taste that wanders in and out. Its quite balanced, and the flavours although subtle are very nice, but watery.
Bottle: Pours a nice dark color in the glass.  Slight red tinge in light.  Doesnt fill up the St Bernardus glass that it came with.  Flowery aroma.  A good fruity taste with a very smooth finish

Just because its the lowest on the chain of abv doesnt mean it sucks....i found this beer quite enjoyeable and a bit easier to drink do to this factor.  at first i thought it may be slightly thinner then its predessesor, which it is, but as this beer warmed  some nice rich fruit aromas and drk tobacco leaves pushed with a pop of sweet malty bread.  a nice beer and one i would definately drink again.

strong spritzy aroma with slight berry notes fought through my congested nasal passage as  my eyes feasted upon a chestnut brown body nestled below a large frothy head, soft mouthfeel and fruity with notable hop presence and bitterness

Fine hazy brown beer, good beige foam. Elegant nose of malts, dark sugars, cakes nuts and some hops. Refreshing taste for a brown beer. Good fizzy feeling with a fine dosis of nuts, malts, sweet bread and dry figgs.
Very nice beer.
comes w/ the gift set, not as memorable as the 12, but still decent.  very drinkable.

Aroma of brown sugar, treacle and candied malt, hazy pomegranite colour, pours a good sized tan head, some fine lace. Flavour is of pit fruits, with an almondy taste as well, nutty, woody, hints of toffee too. Well balanced, medium bodied, pleasantly bitter. A pleasurable offering!

Pours a muddy brown color with reddish highlights and a thick, frothy off-white head. Appealing and complex aroma of  spices, fruits, molasses and yeast with candy-like sweetness. Very good flavor of spices, fruits, molasses and yeast.  Light to medium body, very smooth and creamy texture, soft carbonation. Its better than what I remember, it makes me feel very relaxed after a long day of work, so relaxed that I feel like being on the week-end.
Deep amber/brown pour.  Large white head.  Sweet and yeasty aroma.  Lively carbonation in the mouth, great flavor.  Richly Belgian, smooth and drinkable.  I could drink a lot of this.  Quite tasty.

11.2oz poured into St Bernardus glass. I actually enjoyed this one more than the 8. Poured a medium, murky brown with amber hints. Nice size head. Sparky yeast leaving a somewhat roasted aftertaste....Mostly raisins and some clove sets in. Somewhat sweet with hints provided courtesy of our friend, the banana. Aroma carries a nice spice nick to it. Enjoyable.

Rich brew, long and dry finish. Finally, Ive had it, at Smokeless Joes. Maybe not the best Saint B, but do they make anything less than great? Refreshingly drinkable. Liked the brown colour, the bubbles in the yeast, the lace; the spicy aroma. Unique smoothness.

BB 2004 (2002 vintage?).  Medium brown colored body with a red glow to it and some deep orange tints.  Perched atop is a massive beige head that sticks around persistently.  The first notes I get are of a strong yeast, producing earthy, dusty notes, soil, metal, and damp leaves.  Some notes of raisins and cinnamon creep in, with a bit of caramel when the beer is swirled vigorously.  At first sip, it is not what I expected, begins loose and watery, with a brown sugar and plum-like flavor, some very light banana and clove notes and a touch of chocolate.  As the palate gets used to the medium-light body, a good belgian yeast washes over the palate and I cant say it disappoints.  Caramel, light walnuts and nutty, dry yeast seem to be the big flavors.  On the finish, there is more mashed walnut and brown sugar like flavor, with a chewy yeast sensation (I poured the sediment in to the last couple sips).  Some alcohol is evident, but with this light of a body and 6.7 percent alcohol, Im not completely surprised.  At the end of the glass, as I stick my nose in, there is a sharp, raw ethanol scent that is unsettling, but Ive finished the beer, so I dont mind terribly.  Lightly sweet notes of yeast, aluminum and dark candi sugar linger on.  Depending on how much I swirl the beer, I get different levels of carbonation.  It seems that without letting it breath and swirling off the carbonation, it is too much, but after it evens out, there is a much smoother if somewhat more obviously light body.

Somewhat along the lines of a light dubbel or very light belgian strong.  Nice beer, but pretty one dimensional-light raisin-brown sugar flavor, good carbonation and not much else going on. FIne, but Id gravitate towards their bigger beers.

Bottle. Rust, dark fruit, brown sugar and a subtle hit of paint on the nose, not very pleasant, but interesting all the same. Palate is quite rich, sweet and a touch on the sticky side, before drying out a little. Alcohol shows through, aswell as brown sugar and baking soda, not really a fan of this, or the brewery for that matter, but it some interest to it.

Bottled.  This beer pours a cloudy brown/red colour with a big foamy head, which leaves a very fine lace on the glass. The aroma is coffeish and caramelly. The taste is predominantly caramelly and roastmalty. There are notes of figs and raisins, though. It all ends in a bitter, albeit slightly watery finish. That is the only downside of this beer, otherwise it´s very decent.
From a bottle.Chestnut brown in colour,ok head,same heavy fruit and spices.

Bread-like, floury, yeast aroma melds nicely with plenty of dark fruit esters and sweet toffee-like malts.  Beautiful tan head, two fingers deep, recedes to generous and lasting cover with excellent lacing.  Plums, raisins, cookie-dough yeast flavours are not as sweet as the aroma suggests but rather more focussed on the fruitiness.  Excellent soft texture with engaging carbonation and nice full body.  Bottle enjoyed with PitPit.  Thanks!
Darkish hazy color, big off-white head. Fresh bitter/fruity aroma. Nice fresh bitter/sweet fruity flavor, good heavy finish. Pretty good!!

11.2oz bottle from the gift pack with glass. The glass is a nice goblet wich displays the beer beautifully and captures the aroma to give you  a nosefull with every sip.   Pours muddy brown with a thick, creamy off-white head which shows some lacing.  Pleasant sweet malty aroma.  Doesnt taste as sweet as it smells, but has a lightly sweet malty start, then a dry, tart finish with some bitterness. Some dark fruit flavors which are muted somewhat by the bitter finish.  Nicely balanced.  Medium body, but a fair amount of carbonation lightens it up. Overall its a solid, enjoyable brew, though not spectacular.  I certainly wouldnt mind drinking it again.
This was a good beer.  It would go great with any meal or by itself.  It poured a nice brown color with a tan/white head.  The flavor was malty and the finish was dry.  Well done.
Not too bad.......brownish appearance, creamy head. aroma was a little sweet, fruity and malty as was the flavor. A little spicy and malty, not too shabby.

Pours turbid brown/ruby with a medium, creamy, white head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, cognac.  Tastes malty, dark fruity, with a dry finish.  Nice palate, but this one doesnt stack up to the finer Belgians or even the Pennsylvania Belgians I have access to.  That St. Berny chalice does kick royal ass though!

Deep brown colow with nice tan head.  Head sticks to glass as you swirl. Sweet figgy, nutty aroma.  Flavor is quite good, with spicy plumby, nutty taste.  A touch too much carbonation masks some of the flovor, which hurts the overall score.

A nut-brown beer with a hug light brown head. The aroma is sweet spicy with notes of yeast and nuts. The flavor issweet with notes of wood, spices, yeast, and nuts leading to a dry end. It is quite thin for a Belgian Ale and not very complex.
Dark brown colour wiht small off-white head. Aroma has some sweetness from dark fruits. Flavor is not as sweet as the aroma, but it has got some raisins and plum.

Bottle: Dark ruby with a light tan head.  Aroma is of yeast, toffee, toasted grains, alcohol, raisin, plum, and bread dough.  Taste is initially biting carbonation, sweet syrupy malt, toffee, raisins, mild pepper, yeast, bread, plum/cherry, and a hint of lemon.  Medium modied and very dry.

Muddy amber brown with a huge foamy head of large bubbles. Nose is interesting--a hint of toffee along with the normal St. Bernardus subjects. Full in both flavor in body, fruity with just a touch of residual sweetness and a good dose of bitterness in the finish to balance it all out. Maybe not the best the good people at St Bernardus have to offer but a stand-up brew none-the-less.

Dark ruby with a huge, fluffy tan head.  The nose is full of the characteristic house yeast.  Bits of dry, toasted grains, light toffee, notes of dark fruit, light smoke, doughy bread and a bit of raisin.  The body is not huge, but still substantial, especially for a "smaller" Trappist-type beer.  The flavor is good, but pretty dry and without much residual sweetness.  The finish is warm and relaxing, with a light bitterness that keeps things interesting.  Obviously a beer from St. Bernardus.  I like their stuff, but they start to become all the same with a house yeast that is so dominant.  Well worth trying.

Pours deep brown with a huge light tan lasting head. Yeast dominates aroma, along with some dark fruits behind. Sweet start, malty, toffee, raisins and other dried fruit. Finish is slightly dry. Medium bodied. Not bad.

Deep mahognay w/thick off whtie head. Yeasty, wheat, malt and slight citrus toffee quality on the nose. Foamy in the mouth with a heavey mouthfeel and sweet lingering finish. Cherry, malt, light toffee, and weird citrus flavors. Not bad.
Borwn sugar, some fruits, cinnamon, yeasty,.  Alcohol is apparant.  Dry finish.  A little thin.
Dark brown. Malt taste. No special flavors. Seeing the picture on the bottle, St. Bernardus must have had a few ones!
Aroma is alcohol and malt.  Dark brown with a large head that lasts a long time.  Flavors of malt and caramel.  Smooth.

Mostly carbonation, which is important but shouldnt be the defining character of a beer. Some malt, a little yeasty goodness and a hint of generic "granny smith" apple. The aroma is a bit rubbery. Not really impressed. More like Belgian flavored seltzer.

Bottled. 
Dark brown/red-ish colour. Yeasty backbone, not overly though. Smallish tidbits character. Rich, lively malt. A little sweetish, but pleasantly.

Poured a dark brown, red color with a medium sized, off white, creamy head that left nice lacing on my St. Bernardus chalice.  Dried fruits, light caramel sweetness, yeast, and alcohol in the aroma.  Taste was rather weak with tart fruits, then finished yeasty, dry, and earthy.  Carbonation was a bit too high for my liking as well.
Medium brown and quite opaque.  Nose of fruit and bread.  A bit sour & acidic, with notes of spices, yeast and caramel.   Not bad but not as good as their tripel.

Color is a very nice dark mahagony thats not quite clear but resonates a delightful glow. Expansive and tall foamy crown of dusty brown cream which remains for a good while. A solid thin waffle edging continues to stay present the whole glass down; impressive. Whispy webbed and tinkling lace is established all over the glass side as the cosuming progresses.

Aroma is very nice and soft with a somewhat crispy edge to it. Dark and dried cherry, banana, mixed berries, lemon waffer cookies dotted with powdered sugar and some touches of spicy yeast and phenols. Solid aroma and gets some interesting little hints and nuances as it warms, I keep thinking of a chocolate bread with cherries in it and those little lemon tea cookies as I continue to wiff it in. Yum!

Tastes are just as becoming as the wonderful display of aromas, soft and well rounded with the perfect carbonation that sits slightly dry quickly getting drier but never overly so with notes of the chocolate, berries, cherries, yeast, and lemon cookie crumbs. Quite a treat that remains smooth and inviting the whole way through. Complexing, subtle, and yummy. Super drinkable as it is beyond the threshold of any normal beer. Yet is thee calling card of the St. Bernardus line of yummy delightful treats. Drink and be merry just like the monk on the label. No wonder he looks so happy, he gets to drink this stuff everyday. Good stuff!
Dark brown color, light sweet fruity malty aroma and taste, medium body, light sweet finish.

Super hazy brown coloured body with a dense yellow tan head. Aroma of pale malt, light raisins, caster sugar & light fruits. Light to Medium-bodied; Mild malt flavour with some noticeable pit fruit & sweet qualities, but not much else. Malty/cardboard finish with some spices at the tail end. Overall, a decent beer, the Prior 8 & Abt 12 were better for their styles, though! This one is worth trying if you liked the other ones or like lighter abbeys. I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 31-July-2004 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 Bottled - Oxford BF.  A dark brown beer with a good white head.  A fruity malty aroma and taste with that added Belgian sweetness.  Nice but not a patch on the 12.  Score 3.6Subsequent rating scored 4.0. Average becomes 3.8
Lack of character is the word for this one, its body is flat and such, I was expecting more                                                                      .

I was slightly disappointed by Mr. Beranrdus. He poured a gloomy amber brown body but a thick kaki colored head. The aroma and flavor brought yeasty.. doughy notes, with hints of plums, raisons, figs, brown sugar and earthy oak.. slightly tart.  There was a nice black pepper rendering as well. The palate was velvety and creamy but the brew just wasnt all that exciting for me. A solid beer but it lacks any
hearty character!

Bottle from Rai Wine Shop, Birmingham. Darkish ruddy brown, with a big, soft head and smooth lacing. Chalky, grape aroma, with some gravy and choc. Extremely palatable beer, fluffy in the mouth. Smooth brown ale flavour, with a slight tart finish - cherry and strawberry cream Milk Tray. Easy drinking, not harsh, but equally not the most dramatic Belgian beer in the World.

Fruity raisiny aroma, some phenols, light bubblegum.   Sweet dark malt flavor, but not much in the way of excitement.  Very straightforward, light hint of raisin.   Nice carbonation in the head, but somehow the body of the beer seems thin and watery, at 6.7% alc, im wanting a bit more to chew on.

Bottle:  Aroma is dominated by raisin and some banana and alcohol.  Pours a dark brown with a decent off-white head with decent retention.  Excellent lacing.  Very fruity and malty with some wine flavor characteristics.  Slight alcohol in the finish.  Not much aftertaste, a little sweet.  Gets better as it warms.
Dark brown with a large lasting head. Aroma  reminds me of baby spit-up. Flavor is fruity and malty. Has a sparkling mouthfeel.

Deep red appearance with a brown edge.  Large head evaporated slowly leaving some lacing.  Aroma of whole grain bread and molassas.   Dark fruits mingled with the sweet malts in the medium-bodied flavor.  Some sourness in the long lasting finish.

Had this on tap at the AlpenHof Hotel in Mammoth Lakes.  Has a reddish brown color little carbonation and a thick white head.  Smell is of sweet malt/fruit.  Taste is full bodied of sweet malts/fruit/bread and finishes with a little alcohol flavor.  Overall a pretty good Belgian.
Pours reddish brown with a decent head.  Malty, yeasty, and slightly bitter at the end.

Welcome to Georgia...little friend.  Amongst the lofty level of St. Bernardus, this ale is not the greatest.  This is like saying that Scottie Pippen was not the greatest Chicago Bulls player of all time.  What we have here is a great complimentary player, with all his frothy head, smooth medium malted body, and clean sweet finish.  This is a big upgrade to your run-of-the-mill brune.  The candi sugar slightly overtakes the malt in the end.

This beer sports a large foamy beige head on an hazy reddish brown body.  Nice lacing is present and the overall appearance is nice.  the aroma has yeat, malt and fruity aroma.  Tast is initially sweet, malty and fruity.  Lots of bitterness is present in the finish and it reatians alot of residual alcohol in spite of its relatively modest ABV. Nice plaate and overall a nice double.

Decent look to it, much of the standard trappist goodness.   Then the aroma is more or less like the other St. Bs;  malty and yeasty almost like bread, but not as strong on this brew.  Flavor is about the same as the others as well, just toned down.  Has somewhat of a wine like finish to it, which is the most notable difference.

Pours a murky mahogany brown with a puffy and well-lacing off-white head.  Aroma is a mild, yet complex, blend of sweet caramel malt, bready Belgian yeast and candi sugar.  Starts with a soft bready sweetness turning slightly more dry toward a crisp, enjoyable finish.  Hides its alcohol very well and could even be described as a Belgian session beer.

Nice brown beer with a good ivory colored head.Medium rich aroma of fine roasted malts an candy sugar with a fine frechness in the nose.Smooth mouthfeeling with hints of ripe banana,malts,touch of honey with a soury frechness in the end.A very tastefull and very drinkable belgian ale.

Aroma is yeasty and doughy. Some sour fruit also detected in the nose. The apperance is a brownish red with a moderate head. The flavor is very murky and sour. Mouthfeel is a little thin. An ok effort but Im more excited about trying the 8 and the 12.

Dark brown with a rocky off-white head.  Aromas are yeasty and bready with some spice and sweetness.  Flavours are mild and fruity with more bready yeast and delicate floral notes.  Has a lovely soft foam mouthfeel.
This is a OK Belgian Ale.  Sweet, malty, and fruity flavors.  Finishes sticky, rich, and crisp.

Reddish brown pour with a foamy white head that is quite short lived.  The lacing is moderate.  The nose is malty with a flowery sweetness and a musty earthy yeastiness.  Taste is quite delicate and sweet with roasted dark malt, brown sugar, raisins, and bitter to spicy hops, which are supplemented by a dusty dry yeast strain.  The alcohol presence is a lot stronger than anticipated for a 6.5% ABV brew.  The mouthfeel however is quite watery and hollow.  I am coming to a conclusion, that among the Belgian style beers, Dubbles are the least favorite of mine.  This is not a knock on this beer.  The style just doesnt light me up.

BEER #498. I guess this is produced to a similar recipe to the now discontinued Westy 6 cap. Served in a chalice. Murky dark brown, slight orange hue, crumbly sediment in suspension, thin white head. Malt and yeast in the aroma. Taste is medium bodied, sweet, with malt in the back of the throat, yeasty with some fruit. This bottle benefited from a lack of carbonation, another great St Bernardus beer.

Pours from the bottle with a very dark muddy brown color. There is a medium tan head and some lacing. The aroma is mape, oak, apples and some raisins. The taste is very dry with bread, prune juice and and salt. This rubs me the wrong way. Another St. Bernardus that I do not care for.

Dark and mysterious brown ruby tinged body. Very nice rocky light tan head that exhibits real staying power. Glass lacing is quite nice. Fruity aroma that is not very complex. The flavor is a let-down, sweetness and alcohol, nothing else. The palate is also highly dissapointing, thin and overly carbonated. Not for me.
Hazy ruby brown in colour, huge beige head. Malty, spicy and slightly minty aroma. Sweet and a bit bready flavour, some cocoa, caramell and vanilla flavours. Sweet and spicy finish. Thin body...

Light sweetness, sugar, and some maltiness. Overshadowed by canvas and lactic sourness, bit of metal. Light hops, too. Deep copper red clear with off-white thin lacing head.  Medium high carbonation in medium watery, slightly heavy body. Chalky afterfeel. Starts with a bit of sweetness and no acidity, light bitterness. Finish is medium bitter - very dry, with some acidic nuttiness to it. After is dry and puckerish, nutty.

Bottle pours dirty brown, light off-white head, light carbonation, with nice lacing. &nbsp Dark malts and pitted fruit on the nose, but very subtle. &nbsp Flavor is somewhat malty, moreso than I recall having in a Belgian. &nbsp Light plum/fig flavor as well, but again, very subtle. &nbsp Mouthfeel is good, not overly carbonated, but the flavor isnt all that enticing. &nbsp Mediocre belgian. &nbsp Save your money for the Abt 12, it IS worth it.

A dark brown hue and a fruity, yeasty nose.  The flavor is slightly bland compared to what I was expecting.  Not earth shattering by any means. Sub-par compared to the other beers they brew.  Still quality though.

Very dark brown; preposterously huge, brown head, fast dwindling. Chocolate malt, mintsoap, touch woody in the nose. Sharp woody flavour to start with, then soft sweet malt comes adrift under a sharper roasted profile. Still some chocolate. Rather flat, dead mouthfeel, it's as if the beer's tired. Shame, because quite OK so far. Not thin, however. Not bad overall, but its bigger brothers are way more interesting.

A luscious velvety texture, that has a dark brown color and a nice tan perfect two inch head.  Very smooth and easy to drink, with some yeasty bread flavors like a sweetbread, with some cinnamon and brown sugar flavors, with just a little chocolate and toffee in the aftertaste.  Perfect.

Dark, near brown in color, huge, mostly lasting tanned head. Aroma is malty, pretty spicy, slightly roasted and sweet with notes of alcohol. Medium and smooth body. Sweet, wine-like, a bit roasted flavor with notes of alcohol, toffee and dark chocolate. Very nice Belgi but maybe a bit too light.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 (Bottled) Very dark brown wih a medium head. Aroma of rye-puddingy malt, lavender, rosemary, anise, orange-peel, and a touch of alcohol. Malt-accented, rye-puddingy, slightly sweet flavor with light herbs, anise, low bitterness, and fully hidden alcohol. Medium-bodied, soft and neutral palate. Overall a very smoothly balanced, malty brew. Not the most complex, but enjoyable and tasty - especially for the ABV.

Pours with a large creamy head. Alot of the head remains and provides a very nice velvety palate. Aroma is mostly metallic. Flavor is hard to dissect but is a mix of mild dark fruit, tea, and cola. Something , I assume the carbonation or the alcohol, creates a tingle on the tongue that keeps the flavor lively. Nice beer if you take the metal out of the aroma it would be even better.
St Bernardus makes great beers. This one is not as powerfull as Abt. 12, but the aromas and flavors is the same. Lots of bread.
Brown color with small head. Sweet nutty smell with malt coming on as it warms. Taste is of raisins and nuts with a bread taste coming at the finish. A good brown ale.
aroma is nutty not sure what else. pours redish brown with a offwhite head that slowly disapates. flavor is fruity with an essence of cloves. a pretty good belgan brown ale.
Dark brown with smallish head. Sweet, fruity (figs, dates, plums), bitter chocolate. Better than their "prior"?

1/4/04: bottle. orange-brown body with a light tan colored head.  some lacing.  fruit, alcohol and yeast to the nose.  malt and yeast to taste.  flavor towards the finish reminds me of the taste of white bread.
Raisin color. Top-notch caramel and toffee flavors. Port aroma. Soft woody middle. Sticky finish. Not the best St. Bernardus offering but I wouldn't turn it down.

This was quite a step down from the Prior and the Tripel.  Pretty well-balanced and very drinkable, but not a whole lot going on to distinguish it.  Somehow lagerish, a bit thin.  I wouldn't throw it out of bed for eating crackers.

The aroma is not very present - detect small traces of mint for some reason. Tea colored pour with a good off-white head and good lacing. Carbonation is a bit too high on this one. Flavor has bitter elements but just kind of misses compared to the other St. Bernardus. Some spicy notes compliment it - but overall something is missing.

Very dark brown body. Thin, tan head with nice lacing.
Fruit, malt, brown sugar, spice and yeast in the aroma.
Sour malt, yeast and a mellow Noble hop middle.  Sweet and spicy in the finish. Alcohol is there but not harsh.
Full bodied with an acidic, stripping mouthfeel.

Well nice going, Padre! Old St. Bernie (Kosar) whipped up another winner here, let me tell you. Looks like a non-hazy wheat brew. Just slightly overly malty but not unpleasant. Webster Slaughter dropped by and dumped a load of anice candy into this one. Not bad. Interesting. Thanks lipskin!

Deep brown in colour with some chunks of yeast.  Aroma was yeasty, with peaches and citrus, malt, and sweetness.  Flavour was malty, some licorice, with caramel sweetness and lots of carbonation.  Finish is slightly sweet with a medium bitterness.

Pours an opaque brown, murky with some sediment, long lasting beige head. Aroma of malt, banana, wheat and yeast. Flavor had bubblegum, yeast, malt, and brown sugar. Finish was kind of short. Rounded body, if the abv. was higher i think the finish wouldve lasted a lot longer. Still quite nice.

Bottled: Dusty amber coloured. Huge beige head. Lasting. Malt, yeast and spices in the nose. Malt, fruits, sweets and light notes of chocolate and alcahol in the flavour. Is light bitter and has a grassy and dry aftertaste. Good one.

Very deep chestnut hues, perfect head like a pillow that keeps a layer throughout.  Aroma of baking whole wheat bread, tiny bit of astringency.  Flavor of cracked wheat, like a loaf of grainy bread in a bottle.  Some faint nuttiness.  Very nice.
Thick, and I mean thick head. Nose is highly astringent. Body speaks of alcohol and chocolate. Interesting beer.

This beer pours a deep reddish copper color when held up to the light, otherwise it is a deep amber color. It is lightly hazy and is topped by a creamy off white head.  The aroma is slightly musty, complex and spicy to boot.  A definite spicy brew.  The carbonation tingles on my tongue as it goes down.  This beer is fairly dry though there is a slight sweetness here.  A hint of alcohol character is in the finish.  I get hints of bergamot, ginger, pepper and caramel, as well as a bunch of other flavors that I cannot quite pick out.  As expected from this "6" the body is fairly light, though as it warms up it gets a bit thicker and fuller.  This is good, the complexity is very nice and it keeps you interested in each sip as you try and dissect the flavor components.

Deep brown body topped by a fluffy head.  Aroma was sweet, tangy and 'fresh' smelling - like fresh picked citrus fruit.  An interesting combination of bready malts, citrus tang, light fruit, and carbonation.  Took a lot of warming for the palate to smooth out.

Hazy tawny brown color with a highly carbonated head and not much lacing. The aroma is very yeasty at first, bready. Notes of citrus and plum with a surprising alcohol presence. Flavor is very well rounded and creamy with a solid mouthfeel and finish that is extra smooth. This was a great belgian ale, very refreshing with all the qualities of a well crafted BSA.

Pours a cloudy mahogany with big white head and looks to be leaving a fair amount of lacing behind as it leaves.  Bready aromas with underlying fruits: plums and light citrus.  Flavor mostly of sweet malt, a little of the bread/yeast found in the nose is apparent. A nice creamy palate is finished with a kick of alcohol. I'm liking this BA.

Had this after the Grotten, color is the same brown, head is smaller, just crosses the glass.  The aroma is the big difference, much less aromatic.  Plum and brown sugar sweet mixed with yeast flavors, I was expecting something lighter.  Good beer though.

The beer as it sets in the St. Bernardus Trappist glass a very deep cherry, almost brown with the head a light tan majestic crown that is somewhat creamy in its texture and the lace a satin veil to seal of the glass. The aroma of sweet malted grains, over ripe plums, yeast, crisp and fresh with a bit of tartness, a real treasure to the senses, start is sweet malt and the top middling in its feel. Finish is humane in its acidity with the hops cordial in their spiciness, aftertaste is dry, slightly sour, a fine quaffing brew.

Nice dark amber color with a frothy white head. Soft malty aroma with hints of banana and toffee. Flavor is medium bodied, somewhat subtle. Finish is dry and a little bitter. Was anticipating a more robust, complex flavor. Still well done.
Dark amber color. Nice aroma, malt, candi sugar, fruity (banana), esters. Dry mouthfeel, nutty, roasted hazelnuts; caramel and malt; quite bitter.
Bottled. dark ruby with rich head. Vinous, deep toffee aroma. Softly maltym some banana, deep malt character. Raisiny and rather sweet.

Fruity and malty aroma. Brown coloured with a lasting head. Taste is not very strong, however okay; Fruity and malty, perhaps some spices. Balance is okay, however I expected more from a Bernardus brew. This one is a bit flat.

Deep ruby redish brown with the predictable St. B's creamy head. Has an earthy aroma that is laced with fruit (raisins?), yeast and malt. Creamy mouthfeel with some dryness at the end. Flavor isn't as complex as the others I've had from this brewery. Fruit and malt are present yet not strong enough. Seems like a weak dubbel in my opinion.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Nice ruby brown body with a small off white head. Nose is malted but with a woody, spiced, fruit combo in the mix. The flavor has more spice and a bit of dryness in it. Some cocoa and dried fruit as well. Smooth but with a moderately bitter aftertaste. Still good stuff though!

Pours an opaque purple brown, with a huge rocky foam that forms a large plateau in my glass.  Alcohol laced bananas and sweet whiskey wort aroma, along with some oak and other wood.  Large spicy palate.  Robust on the tongue - cherries, cloves, corriander, nutmeg all wrapped around soft sweet dough.  Very nice, but a long way off from the tripel.
Whispy light grainy nose with a lot of hay. Dull red borwn color. Brown sugar, cookie, carmell, awsome.  Surprisingly light with a strong cookie finish, solid.
Reddish brown, tan head. Fruity notes, as well as caramel malt. Some hop in taste, but mainly malty-sweetness.

Bottled. Ruby red/brown in colour with beige smooth head. I think the crew have got this spot on. The Trappist from St. B. was worth every bit of its rate, the 8 was up for it as well, but this 6 is a little bit cheap. Dry with an ethanol kicker its un-imaginative. The pubs have opened now, so I think its time to bid you all, au revior.
Color is dark brown dubbel color with a fine white head. Taste is sweet and malty. Not the finest dubbel out there but decent.
Decent and malty brown Belgian dubbel. Perhaps a bit sweet though. Not bad at all.
Dark brown beer with a good frothy head.  Excellent malty/fruity nose, with a hopped fruity flavour.  Overall a very good beer.

This moves around a bit, but is not as interesting as it should be. A decent rusty nose rubbed in boiled milk and sugar, then a somewhat tedious taste with that hard water mouthfeel that TAR picked out. And a short bitter finish that goes nowhere, like Lennon's Fool on the Hill. Rather like spanking a dead donkey.
Spicy aroma, dry flavour and dito palate.
Sweet cookie-like nose, hazy amber color, foamy head. Yeasty malty body with a wonderful. Medium bodied and a decent balance. Overall quite enjoyable and versatile.
Plums and rum nose and taste. Fizzy head on a light brown (with hints of red) body. Not that thrill!

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 (9/20/06, bottle) Clear dark copper body with beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, raisin/cherry, some alcohol.  Taste is medium sweet, raisin/plum, some rootbeer, alcohol.  Medim body, light acidity. (6/4/7/3/13)

(1/2/03) Opaque dark brown, highly carbonated tan head out of the bottle.  Aroma is richly fruity (fig & banana), butter rum, and slightly alcohol.  At the front of the tongue the flavor is slightly astringent.  As it moves toward the back, the flavor becomes sweet, fruity (fig, banana, slight raisin) and malty.  Warm mild alcohol aftertaste.  Too carbonated.  (7/4/6/3/13)
Very nice- dark, rich, nutty, fruity, malty, etc.
Nice beer. Creamy head, nice dark color. Malty, fruity taste, some toffees. I really enjoyed this one.
Full of flavour... rich and exciting.... I liked this one.  To bad I cant find it around me any more
toffee, anise, fig, creamy feel, full aroma, delicious! almost cheesy nose complexity
Wonderful big and creamy head which lasts. Some banana and maltyness in the nose. Notes of orange and cocoa in the flavour. Very good considering its low alcohol content.

Very easy drinkable. The lightest in the Bernardus serie, but not in taste. Fruity, malty and even alcoholic notes are found in both aroma and flavour. A great alternative when a no. 12 would be too much.
Very nice beer from Bernadus. If youre driving home take this! It is also the most thin one of the Bernadus series.

Light red-brownish with a big head. Sweet malty soapy aroma.  Well balanced. Sweet start with a slight bitter finish. The flavour goes towards a mild high level trappist like Rochefort 10 or Westy 8. I am impressed.
It has a real marmite yeasty aroma and taste to it. Interesting but its not really my cup of tea.

This blue labeled beer says St. Sixtus with Pater 6 on the cap. Could this beer be as much as 10 years old? Nearly black in color with huge chunks of yeast sediment floating about. Thick sludge covers the bottom of the bottle. Somewhat dense off-white head. Aroma like a port wine, dried fruits, candi sugar and some slight alcohol notes. Flavors of port, chocolate, prunes and an overall sweetness that finishes dry and quiet. Hop bitterness is restrained but noticeable on the sides of the tongue. I have one more of these in the cellar that I now consider the prized jewel of my growing collection!

Loaded with promise.  Gorgeous appearance--thick, fluffy head like a root beer float, on top of a pleasant dark brew, and the head persists for a good while.  Full marks for appearance.  Lovely aroma, too, lots of banana and a whiff of alcohol.  But the promise is not fully fulfilled in the tasting.  Slightly thin texture, relatively mild carbonation on the tongue, and a lack of flavor complexity.  Slightly improved as it warms.  Fine beer on the whole, but doesnt hold up against the very best Belgians, leaving me somewhat unenthralled.
Malty, herbal aroma. Hay. Rather sweet taste with citrus, liquorice, coffee and chocolate. Full bodied. Very nice abbey ale, warming and full of taste, in spite of its moderate alcohol content.

This is a very interesting beer. Ruby red-brown colour with a super large bubbled long lasting mid-beige head. The foam is quite strongly bitter but the aroma is wonderful. Floral, yellow apple, citrusy, malt and honey. The palate is a bit soft for my liking and probably its weakest point. Medium body slightly sweet /sour start, hoppy malty middle flavour and a medium strength shortish  bitter dry finish.

tremendous.  nuttybrown color with a red hue.
big malt aroma. hints of toffee and bananas.

hassa taste sikilar to a rum soaked fruit cake.   lots of fruit with plum and banana flavors dominating. also hasa sweet sugary alcohol taste.
smooth chewy palate completes a great experience

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2004 Big aromas of malt toffee and bananas (not quite 'liquid bread' more liquid banoffee). Good longlasting head with lots of lace and plenty of condition all the way to the end. More banana in the mouth balanced by malt, esters and a pleasant yeastiness. Aftertaste is dry with a salty bitterness and an alcoholic kick at the end. Got to use my St Bernadus glass for the first time in years!

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2003 Irony aroma.  I also noticed aromas of cream, butter rum, caramel and cocoa.  Pours with a head with mixture of small and big bubbles (usually means low quality, IMO) and turns rocky with moderate retention atop a hazy, deep orange color.  Mouthfeel is a bit too hard and carbonated.  Swirled my glass a lot to release Carb.  Taste is almond butter, nutty, yet lacking complexities.  A well made and interesting beer, but not worth the trouble it takes to find it.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Not much aroma, hay, bit rust. Ruby colour with beautiful firm beige head. Very full, round, sweet, dark malt flavors. Finishes smooth but still a bit hoppy.
I liked this beer actually. Dark appearance, bit yeasty malt taste. Easy to drink.
Nice starter for a beer drinking eavening, but as the eavening draws on, it loses its speciality.

I dont know why I liked this beer - dirty brown colour, nice head, fruity nose (mango, banana), very malty and yeasty, too much carbonation, very sweet, heavy with a quite disgusting banana aftertaste
A well-made light dubbel.
